HEADLINE: Drug Companies Increase Spending on Efforts to Lobby Congress and Governments 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 31 

 BODY:
Lobbyists for the drug industry are stepping up spending to influence Congress, the states and even foreign governments as the debate intensifies over how to provide prescription drug benefits to the elderly, industry executives say.
 Confidential budget documents from the leading pharmaceutical trade group show that it will spend millions of dollars lobbying Congress and state legislatures, fighting price controls around the world, subsidizing "like-minded organizations" and paying economists to produce op-ed articles and monographs in response to critics. 
 The industry is worried that price controls and other regulations will tie the drug makers' hands as state, federal and foreign governments try to expand access to affordable drugs. 
The documents show that the trade association, the Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America, known as PhRMA, will spend at least $150 million in the coming year. 
That represents an increase of 23 percent over this year's budget of $121.7 million. 
Directors of the trade association approved the new budget, together with an increase in membership dues to pay for an expanded lobbying campaign, at a meeting last week. 
"Unless we achieve enactment this year of market-based Medicare drug coverage for seniors, the industry's vulnerability will increase in the remainder of 2003 and in the 2004 election year," says one document, which laments the "demonization of the industry."
Congress will plunge into work on Medicare soon after it reconvenes next week. President Bush and Congressional leaders have said they intend to revamp Medicare and add drug benefits for the elderly. Both houses plan to vote on the legislation before the Fourth of July recess. But a struggle over drug costs and benefits is likely to continue for months, or years.
The drug trade group plans to spend $1 million for an "intellectual echo chamber of economists -- a standing network of economists and thought leaders to speak against federal price control regulations through articles and testimony, and to serve as a rapid response team."
The trade association and its tactics have become an issue. In debate on the Senate floor last summer, Senator Richard J. Durbin, Democrat of Illinois, said, "PhRMA, this lobby, has a death grip on Congress."
Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, said the drug industry made wonderful products, but was becoming "despised and hated" because of its aggressive efforts to keep prices and profits high.
But Senator Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah, defended the trade group, saying it had been vilifed as a "satanic" force, "a bunch of greedy, money-grubbing companies." In fact, he said, drug makers do more than any other industry to help people.
The pharmaceutical association gets nearly all its revenue from dues paid by member companies, according to the documents, which were obtained from people in the industry. Dues will total $143.8 million in the coming year, an increase of 24 percent, or $28.3 million, over this year's dues, the documents show.
In its budget for the fiscal year that begins on July 1, the pharmaceutical lobby earmarks $72.7 million for advocacy at the federal level, directed mainly at Congress; $4.9 million to lobby the Food and Drug Administration; and $48.7 million for advocacy at the state level.
In addition, the budget sets aside $17.5 million to fight price controls and protect patent rights in foreign countries and in trade negotiations.
The PhRMA budget allocates $1 million "to change the Canadian health care system" and $450,000 to stem the flow of low-price prescription drugs from online pharmacies in Canada to customers in the United States. 
The major pharmaceutical companies operate in global markets. Canada, like many industrial countries, offers health insurance to all citizens, but limits drug prices.
A memorandum for the PhRMA board says the industry is on the defensive, facing a "perfect storm" whipped up by several factors: "expanding government price controls abroad, resulting in politically unsustainable cross-border pricing differences; increasing availability of medicines from abroad via Internet sales"; state ballot initiatives to make drugs more affordable in the United States; increasing state demands for drug discounts in the Medicaid program; and "false perceptions that drug prices are increasing by 20 percent a year."
Exact comparisons are difficult, but a group facing similar problems, the American Association of Health Plans, budgeted $26 million this year to lobby for health maintenance organizations. 
In its budget, the Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America says it will spend these amounts in the coming year:
*$15.8 million to fight "a union-driven, get-out-the-vote ballot initiative in Ohio," which would lower drug prices for people who have no insurance to cover such costs.
*At least $2 million, and perhaps $2.5 million, in payments to research and policy organizations, "to build intellectual capital and generate a higher volume of messages from credible sources" sympathetic to the industry.
*$9.4 million for public relations, including "$1 million for inside-the-Beltway advertising, $555,000 for placement of op-eds and articles by third parties," $600,000 for polling, $1.3 million for local publicity in 15 states and $680,000 for media relations consultants.
The federal affairs staff at PhRMA has quadrupled, to 20 employees today from 5 in 1999. The organization plans to spend $5 million for outside lobbyists at the federal level. In their campaign contributions, drug companies have favored Republican candidates. But PhRMA has retained a diverse group of lobbyists to ensure access to politicians of both parties.
Its Democratic lobbyists, listed in recent reports to Congress, include former Representative Vic Fazio of California; David W. Beier, who was chief domestic policy adviser to Vice President Al Gore; Joel P. Johnson, who was a top aide to President Bill Clinton and to Senator Tom Daschle, the minority leader; and Nick Littlefield, former chief counsel for Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts.
Republicans who reported lobbying for PhRMA include former Representatives Vin Weber of Minnesota and Bill Paxon of New York; Dave Larson, former health policy adviser to Bill Frist, now the Senate majority leader; Edwin A. Buckham, former chief of staff to Tom DeLay, now the House majority leader; and Scott Hatch, the son of Senator Hatch.
The state government affairs division of PhRMA will spend $3.1 million to retain more than 60 lobbyists in the 50 states. The number of state legislative proposals dealing with prescription drugs has doubled since 1999. The drug industry says many of the bills "are seriously negative, have a high probability of enactment and require major attention on our part."
Dale Butland, a spokesman for the coalition seeking lower drug prices in Ohio, said the drug industry lobby was "spending money like water here," challenging the validity of signatures on petitions seeking a statewide referendum.
PhRMA said it would spend $12.3 million to develop coalitions and strategic alliances with doctors, patients, universities and influential members of minority groups.
The organization has earmarked several million dollars to foster ties with groups like the National Black Caucus of State Legislators, the National Hispanic Caucus of State Legislators and the National Medical Association, which represents the interests of African-American doctors.
The budget includes $500,000 for efforts to "educate and activate Hispanic-Latino organizations on a state and federal level."
Several Hispanic groups have joined the drug industry in opposing state efforts to control Medicaid costs by establishing lists of preferred drugs. The Texas League of United Latin American Citizens issued a statement last year saying it "stands solidly" behind a lawsuit filed by the industry to block the use of such lists.
Luis Roberto Vera Jr., general counsel of the Texas Latino league, said it received $10,000 from PhRMA to help pay for a workshop on Latino health issues last year. But "there was no quid pro quo," Mr. Vera said.
Ana Yanez-Correa, policy director for the Texas group, said PhRMA was "overstating and misrepresenting the amount of support it had" from Latinos.
Dr. L. Natalie Carroll, president of the National Medical Association, said her group had received small amounts of money from PhRMA. The grants, she said, helped the association publish research showing that different racial groups respond differently to some drugs.
As a result, Dr. Carroll said, state policies steering patients to the cheapest drug in a therapeutic class could be particularly harmful to black patients.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR: THE ECONOMY; 
After Years of Stagnation, Iraqi Industries Are Falling to a Wave of Imports

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 31 

 BODY:
Shakir Thiab and his Al Bayltha candy factory survived the American military invasion without a scratch. But the invasion that followed has all but shut him down.
 When the war ended in early April, a two-pound bag of his Fenom line of fruit-flavored hard candies sold for 3,000 dinars, or about $1.50. Today, faced with a flood of duty-free imports from Iran, he can only charge 1,000 dinars. 
 Cutthroat pricing is not the only problem. Opening a pack of his Garnaata-brand cream-filled wafers, Mr. Thiab noted gloomily that his wafers had congealed into an unappetizing mess -- a result, he said, of the inferior flour available to him. By contrast, imported Tasteful Wafers from Iran were fresh and crisp. 
"We dropped our prices to keep selling, but we cannot do business," said Mr. Thiab, who shut down most of his aging machinery three weeks ago. "Iraqis only want to buy foreign products now. They don't trust anything made in Iraq."
Mr. Thiab's problems are a foretaste of a much broader economic shock in Iraq. After 12 years of trade sanctions imposed by the United Nations, and 30 years of economic mismanagement under Saddam Hussein, Iraq's cloistered industry suddenly faces the full fury of globalization and international competition.
In the seven weeks since American forces seized Baghdad, Iraq has been transformed from one of the world's most isolated economies into a huge new free-trade zone.
Open-air markets and stores here are being flooded with television sets from South Korea, refrigerators from Iran and China, toasters from Germany, and packaged food from almost everywhere.
For Iraqis with any money to spend, the free-for-all has brought a dazzling range of new choices. Satellite telephones and portable kerosene stoves, badly needed to cope with the absence of normal telephones and the lack of cooking gas, are so plentiful that prices have declined.
But the downside is also taking hold. Iraqi manufacturers, which employed more than one-tenth of all workers before the war, are almost powerless to match the new competition.
Their equipment is badly outdated. Their sense of marketing has atrophied. In many cases, their image among Iraqi consumers is abysmal.
The free-market shocks are even bigger for Iraq's state-owned industrial companies, which produce everything from packaged foods to electrical equipment and employ more than 100,000 people.
Adding to the stress for manufacturers, the Iraqi dinar has unexpectedly soared in value since the end of the war. The strength of the dinar, which has increased to about 1,300 to the dollar from 3,000, has pushed down the cost of imports just as customs duties were disappearing.
All this poses a complex challenge for American and British officials. Hoping to improve business and investment in Iraq, American officials plan to announce a six-month tariff holiday on imports in the next few days. For the longer term, they speak grandly about hammering out a free-trade agreement between Iraq and the United States.
At the same time, American officials are desperate to get people back to work. That goal will be badly frustrated, though, if Iraq's manufacturing enterprises crumble in the face of new competition.
L. Paul Bremer III, the civilian administrator in charge of postwar reconstruction, hinted at the quandary at a recent news conference.
"Because the economy was so tightly controlled and so interlinked, you find that when you move one part of it, everything else moves with it," Mr. Bremer remarked. "You have to move quickly, but carefully."
The experience of postcommunist countries in Central Europe and Russia suggests that Iraq's traditional industrial enterprises will either collapse quickly or be propped up by political leaders at great cost to the economy as a whole.
But unlike Poland or the Czech Republic, whose leaders made their own decisions, the decision-making responsibility here lies overwhelmingly with the American administrators under Mr. Bremer.
Both Iraqi industry and agriculture declined sharply during the past two decades. Racked with inflation as Mr. Hussein printed money to pay for wars against Iran and Kuwait, Iraqi companies could not afford to import new equipment or to invest in improving their operations.
The trade sanctions imposed by the United Nations after the Persian Gulf war in 1991 aggravated the problem, making it difficult for companies even to get permission to import new equipment.
"We have not enjoyed political stability for more than 20 years," said Mr. Thiab, whose father started Al Bayltha. "As a result, Iraqi industry has stayed stagnant, backward in comparison with other countries."
All the machines in Mr. Thiab's candy factory are more than 25 years old, antiquated even in comparison with those in Iran or Syria -- much less those in the United States or Europe. The machines have been kept functioning only through ersatz replacement parts cobbled together by local machine shops.
In the Jamila industrial district, home to Mr. Thiab's company, at least a half-dozen other candy producers have essentially halted production. Electricity problems were one reason, but business owners said the biggest issue was competition.
"If you go to the markets, you will see the Iranian, Syrian and Turkish products," said Abid al-Karim, manager of Al Zayzafoon, a company that produces Queen Cocktail toffees. 
Mr. Karim's toffees sell for slightly less than Iranian rivals, he said, but he has halted production for the time being because, he said, "Nobody wants to buy them."
As for the state-owned companies, they enjoyed heavy protection from imports, and the United Nations trade embargo left them with very little competition in the first place.
"Before the war, people had to line up to buy our equipment," said Khalil al-Asadi, technical manager at the State Company for the Electrical Industry, a company whose most important products were motors in air-conditioners.
Today, appliance stores around Baghdad offer trim new air-conditioners by Samsung and Daewoo of South Korea, as well as by Japanese and Chinese conglomerates.
With postwar reconstruction picking up speed, and summer temperatures rising to more than 110 degrees, demand for air-conditioning systems is very high.
But Mr. Asadi's state-owned company is still barely functioning. The company headquarters was destroyed by looters, only one assembly line is in operation, and only one-tenth of the company's 3,000 employees are actually working.
Furthermore, the factory, which makes motors for water-cooled air systems, has deteriorated sharply since it was built in 1986. "This used to be very automated, but now it's largely manual," Mr. Asadi said, pointing to a vast dark building full of machinery. "We couldn't get the parts we needed."
American officials, trying to decide what to do with Iraq's 52 government-owned companies, are seeking advice from experts in Poland who went through that country's transition from communism to capitalism.
American officials and some Iraqis clearly want to privatize the state-owned manufacturers, and they see it as the only way to attract private investors.
But Ramsi Youssef Jiddou, a returning Iraqi exile who is advising the ministry, recently warned that privatizing the companies might be tantamount to dismantling them.
"We sold companies in the past, but it was not a good experience," Mr. Jiddou said. "Investors who bought the companies treated them like scrap material."
That would be consistent with what happened in some formerly communist nations. But state-owned or private, Iraqi manufacturers know they are too weak to stand on their own.
Mr. Asadi, at the state-owned electric manufacturer, is hoping for a partnership with an American company like Carrier, which makes air-conditioners.
Mr. Thiab pleaded for American officials to close off the border to imports, at least temporarily.
"I know Americans believe in free markets and globalization, but this does not work in all cases," Mr. Thiab contended. "If Americans don't protect Iraqi industry, we will all be unemployed."

HEADLINE: Roy Rogers and Dale Evans Ride Off to Missouri 

BYLINE:  By CHARLIE LeDUFF 

DATELINE: VICTORVILLE, Calif., May 27 

 BODY:
A small yet not insignificant piece of news occurred in April while the world's attention was turned toward Iraq.
 The Roy Rogers-Dale Evans Museum, an old-West cavalry-style fort on Highway 15 in the high Mojave Desert, picked up and moved. It has resettled in Branson, Mo., the transplanted heart of country-western life and culture. 
 The move was economic, said Victorville city fathers. Fewer and fewer people, it seems, are interested in the life of the "King of the Cowboys" or his wife, Dale Evans, known as the "Queen of the West." After Mr. Rogers died in 1998 and his wife in 2001, museum attendance plummeted.
People had come to this desert outpost to inspect his gun belt, boots and the museum's prized possession and top draw -- Mr. Rogers's stuffed horse Trigger.
"It's left a big hole in the heart of Victorville," said Mayor Terry Caldwell, who attended the same church as the first couple of Victorville. "There was a wholesomeness synonymous with Roy Rogers and now that the museum has gone, it marks the end of an era here."
At one point in the 40's and 50's, Roy Rogers was every bit the celebrity Bob Hope was. Like Mr. Hope, Mr. Rogers grew up in Ohio. His name was Leonard Slye and he dropped out of high school, making his way to California and the silver screen. His records topped the charts and his image appeared on 2.5 billion boxes of Post cereal.
The self-taught cowboy was known for his his patriotism. While Mr. Rogers made movies in World War II, he sold millions of dollars in war bonds and made a U.S.O. tour with Trigger. He also made a tour of Vietnam.
Sadly, celebrity fades. The Rogers generation is passing on and the new immigrants who have settled in California have little interest in these icons of old.
"Roy Rogers? He doesn't mean anything," said Rosalina Sondoval-Marin, who was having a beer in the El Chubasco bar on historic Route 66. "There's a revolution going on and it don't include no Roy Rogers or Bob Hope."
Perhaps. But for those who still care about the King of the Cowboys, the new Roy Rogers-Dale Evans Museum and Happy Trails Theater is scheduled to open in Branson in late June. It is behind Yakov Smirnoff's theater, Mr. Smirnoff being that Russian-born cold war comedian whose contributions to the country-western way of life are not entirely apparent.

Emilio Flores for The New York Times); Roy Rogers was Leonard Slye of Ohio before he became the "King of the Cowboys." He is with Dale Evans and Trigger in 1952. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: In Land of Sake, Brewers Suffer as a New Generation Sniffs Disdainfully 

BYLINE:  By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: YASUGI, Japan 

 BODY:
With his crisp Oxford shirt and banker's armbands, Takeshi Yamamoto strives for a modern look. A laptop sits on his office desk, and more importantly, computers regulate the most important processes on the factory floor nearby.
 But even 15 years of persistent improvements in his business, a distinguished sake brewery that has been in his family for six generations, have done little to change one vital and depressing fact. Sake, a product as distinctively Japanese as sumo wrestling and kimonos, has fallen brutally out of fashion. 
 Sake is still consumed widely in this prefecture of glistening rice fields and rolling hills that fronts on the Sea of Japan. But brewers say this has little to do with the fact that Shimane Prefecture produces some of Japan's finest sake. Rather, it is because the percentage of people older than 65 years is the highest in the country.
"There is no point in promoting sake among young people," said Mr. Yamamoto, who is 46. "When they first begin to drink, they swig cheap sake at parties, so sake has an image of being strong and of having a bad odor. In fact, all over Japan, the police use pictures of sake bottles with X's marked on them in their anti-drunken-driving campaigns." 
Recently, it has become easy to imagine Japan as a land of glacial cultural change. Antiquated symbols still supply many of Japan's most enduring stereotypes. Meanwhile, the country has been locked in economic stagnation for well over a decade.
The reality, however, as brewers of the rice-based drink are discovering to their increasing chagrin, could hardly be more different.
The statistics of sake production are grim. The number of breweries in Japan has halved since 1955. In just 12 years, from 1989 to 2001, domestic consumption of sake plummeted by 30 percent. 
Nowadays, as teenagers enter adulthood, their early experiments with harsh, industrial-grade sake typically lead them toward beer and wine consumption, which has more than doubled in little over 10 years.
A small twist in the situation is the fact that sake has enjoyed great success of late as a slightly exotic import in the United States. Many old-line brewers here say the export market is their only hope for survival, and not simply through overseas sales. If sake develops enough cachet abroad, they hope, there could be a rebound effect on its prestige among the young here.
"The key is getting young people to try it," said Mr. Yamamoto, whose small team of employees still affix the labels and seal the bottles of his brewery's more than 20 varieties of sake by hand. "If you give them a glass of good, chilled sake, they are invariably surprised. 'Mmm, I didn't know sake could be so delicious,' they say."
At the Kokki brewery, in the nearby city of Matsue, the fifth generation owner, Hiroki Iwahashi, 38, designed his salesroom with an elegant tasting bar, built around a bank of glass-door refrigerators so that people passing by might stop for a sample.
On this day, however, the salesroom was barren. Asked what distinguished his sake, Mr. Iwahashi paused briefly, then gamely picked and chose from the dozens of specialized adjectives that sake fans use to describe their brew, much as wine connoisseurs do. "Houjoun to toumeikan," or, mellow and clear, he pronounced, inviting a foreign visitor to swirl it around his tongue slowly. The drink had a delightfully clean taste, with intriguing flowery hints at the finish.
"Unfortunately, a lot of customers don't know very much about sake anymore," Mr. Iwahashi said. "They find it very difficult to choose."
At another Matsue establishment, the Miyako no Hana sakery, Umechi Matsumoto, who at 83 years old has been a master brewer, or toji, for 48 years, is anything but discouraged.
"My motto is, 'Make delicious sake and no one can be turned off by it,' " said the slightly bent toji, who served in Manchuria in World War II. 
Mr. Matsumoto eschews the computer controls that most sakeries have installed to cut costs and improve consistency in a product that is especially temperature sensitive. "My secret weapons are my senses. That's the most important thing."
The one concession to modernity at this prize-winning producer is a cagelike freight elevator installed a few years ago so that Mr. Matsumoto, and his 67-year-old apprentice, would not have to carry the heavy bags of rice up a steep, rickety stairway to the brewing vats, as they once did.
"This is my destiny," he said in his small, junky office, dominated by a poster of beautiful calendar girls. Using no computer controls means sleeping here to keep vigilant watch on the production temperatures through the frigid winter months, after the rice harvest, when sake is produced. 
"I'd like to continue as long as I can," Mr. Matsumoto said, his eyes suddenly cast downward. "I feel like I've got another three years in me."
Though she has not said as much to Mr. Matsumoto, the owner of the sakery, Yuko Harada, is equally uncertain about how long she can continue in the business. 
"Back in the late-Edo period, my family used to make candles for the Matsue castle," Ms. Harada, a 47-year-old who took over from her father 15 years ago, said, recounting the origins of her brewery in the 1860's. She spoke in a setting that was old Japan, down to the smallest detail: a sumptuous tatami-floored room, with shoji, or paper screen doors, that looked out onto a formal Japanese garden.
"I've got teenage sons, but I don't know how they will feel about succeeding me," Ms. Harada said. "This has been a bad business for a long time, so we haven't talked about it."

HEADLINE: As Far as the Eye Can Climb, Towering Spots With History 

BYLINE:  By C.J. HUGHES

 BODY:
IT is hard to pass through Connecticut without a mandatory pilgrimage to Gillette Castle, the perennially popular stone citadel on a tall river bluff that has become as much of a symbol of the state as the nutmeg. Yet Connecticut offers plenty of other options for a climb to a mountaintop aerie, and you might win points for originality for suggesting such a destination.
 Strung across the state like beads on a necklace, from the northwest's limestone peaks to the eastern highlands' gneiss hills, these castles were for the most part built in the early 20th-century, an era when any rise in elevation demanded creation of a place to appreciate a good view. 
 Honoring Romantic ideals that emphasized the interplay of humans and nature, builders threw up roads, trails, pavilions and towers -- anything that allowed for contemplation of a beautiful vista. 
"Back at the turn of the century, the idea of the scenic overlook was born, predating even automobiles," said Bob Reynolds, a program specialist in the Department of Environmental Protection's state park division. "The ideal was to be able to take a picnic, go out and do the family thing, but in sight of nature."

Bavarian Retreat
On Talcott Mountain, off Route 185 between Bloomfield and Simsbury, for example, George Heublein, a Hartford liquor tycoon, built an opulent summer home in 1914 that rivals Gillette Castle. Fashioned in the style of a Bavarian retreat, Heublein's three-story, cream-colored stucco house has oak-paneled living rooms, a wine cellar, servant's dining quarters and a pitched Spanish tile roof. The point of Heublein's spire soars 1,145 feet above sea level and looms as if a lighthouse for the Farmington River valley.
The tale of Heublein Tower in many ways echoes the history of much of Connecticut's hilltop parkland: former estates of the wealthy that wound up in the hands of the state. Heublein first sold his home to The Hartford Times. Then the state bought the property in 1965 and immediately set about opening it to the public. In the rush, many of the home's pre-War trappings were destroyed and are only now being restored. Yet, the tower still stands as a lavish lookout, a fact not wasted on the hordes of locals who climb the tower's 120 steps between Memorial Day and Halloween.
"Everybody in the three towns surrounding the park has been up there at some point, and they always come back with their guests," said Mason McKibben, the park maintainer in Talcott Mountain State Park. "The overall view is pretty spectacular."

Medieval and Scenic
Crowds are not as much of a problem in Norfolk's Haystack Mountain State Park, where budget cuts this year have forced the gates closed for the season. Parking is still allowed at the entrance, a half mile north of the junction of Routes 44 and 272, however, and hiking the yellow-blazed trail through thick hemlock, birch and mountain laurel groves to the 1,677-foot summit is a fitting way to reach the payoff: the Battell Stoeckel Tower, a National Register property built in 1929.
Medieval in design, this rough-hewn granite cylinder with a conical top had thrown its doors open to hikers until a lightning storm in summer 2000 torched the wood stairs near the top. (It's scheduled to be repaired this summer.) Yet even from the wide stone steps that lead up to the tower's gate, there is a stunning panorama, presenting Norfolk's town green like a postcard far below.
"Park developers in general wanted to give you a sense of the power of nature, so you could feel elevated above your day-to-day concerns," said Peter C. Baldwin, an assistant professor of history at the University of Connecticut. "After World War II, this changed, and there became a lot less emphasis on the appearance of a park and more on its function, emphasizing its ball fields and swimming pools."
The tower, and Haystack Mountain, were gifts of Ellen Battell Stoeckel, an accomplished pianist who was also something of a patron saint to the town, donating much of her family's property. Upon Stoeckel's death in 1939, Yale University also inherited her estate down the road for use in summer music festivals.
Similar donations in the forms of pavilions and towers can be found nearby at Dennis Hill State Park, about two miles south of the Norfolk Green on Route 272, and at Mount Tom State Park, off Route 202 on the Litchfield/Washington town line.

Reclaiming Nature
Sometimes making sure an area's highest points stayed open to the public required more direct action by the public. Sleeping Giant State Park, on Mt. Carmel Avenue in Hamden just east of Route 10, which owes its existence to local citizens who banded together in 1924 intent on reclaiming the land from private owners.
The association gradually bought 20 parcels of land that included everything from primitive cabins to two-story summer cottages, perched along the humped basalt ridges. The association also managed to shut down a quarrying operation on the giant's "head."
Still, the view was the thing, and there needed to be some way to take it all in. But rather than just take over an existing cottage, the Works Progress Administration -- under the direction of Bancel LaFarge, an architect and Hamden resident, and Harry Webb, an engineer -- tore down Davis Wiser's house, and from its stones, built a four-story, turreted fieldstone castle, completed in 1939.

Minding the Forests
By the early 1900's, trees had been erased from a lot of the Connecticut landscape, chopped down for fuel and to open up farmland or destroyed in forest fires.
From these conditions was born the state forestry movement, its mission to encourage the preservation of forests as well as sustainable incomes from them. Connecticut, also home to the new Yale School of Forestry, was the first state in New England to purchase property for this purpose, buying part of what is today known as Portland's Meshomasic State Forest in 1903. By 1913, the Connecticut State Park Commission formed, but it wasn't until the boom years of the 1920's that the state finally had enough money to aggressively start acquiring green spaces. By then, another factor was taking its toll: pollution. Citizens of overcrowded factory towns like Waterbury and Hartford -- many of them now owners of cars -- were seeking clean country air. 
At the same time, the state also realized it had to start better monitoring fires, and the easiest way to do this was to buy mountains and build towers on top of them. In 1929, this thinking led to the purchase of Soapstone Mountain, a windswept, 1,075-foot peak jutting up from the state's tobacco valleys that was also the first piece of Stafford Springs' Shenipsit State Forest, two and a quarter miles south of Route 190 on Gulf Road in Stafford Springs.
Toward the end of the century, as the state grew many of its trees back, it also became obvious that it was easier to patrol for fires by plane. 
In 1976, Soapstone's original fire tower, by then the only one left in the state, was removed and ended up in the Sessions Woods Wildlife Management Area in Burlington, where it now serves as a blind for studying deer and beavers. 
Its replacement, a 45-foot lifeguard-stand-like wood deck, is the only state-owned public observation tower in the eastern part of the state and allows a straight-ahead sighting of New Hampshire's flat-topped Mount Monadnock. Giant antennas, however, obscure the southern view. 
Though Shenipsit's summit is accessible by car, it can also be reached by extensive hiking, biking and snowmobile trails that crisscross its 6,126 acres.
All are the work of the Civilian Conservation Corps. Though the majority of Connecticut's wilderness lands were purchased in the 1920's, most landscaping took place during the Depression.
Connecticut's 21-camp conservation corps program, established to take unemployed men out of the city and give them low-cost projects to work on in rural areas, was responsible for building most of the roadways, picnic areas, and pond dams that grace the state's parks and forests today.
"Their contribution was immeasurable because we would have never had the money to build the road and recreation areas otherwise," said the Shenipsit forest supervisor, Marilyn Aarrestad.
"It also got the general public thinking about outdoor etiquette and open space and how important it all is."

Self-Monuments of Sorts
In addition to civic-minded governments, there were also civic-minded industrialists who put public needs first and foremost. Meriden's Walter Hubbard, owner of the metals manufacturer Bradley and Hubbard Manufacturing Company, built his Hubbard Park in 1900, --today one of the largest municipal parks in all of New England -- though for a long time state owned -- and crowning it with Castle Craig on top of East Peak in the city's Hanging Hills.
Familiar to passing drivers from its location high above I-691, Castle Craig's 32-foot brown turret is something of an architectural mishmash. It's named for Craigellachie, Scotland, but supposedly built to resemble either a Turkish or French battlement. It comes off looking like an oversized chess rook. Though hikers can climb to it, the castle is perhaps viewed best in its historical context, from the old carriage road that that begins inside the park entrance on West Main Street, one that arcs up past a reservoir to the top of the trap-rock ridge.
"I think the open-space movement here was a huge success, because they ended up creating very large blocks of property that support a number of things that are important to us," Mr. Reynolds said. "If you look at development pressure in the state today, these may continue to be the only large blocks of open space we have left."

Carmel Avenue in Hamden, was initially privately owned land. It was built as a four-story, turreted fieldstone castle and completed in 1939. HEADLINE: Going Uptown Down the Shore 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT STRAUSS

DATELINE: OCEAN GROVE 

 BODY:
GWEN PASTORELLI was thrilled to sell Cynthia Hartwig on this once-sleepy village in the shadow of Asbury Park that was better known as a staid Methodist retreat. It wasn't scripture, however, that lured Ms. Hartwig, who had been a cook at one of Philadelphia's premier seafood restaurants, to this shore community. It was the smell of success.
 "I really felt like I needed to invest here," said Ms. Pasterelli, who had her eyes on the Raspberry Cafe, a shuttered little restaurant on Main Avenue. "Everything is just going so well. And she had the expertise." 
 So Ms. Pasterelli and Ms. Hartwig opened the 30-seat cafe two weeks ago, betting that Ocean Grove would have a bang-up summer, with vacationers lined up out the door in search of such delicacies as miso-crusted salmon with baby spinach, pumpkin risotto and cumin-braised Atlantic cod. 
 Ocean Grove, not long ago a repository of reasonably priced rental homes swelled by a summer influx of fastidious and teetotalling families, is still a dry town. Yet like virtually all of the 127 miles of New Jersey's coastline, upscale is the operative word. "You would be hard-pressed to find a decent house for under $500,000 here any more," said the entrepreneurial Ms. Pastorelli, who also sells real estate for the Mary Holder Agency."
It is in this environment this that merchants and motel operators who stand to make money during the summer vacation season are practically salivating. A snowy, frigid winter, followed by a reluctant spring with the rainiest May in 40 years -- tangled up with a war in Iraq and heightened terrorism alerts that left airplanes half empty -- have kept people close to home for months. Now the conventional betting is people are prepared, even eager, to spend a small fortune during a week or two at the New Jersey shore. 
 Real-estate agents say that the rental market, slow to get off the ground this because of the harsh winter and window shopping on the internet, is picking up. Generally, rental prices have risen only slightly in a bow to the balky economy, but nothing like the huge leaps of the last several years. On the other hand, housing prices, which have more than doubled since 1998, continue to surge. 
 Put that all together, and retail businesses and restaurants are gearing for what they believe will be a lucrative season. That's the case in Atlantic City, where snow-encrusted highways and the uncertainties of war crimped profits -- $1.3 billion at the casinos in the first four months of 2003, off 4.7 percent from the same period in 2002. Still, many of them have added rooms, bars on the beach and flashier entertainment, if only to try to compete against the much-ballyhooed $1.1 billion Borgata Hotel, Casino and Spa, the first new casino-hotel to open there in 13 years.
 "I think growth is there for a long time to come," said Milton Leontiades, dean of the business school at Rutgers- Camden and a longtime shore watcher. "With the Borgata coming and more retail and hotel towers going up, Atlantic City is getting better. That also has a spillover effect into other towns, like Brigantine to the north, because people have jobs and need homes and executives can afford higher prices on the beach."
 In these otherwise tenuous economic times, said Joseph Seneca, vice president for academic affairs at Rutgers and chairman of the New Jersey Council of Economic Advisors, consistently good business at the Shore in recent years has helped keep New Jersey, Wall Street's bedroom community, healthier economically than it could have been.
 "The attractiveness of vacationing close by has spurred the real estate sector at the Shore tremendously," said Mr. Seneca. "That has caused a trade-up in house prices all over the state. Most people are enjoying appreciation in their homes. Tourism is a big part of the state's economy, and as it has been doing well, New Jersey is faring better than in the national economy. Despite the pain we are feeling in state government, the general economy, boosted by tourism and the pharmaceutical industry, is doing well here."

Signs of a Successful Season
 Another indication that this summer may be a successful one is an increase in early beach-tag sales. For instance, Sharon Day of the Belmar Tourism Development Commission said that sales of season-long beach tags, discounted from $50 to $40 before May 14 in Belmar, rose to 1,100 this year as against 500 in 2002, boding well for beating last year's overall record of $2.1 million in sales. Of course, it is a long way to $2.1 million, and perhaps more people simply wanted to save the $10. 
 "We've started advertising in Pennsylvania, New York and Connecticut and we are seeing results," Ms. Day said. 
 Not to be outdone by the newfound prosperity of nearby Ocean Grove and the real estate speculation that is driving up prices in Asbury Park, Ms. Day said a former arcade and a row of somewhat shabby stores was being razed along the ocean between 12th and 15th Avenues in Belmar and would be replaced with large single-family homes.
 "All of these things has meant a big run-up in housing prices at the Shore, particularly when you consider there isn't much building with the restrictions we already have in place," Mr. Seneca said.
 Statistics bear Mr. Seneca out, particularly in such upscale towns as Stone Harbor and Avalon on what is known as Seven-Mile island in Cape May County.
 Ron Saldano, an agent at Otten Real Estate in Stone Harbor and Avalon, the two priciest towns south of Atlantic City, has done an analysis of sales there in recent years.
 In 1998, Mr. Saldano found, the median home sale in Stone Harbor was $411,700, only slightly higher than the $405,000 the year before. By 2001, the median sale price of the 55 single-family homes sold in Stone Harbor was $950,000, more than double what it was just three years earlier. 
 And while the rate of appreciation may have slowed a bit, it has not stopped. The median home sale through June in Stone Harbor was $995,000. Avalon, its neighbor to the north, saw its highest-price sale ever in April: $5.7 million for a beachfront house near 52nd Street in the middle of the island.
 "And it was sold unfurnished," said Mr. Soldano in mock surprise. "With the demographics, I don't see how this will stop any time soon."
 Mr. Soldano and others attribute the real estate run-up,-- despite the devaluation of the stock market, to several factors. First, said Mr. Soldano, there is a tremendous amount of inherited wealth coming into the market. 
 He said that as people from the Depression and World War II generation died off, they were leaving their money to their children, many of whom are nearing the end of paying college tuition for the own children. What better investment with those inheritances than second homes, particularly with stagnation in the stock market and money-market interest rates at a 40-year low.
 "Where else are you going to put your money?" said Gail Cook, the owner of Real Estate in Harvey Cedars, a well-heeled section of Long Beach Island. "There is a mix, too. There are the conservative older folks who always had investments in real estate. There are people whose stock portfolios lost money and realize they have to diversify. And we have younger people who have recently made a lot of money. Plus, it's fun to have a beach house instead of, say, an office building as an investment."
 In addition, the past several years have seen New Yorkers looking toward New Jersey rather than their traditional vacation spots on the eastern end of Long Island, where prices truly are astronomical. Now, said Mr. Soldano, New Yorkers are venturing farther south than Atlantic City. 
 "I had a family from Massachusetts buy a summer house here," he said, echoing Ms. Cook's observation that people were coming from as far away as Ohio, Florida and even Arizona to look for property on the New Jersey shore this year. Two years ago, she said, a family from California built a 6,000-square-foot house on the beach in Loveladies, another expensive town on Long Beach Island.
 "People who grew up at the Jersey Shore as baby-boomers remember it fondly, so they are now coming back, wherever they might live, especially if it's a day's drive like Washington or Baltimore or even Massachusetts," said Mr. Soldano. "Plus, those near New York have found that however high we may think it has gotten, it is still cheaper and less aggravation than Long Island."

More Year-Round Residents
 More and more, in fact, people who have spent their vacations at the Jersey Shore are staying there year-round. In Manasquan, for instance, the population rose by nearly 20 percent, to 6,310 from 5,369, between 1990 and 2000. Nor is it alone in witnessing that phenomenon; during the same 10-year period, according to 2000 Census figures, the population in Seaside Heights rose 33 percent, from to 3,155 from 2,136; Ventnor went up 17 percent, to 12,910 from 11,005; Brigantine 11 percent, to 12,594 from 11,354; Wildwood 21 percent, to 5,436 from 4,484; and Avalon, up 18 percent, to 2,143 from 1,809.
 One of those new year-round residents in Avalon is Dave Coskey, president of Comcast-Spectacor marketing, which controls the the Philadelphia 76ers and the Flyers, who drives about 70 minutes each way to work so he can have his beach paradise when he comes home.
 "We lived in Gloucester Township, about 40 miles more toward Philadelphia, and had a summer house down here," said Mr. Coskey. "By the time our oldest was in fourth grade, we noticed that our weekends were becoming longer. We never wanted to leave, so we would stretch it to Monday morning and maybe come down on Thursday night. Finally, it was a gorgeous day at the beach. My wife had just transferred to sales, so she didn't have to go into the office every day. So we just decided to go for it."
 His wife, Monica, who used to make the 100-mile trip to New York from Avalon three times a week, finally quit her job this year and bought the Ocean Deli, on 33rd Street and Ocean Drive, about eight blocks from the Coskey home.
 "Now, we're really a Shore household," said Mr. Coskey. "It's just another measure of how much things have changed here."
 For some businesses at the Shore, wealthier yearround residents present a mixed blessing. Larry Hanker, who has owned Neptune's Jewels as well as The Store for Pappagallo, a women's clothing boutique, on the main shopping drag in Stone Harbor since 1981, felt compelled to redesign his stores' interiors, making the lighting more subtle and putting in maple cabinetry and trim.
 "When you find you have an average home price of $1 million, you find you have a different kind of clientele and you need to do things differently," Mr. Hanker said. 
 He said that when he first opened hisshops 96th Street, the main shopping strip, was "wall-to-wall people" every night of the summer. But these days, Mr. Hanker added, bigger and more expensive houses have translated into fewer renters and less foot traffic.
 "It absolutely worries me," he said. "There is more money here, but since they are here all summer, they don't shop as much. It is vacationers, the week-ong people, who drive summer business. Still, you have to go with what you have, so we hope our renovations bring in that clientele."
 Further north, where there are even more yearround residents, merchants have similarly adapted to a changing marketplace. Tom Rechlin, whose Ocean Grove Flower and Gift Shop on Main Avenue, not far from the Raspberry cafe, has been open for 35 years, said the summer was no longer his busiest season.
 "Ten years ago, maybe, this was a summertime scene," Mr. Rechlin said, "but now we have more year-round residents and December, with Christmas flowers and all, is our busiest month. May is our second busiest, with garden supplies and that line."
 "Don't get me wrong," he added. "I love the summer business and we all want a good summer. I have a line of T-shirts and those things for the summer visitors. But any business owner here who now caters to just summer business is missing the boat."

Rebuilding Asbury Park
 In Asbury Park, where demolition of abandoned buildings is going apace in an effort to revive this burned-out beach town, the potential for attracting year-round residents has the allure of gold at the end of the rainbow. In fact, the former owners of the Raspberry Cafe in Ocean Grove, crossed Wesley Lake last year to open a restaurant called Moonstruck in a four-story Victorian building in Asbury Park.
 "Originally we moved because we wanted more space and have a liquor license and still be near Ocean Grove," said Luke Magliaro, one of the owners. "But now with Asbury poised to come back, it is a really good move. 
 Mr. Magliaro said he anticipated a strong summer, though "to tell you the truth, the winter was unbelievable; we were booked every Saturday night and did well even in February."
 Ultimately, the reason that businesses in most Shore will thrive is simple: that huge body of water just to the east.
 "There is never going to be enough supply of anything at the Shore that will outstrip demand," said Joel Naroff, the chief economist at Cherry Hill-based Commerce Bancorp. "Even if there is a downturn, there seems always to be a floor to the downturn. And now that the Shore is being looked at as not only a rental or a secondary location, but a primary one, the supply is even less.
 "I tell you this, and I am surely not alone," he added. "If my wife didn't have a great teaching job and we could live wherever we wanted, you had better bet we would be looking at the Jersey Shore. It is a wonderful place to be."

HEADLINE: RESTAURANTS; 
White Glove

BYLINE:  By DAVID CORCORAN

DATELINE: PIERMONT, N.Y. 

 BODY:
A GIANT steel flywheel sits in the park by the Hudson River in this Rockland County village, a few miles north of the state line. It is sculpture now, a rusted monument to Piermont's industrial past. If you turn your back to it, you can see the rambling clapboard building where Xaviar's occupies part of the ground floor.
 Peter Xavier Kelly, the 43-year-old founder, namesake, chef and guiding spirit of the restaurant, grew up in Yonkers, a gull's flight across the river. When he was a boy, that flywheel was still churning out electricity for Piermont's two paper factories, whose workers would finish their shifts and head for the taverns that lined Piermont Avenue. Today the paper mills are long gone, replaced by waterfront condominiums, and the taverns have been replaced by restaurants and galleries. Still, if you squint, Piermont Avenue looks much as it did then. 
 Yet when you enter Xaviar's, you are in some Parisian jewel box, a tiny room with a dozen tables laid with Versace china and Baccarat figurines, walls and ceiling hung with paintings and crystal chandeliers, and staff and patrons dressed accordingly. When the condos were going up across the street, the developer described them as "white glove"; well, this is a white-glove restaurant. 
 As such, it is not for everybody. The menu is prix fixe, $60 for four courses. At 16, Xaviar's is the oldest restaurant in a small Kelly empire. The others -- the Freelance Cafe, next door (enthusiastically reviewed in this space in 2000), and Restaurant X in nearby Congers (ditto, 1998) -- have a casual, populist streak. By contrast, Xaviar's feels formal and a little stiff. 
 Still, it is hard to argue with its success, or its cooking. Mr. Kelly, who is self-taught, was heavily influenced by nouvelle cuisine pioneers like Paul Bocuse and Alain Chapel. The recipes are French with Asian and Mediterranean accents, the ingredients are seasonal and flawless, and the dishes are colorful and beautifully balanced. 
 In recent weeks, for example, Xaviar's has been serving a first course that could hardly be simpler: four stalks of poached asparagus in a creamy wine sauce loaded with morel mushrooms. The morels are fresh, from a local farm whose location Mr. Kelly will not discuss for fear of an invasion of enthusiasts. They are tender, free of grit and full of character. I don't think this dish will be on the menu very long; if you see it you need to grab it.
 Asparagus takes on a different personality in a spring salad, in which it is shaved to fine shards, blanched for 20 seconds, then combined with a black-truffle vinaigrette, tiny balls of avocado and shavings of fine aged Parmesan cheese. Thin, crackerlike grissini protrude like antennas; a dusting of Thai spices makes them full contributing members of the production.
 In another first-course salad, calamari are described as "pasta," and they are unlike any squid you are likely to encounter: thinly sliced, briefly poached and tossed with garlic, broccolini and red peppers. Oyster sauce, sake and espresso lend notes of brine, sweetness and smoke. It's a stunning combination. So is a spring salad of raw hamachi, or yellowtail tuna, with roasted red peppers, ramp leaves and potato crisps.
 A slab of mild foie gras, perfectly poached, comes with three garnishes: rhubarb-ginger chutney, orange-peel marmalade and a robin's-egg cup of Sauternes jelly. Skate wing is handsomely browned, its nutty flavor set off by aged balsamic vinegar and by a leek puree; little packets of Bibb lettuce enclose chunks of lobster, an irresistible touch. 
 Some early courses do not come off as well. Scallops with oxtail may be a nouvelle cuisine standby, but it is an odd combination because both main ingredients are soft. "First of the season" soft-shell crab is batter-fried to the point of greasiness. And lobster tail does not benefit from a draping of salty prosciutto.
 Among main courses, rack of lamb is simply classic: two large, superb chops, with more of that asparagus and a nifty round of garlic custard. Veal medallions are roasted with a flat sausage of chopped sweetbread; it adheres to the veal with a thin layer of caul fat that melts in the roasting -- a rich, deeply satisfying dish. 
 Pekin duck (the kind from Long Island, not Beijing) is wrapped around foie gras; it might be too high-toned and precious if Israeli couscous with North African spices didn't provide an impish counterpoint. I have no argument with two more standard dishes, Pacific ahi tuna in a wasabi crust and dry-aged New York sirloin with gingered shiitake mushrooms and truffled French fries.
 Desserts tend to depart from the high seriousness of the rest of the menu. Baked Alaska is an outsized Hostess Sno-Ball-like confection of chocolate, pistachio and raspberry ice creams under a layer of browned meringue. White Chocolate Dome, an igloo of white chocolate pudding in a dark-chocolate coating, is surrounded by a whimsical circle of dulce de leche sauce that looked so much like a giraffe's coat that it brought grins to everyone at our table.
 It seems preposterous to advise saving room for anything, but the waiter will bring a tray of excellent petits fours; one recent night they included mini-beignets in the tradition of Mr. Kelly's beloved New Orleans.
 He may love Louisiana, but his heart is in his hometown, and he is negotiating with the City of Yonkers to open another Xaviar's on its aged City Pier. This one would be big and brash, more of a Restaurant X than a Xaviar's. It sounds like a stretch, particularly in today's economy. But if anyone can pull it off, he can.

Xaviar's
506 Piermont Avenue, Piermont, N.Y.
(845)359-7007
www.xaviars.com

EXCELLENT

ATMOSPHERE -- Classic French: haute, intimate and formal. (Men must wear jackets.)
SERVICE -- Polished and correct.
SMOKING -- Not allowed.
WINE LIST -- An encyclopedia with 800 entries, including a fair selection in the $20's and $30's, with a few well-chosen offerings by the glass.
RECOMMENDED DISHES -- Asparagus with morels, shaved asparagus salad, calamari salad, foie gras, braised short ribs, skate wing, red snapper; Pekin duck with foie gras, veal medallions, Pacific ahi tuna, rack of lamb; walnut parfait, cheesecake, white-chocolate dome, baked Alaska, Grand Marnier souffle.
PRICE RANGE -- Lunch: $35 for three courses. Dinner: $60 for four courses, $80 for a 10-course tasting menu.
HOURS -- Closed Mondays and Tuesdays. Lunch: Fridays and Sundays, noon to 2 p.m. Dinner: Wednesdays, Thursdays and Fridays, 6 to 9:30 p.m.; Saturdays, two seatings, at 6 and 9 p.m.; Sundays, 5 to 8 p.m.
CREDIT CARDS -- Not accepted; cash or personal checks only.
RESERVATIONS -- Recommended.
WHEELCHAIR ACCESS -- Not accessible. Restaurant is three steps up from street level, and tables and the restroom entrance are a tight squeeze.

IF YOU GO -- Piermont is in southeastern Rockland County, three miles north of the New Jersey line. From the Palisades Interstate Parkway, take Exit 4 to northbound Route 9W and continue three miles to the exit for Piermont. Turn right on Ferdon Avenue, which becomes Piermont Avenue, the village's main street. The restaurant is on the left. It offers valet parking, almost a necessity on weekends.

HEADLINE: COMMUNITIES; 
It Takes a Special Dog For a Needy Elder

BYLINE:  By BARBARA STEWART

DATELINE: MORRISTOWN 

 BODY:
LLOYD BURLINGAME'S first guide dog at Seeing Eye here in Morristown was a German shepherd that was spunky, smart and handsome - or so people told him. Mr. Burlingame, who was 63 at the time and the chairman of the graduate theater design department at New York University, had to take their word for it. He had been left blind from a virulent form of macular degeneration.
 Within days, he realized that the shepherd was, as he put it, miscast. Like a callow youth in a rush, the dog was impatient with the measured pace of the older man. 
 "That dog was more than I needed," Mr. Burlingame said. At intersections, he said, the shepherd would charge ahead, pulling Mr. Burlingame behind him. "I told them: 'You've given me a 12-cylinder Ferrari. I need a 6-cylinder Volvo,"' he said. 
 So they gave him Hickory, a yellow Labrador retriever. As soon as Mr. Burlingame picked up Hickory's work halter, his life, which had gone from constricting to imprisoning, burst open again. 
 "I felt: 'Where has this been all my life?"' he said. "'This is magnificent."" 
 Now, five years later, he grasps for superlatives to describe Hickory and their relationship. Before Hickory, he said, he would start the day by groping his way from his Greenwich Village apartment to the university, a few blocks away. When his sight worsened, he tried a white cane. Twice he was struck by bicycles. Once a malicious stranger directed into moving traffic, telling him that the coast was clear. (A passer-by grabbed him as he stepped off the curb.)
 That was when he realized that he wanted a guide with a brain, who loved him. 
 Now, he said, he and Hickory go out at night and take two-mile walks every day. Regulars on the route see Hickory so often that they call him the mayor of Washington Square.
 Stories like Mr. Burlingame's - of happy matches between older blind people and gentle-tempered guide dogs - are increasingly common at Seeing Eye and other guide-dog schools through the country. Twenty years ago, most blind people seeking guide dogs were well under 50, said Douglas S. Roberts, program director at Seeing Eye. But half the 275 people who received a Seeing Eye dog last year were 50 or older. One-third of them were getting their first dog, while the others were seeking a replacement for a dog that was retiring. 
 Older people need quieter dogs that require less vigorous exercise, he said. Ten years ago, when Seeing Eye looked at population projections and saw a bulge coming, it began to breed dogs to fill the need. (It is also breeding its dogs to be a bit smaller, to fit comfortably into cramped spaces in economy cars and under airplane seats.)
 A younger person whose life is a brisk round of classes, jobs, friends and workouts needs a guide dog with unflagging energy to keep pace. But the older people are, the more likely they are to take their time. That means their guide dogs must also be content with life in the slow lane. 
 A growing older population is resulting in more people with vision deterioration, especially macular degeneration, the most common cause of blindness in the elderly. In addition, the number of younger people who are blind has dropped sharply over the last 25 years, with the elimination of several major causes of blindness in the young. Soldiers have not been involved in sustained combat, as they were in Vietnam when many were blinded. In the 1980's laws requiring motorcycle riders to wear helmets cut down on the high rates of head injuries that were often accompanied by blindness. And the treatment of premature babies was changed, reducing the incidence of detached retinas that left many sightless.
 Seeing Eye has long used golden and Labrador retrievers and German shepherds, which were the first guide dogs in the 1920's. In attempts to breed gentler dogs, it is using labs and goldens, and sometimes also producing golden-lab crossbreeds. 
 But dog-breeding is an imprecise science, especially when characteristics like gentleness and patience are so subjective.
 "You can breed two gentle dogs," Mr. Roberts said. "But you don't know if the puppy will be gentle, too."
 It is far simpler to breed lively dogs, he said. Furthermore, the danger in breeding gentle dogs is that they will be timid. 
 "We have plenty of young fireball dogs, no problem," he said. "But it's much harder to develop a dog that is gentle-natured and is not going to pull somebody over or pull a back muscle - but that will still be courageous. If it's too gentle, it won't have the courage to guide a blind person." 
 Dr. Eldin Leighton, a geneticist at Seeing Eye, says that dogs are generally bred for the quality of the hip joints and "trainability," which he defines as a love of humans and of work, a strong sense of responsibility and an ability to puzzle through problems. 
 Until the late 70's, when it built its own breeding facilities, Seeing Eye bought dogs from outside breeders. Now it breeds most of its own, though a few are periodically brought in from the outside to prevent in-breeding. 
 At Seeing Eye, the dogs have been "molded" to weaken their natural herding and fetching instincts, Dr Leighton said. What remains is a capacity for love and duty. 
 "They have an even stronger desire to be with humans ," he said. "And they want to work. Once they're trained as guides, that's their joy in life. They have a job to do now, and they're just delighted to do it everyday."
 The dogs do not just spring up as guides, of course, ready to valiantly lead their owners out of the train station or through the crush to Macy's sales racks. 
 At any time, Seeing Eye has 600 puppies, which are raised as pets by volunteers, in their homes - including many high-school students in and around Morristown. At 5 months, the puppies begin six months of extensive guide training. At Seeing Eye 70 percent will graduate, going on to guide blind people. The others, which are usually rejected for minor physical problems, may be adopted as pets or as working dogs for the deaf or disabled. The waiting list to adopt a Seeing Eye dog can be as long as four years. Finally, a guide dog spends a month with its new owner, who, with others from around the United States and Canada, stays at the school's residences to learn to command, trust and be led by the guide dog. 
 It is all the training that makes a skilled, unflappable guide dog out of a bundle of potential. 
 To succeed in a career as guides, dogs should fit a mold. Guide dogs are trained to disobey an owner's command in dangerous situations; they will refuse, for example, a command to step into the path of an oncoming car. Seeing Eye calls this intelligent disobedience, a difficult but essential concept for a guide dog to master. 
 But, Mr. Roberts said, dogs shouldn't be too smart. For instance, he said, border collies are so smart that they give more priority to their own interests than their owners. Rather than obey a command like "Stay!" they might be scheming to grab the hamburger out on the counter. 
 "We want dogs that are smart, consistent, steady, quiet," Mr. Roberts said. "We want them to take initiative, but we don't want them to be too independent. Like good employees."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Sweetheart, a crossbreed training on the streets of Morristown, above, and a puppy, left, were bred to be more gentle than guide dogs of the past. (Photographs by Nancy Wegard for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: SOAPBOX; 
Why Ban Offshore Services?

BYLINE:  By ARJUN SAXENA and DOUGLAS LAVIN; Arjun Saxena and Douglas Lavin are consultants at Inductis, a strategy consulting firm in New Providence.

 BODY:
THE state senate recently passed a bill to prohibit the state government from contracting with foreigners to perform services. Maryland, Missouri, Wisconsin and Connecticut are contemplating similar legislation. Long on sentiment but short on sense, such bills deprive states of a powerful tool for saving money and undermine their economies.
 The New Jersey bill materialized after a contractor hired by the state to manage a welfare and food-stamp program moved its customer-service operations to Bombay from Wisconsin to cut costs. The grandstanding began almost immediately. 
 "We shouldn't be sending taxpayer-funded jobs for state contracts to foreign countries when our citizens need work." said Senator Shirley Turner, a Mercer Democrat who introduced the bill. 
 Never mind that the jobs were not based in New Jersey in the first place. After a member of Congress, Representative Thomas M. Barrett of Wisconsin, asked the federal government to look into the situation, the health and human services secretary, Tommy G. Thompson, tactfully replied that although the practice of sending work offshore made him uneasy, it lay outside the jurisdiction of the federal government.
 But since when does buying from foreigners make America uneasy? Tell that to the Toyota assembly workers in Kentucky and the Honda employees in Ohio.
 Consider the private sector. GE Capital and American Express together are said to be saving more than $450 million a year by using offshore outsourcing of services. For the banking industry, reports say that outsourcing to India has resulted in $8 billion in savings over the last four years. With some 82,000 employees, and an annual budget of nearly $24 billion, New Jersey could achieve similar savings if it undertook even a modest offshore initiative. With the savings, the state could increase education and job training programs or, if it is really concerned about economic development, lower taxeson business.
 Innovative governments are catching on. The Greater London Authority awarded a $10 million contract to an offshore software company, Mastek, to develop the software and run the back-end of the radical new program in London that charges tolls for driving within the city during rush hours. Data show that buying services offshore saved the city $4 million to $5 million.
 Efforts to stop local government from buying abroad run afoul of numerous commitments made by the United States in such accords as the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, or GATT, and Nafta, the North American Free Trade Agreement. And they run counter to national policy. For more than a decade, the United States has been preaching liberalization of trade in services, adopting policy to force countries to allow American banks and insurance companies to operate abroad.
 That is because services is an American strength.
 Instead of trying to stop market forces by legislative fiat, New Jersey should take a cue from some of the companies that are based in the state. 
 The telecommunications companies Lucent, AT&T and IDT are investing to take advantage of a simple economic fact: services can be imported and exported over phone lines just as easily as goods can be shipped by boat.
 What's next? Will New Jersey outlaw purchases of computers and cars that are made offshore?
 Because most products are no longer pure goods or services anyway, enforcing the law could require some strenuous exercises in metaphysics. As much as 60 percent of the value in an average desktop computer is represented by software. That includes driver software produced in Taiwan, the soft component of memory chips designed by Korean technicians and Windows, some of which is produced by Microsoft offshore.
 What state governments need is not naive legislation, but cost-saving innovation. 
 The 50 states face budget shortfalls of $29 billion in the current fiscal year. Bills like New Jersey's certainly won't help close the gaps. In fact, such bills benefit no one: not poor people, workers, taxpayers or state economies that, like it or not, are deeply enmeshed in global trends in technology and trade. Choosing political grandstanding over sound economics does, however, ensure that states will pay above-market rates for services.

HEADLINE: Quietly Expanding Our Nuclear Budget 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "Cold War Long Over, Bush Administration Examines Steps to a Revamped Arsenal" (news article, May 29): 
 Although the nearly $50 million just approved by Congress for developing new or modified nuclear weapons and for reducing the time necessary to conduct a nuclear test to just 18 months appears "tiny by the standards of the $400 billion Pentagon" budget, a look at the bigger picture reveals a troubling trend. 
During the cold war, the Department of Energy and its predecessor agencies spent an average of $4.2 billion annually, in inflation-adjusted dollars, to develop, test and manufacture 70,000 nuclear weapons and to maintain the nuclear weapons production infrastructure. Today, even though no new weapons are being built or explosively tested, the fiscal 2004 defense budget requests $6.4 billion for the same basic activities (7 percent more than 2003 and 15 percent more than 2002).
The Bush administration may say it is reducing both the number and the role of nuclear weapons, but its budgets send the opposite message.

STEPHEN I. SCHWARTZ
Publisher, Bulletin of the
Atomic Scientists
Chicago, May 29, 2003

HEADLINE: BRIEFINGS: RELIGION; 
ARCHDIOCESE CUTS STAFF

BYLINE:  By Karen DeMasters

 BODY:
 In a rare move, the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Newark has laid off employees in an effort to close a $3.5 million deficit in its $40 million budget. 
Forty-four of its 250 employees, or about 18 percent, were let go. The archdiocese includes 235 parishes and 173 schools, as well as its administrative offices in Newark. A spokesman attributed the shortfall to the poor economy. He said a furlough was last considered in the 1970's but was not imposed then. Karen DeMasters

HEADLINE: MAY 25-31: ECONOMY; 
GOOD NEWS?

BYLINE:  By David Leonhardt

 BODY:
All the ingredients are in place for an economic rebound during the rest of 2003. Now investors and policy makers are scouring the economy for actual signs of an improvement. 
 Last week brought some early -- if still uncertain -- hints that good news might arrive in time to keep the Federal Reserve from deciding it must cut short-term interest rates again when it meets in late June. 
 Retail spending rose in late May, according to two surveys of chain stores released Wednesday. New claims for unemployment insurance fell slightly, the Labor Department said the next day. On Friday, a closely watched survey of corporate managers in the Midwest showed that they had ordered more goods in May than in April.
None of the improvements were large, and these indicators are among the economy's most volatile. But the recent increase in the stock market, the decline in oil prices and the tax cut signed by President Bush last week give economists reason to think the signs will become more clearly optimistic in the weeks ahead.
If they do not, the Fed is likely to cut rates for the 13th time since the start of 2001 in an effort to prevent a deepening of the nearly three-year-old economic slump.
 David Leonhardt

HEADLINE: HORSE RACING; 
Where No Gelding Has Gone Before

BYLINE:  By JOE DRAPE

 BODY:
The saga of Funny Cide is a fairy tale, beginning with his place in history as the first New York-bred horse to capture the Kentucky Derby and down to the charm of his small-time owners -- a cross of upstate high school buddies and devotees of horse racing's Brigadoon, Saratoga Springs. They have boarded a yellow school bus in Louisville and again in Baltimore to watch their modest purchase run off with the first two legs of the Triple Crown.
 Now Funny Cide is a victory from becoming the 12th horse to sweep the series and the first since Affirmed did so in 1978. His owners are just the mile-and-a-half distance of the Belmont Stakes, the Test of the Champion, from pocketing a $5 million bonus. 
 But one textbook fact slows the narrative and erodes some of the romance of this tale: Funny Cide is a gelding, or a castrated horse. 
It is not uncommon to find geldings in races at tracks across the nation: of the 72,825 individual thoroughbred starters in North America in 2002, 18,796 -- or 25.8 percent -- were geldings, according to Jockey Club officials, who say that estimate is on the low side because of incomplete reporting. They win, too, taking down more than $282 million in purse money last year, or 23.1 percent of the purses available in North America in 2002. 
It is also not unusual to find geldings in the pantheon of the sport's great and most beloved horses. Kelso was named Horse of the Year five years in a row from 1960 to 1964, Forego claimed that title three times in the 1970's and John Henry twice in the 1980's.
But a gelding has never challenged for a Triple Crown. In fact, from 1919 to 1956, geldings were prohibited from running in the Belmont Stakes, so owners intent on making a killing in the breeding shed did not have to worry about having a payday spoiled by an animal who could not procreate. 
To this day, Funny Cide's lack of genitals would keep him out of the classic 3-year-old races in Europe like the English, Irish and French Derbies.
"It's harder to cut horses because of their economic value," said John Ward, who trained the 2001 Derby winner, Monarchos, and whose uncle, Sherrill Ward, trained Forego to two of the gelding's three championships. "You really can't cut a horse with a nice sire until they are past their star power."
In many instances it becomes a case of pay-me-now-or-pay-me-a-lot-more-later. Three years ago, Fusaichi Pegasus caught the nation's fancy with an emphatic victory in the Kentucky Derby, but raced only three more times before being retired to the life of a stallion. As a racehorse he earned nearly $2 million. As a stallion prospect, however, the son of the late Mr. Prospector was sold for $60 million to Ashford Stud, where he earns $125,000 a session to breed with up to 100 mares a season.
Funny Cide, on the other hand, was woefully lacking in pedigree; he was the product of an unproven sire named Distorted Humor and a mare named Belle's Good Cide who died in March from colic and who earned only $26,469 in a 26-race career that included only two victories. Besides, Funny Cide had another problem -- he was a ridgling, or a horse with one undescended testicle.
"Sometimes this causes discomfort during training," explained Dr. Larry R. Bramlage, an on-call veterinarian for the American Association of Equine Practitioners. "The castration of a horse, once it is decided that it will not be a stallion, makes them much more tractable in training and a much more effective athlete. Many of the famous geldings of the past were totally ineffective racehorses as intact males and became stars once gelded."
Funny Cide was already gelded when the trainer Barclay Tagg purchased him last spring as a 2-year-old for $75,000 on behalf of the Sackatoga Stable partnership. He had been following the progress of the youngster on a training farm in Florida for months and was captivated by his long, lean build.
"When you castrate horses, they don't quite get that heavy growth up front," Tagg said. "The front end is usually 65 percent of their weight and then you put a jockey on and there's a lot of pounding on their front legs. Castrating a horse tends to distribute the weight a little bit more. I think it helps with soundness. I've found that geldings tend to stay sounder longer."
But gelding also affects the disposition of a horse, especially 3-year-old colts, who are akin to teenage boys raging with hormones and discovering girls for the first time.
"Colts naturally become more aggressive, and especially between races they become hard to handle," said Ward, who kept the massive Forego on his family farm for part of the gelding's retirement. 
"They can do more harm to themselves as far as striking and challenging the people around them, as well as other horses," he said. "They are more interested in being macho with the horse next to them, instead of getting down to business and running by them. Geldings are way more mellow."
Deprived of a love life, geldings become more dedicated to the craft of running and often gallop their way into the hearts of racing fans. The indomitable Kelso started 63 times from 1959 to 1966 and won 39 times at distances from six furlongs to two miles in mud, dirt and on grass.
"You look at the pictures of Kelso in the stretch, and in every one of them his ears are pinned back because he is determined not to let another horse get in front of him," said Kelso's trainer, Carl Hanford, 87. "He would be kind and placid in the barn, but run his legs off on the track."
After finishing fourth to Secretariat in the 1973 Derby, Forego raced until he was 8, winning 34 of 57 starts and going off as the post-time favorite in 40 of his last 42 races. And John Henry, a champion on both dirt and turf, retired in 1984 after his 83rd start with 39 victories and more than $6.5 million in earnings, still a record for geldings. 
On Oct. 15, 1983, in one of the most memorable days in the history of Belmont Park, Kelso, then 26, and Forego, 13, showed up on the track to lead John Henry to the post for the 65th running of the Jockey Club Gold Cup. Some 32,000 people lined up 10 deep on the rail and cheered their approach.
"It is now post time -- for Kelso and Forego!" said the track announcer, Fred Capossela, the voice of New York racing for 31 years, who came out of retirement for the day.
 But alas, it was not John Henry's day. He finished fifth behind Slew o'Gold. Nor, as it turned out, was it Kelso's; he succumbed to colic the next day and died. In 1997, Forego was put down after breaking his long pastern bone.
Still, one of the great geldings survives: Now 28, John Henry is enjoying retirement at the Kentucky Horse Park in Lexington.
On Saturday, more than 100,000 people are expected to trek to Belmont Park in Long Island to watch another would-be great gelding perhaps make a little more history. Yes, a fairy tale ending would be nice, but an epic one would be even better.
