HEADLINE: Market Place; 
The American Exchange is being sold as NASD focuses on being a regulatory organization.

BYLINE:  By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
AS Henny Youngman might have said, "Take my exchange, please."
 For the second time in four years, the American Stock Exchange is being sold, this time to a private equity firm that has agreed to invest $110 million in what was once known as the Curb Exchange because it operated out of doors. 
 The seller is NASD, the regulatory organization that bought the Amex in 1999. NASD will not keep any of the money being spent on the exchange by the private equity firm making the investment, GTCR Golder Rauner. 
Instead, all of that money is to be invested in the Amex.
What NASD will get is, in a word, out. It will be exempted from the remaining financial obligations that it undertook when it agreed to buy the Amex.
It appears that NASD lost money on its ownership of the Amex, although no one was willing yesterday to say just how much.
When NASD announced plans to buy the Amex in 1998, it talked about creating a "market of markets," but few synergies developed.
NASD is also in the process of divesting its stake in the Nasdaq stock market, which is now partly owned by the public. When that is completed, it will be solely a regulatory organization. But it will not even keep the self-regulatory functions of the Amex, which will stay with the exchange when it is sold.
The buyer is not really parting with nearly as much money as might appear from the $110 million price. The money is to go back to the Amex, with part of it used to complete the investment obligations made when NASD took over the exchange. The Amex has about $50 million in cash, said one person who has seen the exchange's books, and that money will remain with the exchange.
At the time of its purchase, NASD pledged to invest $110 million in technology and to set up a $50 million seat-stabilization fund to protect the investment of Amex members, who must own or lease seats to have the right to trade on the exchange. There are 864 seats.
An NASD official said the fund owned 10 seats that it had bought from members who wanted to sell. Another person involved in the deal said the fund now had less than $30 million in it, which would be distributed to the seat holders.
They also are to end up owning slightly less than 10 percent of the exchange, according to one person briefed on the details of the deal, which were not disclosed.
Nonetheless, the seat holders have not done very well since the merger, although an Amex official pointed out that prices at other exchanges that specialize in options and other derivative securities had also fallen rapidly since the stock bubble burst.
At the end of the first quarter, the most recent period for which data is available, the last price for an Amex seat was $140,000, down from a peak of $725,000 in 2000.
The deal announced yesterday is subject to the approval of seat holders, as well as of the Securities and Exchange Commission.
The buyer of the exchange, GTCR, has made investments in several companies involved in the processing of securities transactions. Yesterday, Collin E. Roche, a principal of the firm, was offering few details on what it planned to do with the Amex, although he said the management team would stay in place. 
"Over the years, the American Stock Exchange has demonstrated tremendous innovation and ingenuity," Mr. Roche said in a statement. "In the dynamic securities industry, we believe that the Amex has strong opportunities to grow in its existing product classes while also introducing new products." In an interview, he declined to say what new products he had in mind.
Mr. Roche, who has been with GTCR since 1996, previously worked for Goldman Sachs and Everen Securities. 
The Amex long held the No. 2 position as a stock market in the United States, but it fell to No. 3 with the rise of Nasdaq. If all it traded was stocks, it probably would have gone out of business years ago.
But over time it has been far more entrepreneurial than its much larger competitor, the New York Stock Exchange. It was an early participant in the listed stock options market in the 1970's and continues to be a significant player in that arena, and it is the dominant market for exchange-traded funds, which it began trading a decade ago.
The Amex traces its history to the 19th century, when traders gathered in the streets of Lower Manhattan to buy and sell securities that were not listed on the New York Stock Exchange. But it was not until 1921 that the Curb Exchange, as it was then known, moved indoors.
When NASD bought the Amex, there was a lot of talk about synergies and about the ability of the two markets to offer companies a choice of trading systems. Like other stock exchanges, the Amex uses a specialist system, with each security having one firm that is required to make a market in the security. Nasdaq uses competitive market makers in a dealer system.
The management of Nasdaq at the time thought that many smaller companies listed on Nasdaq might be better off going to the Amex, where they could be sure of a dedicated market maker. At Nasdaq, some of those companies were having trouble attracting the attention of market makers.
But by the time the merger was completed, in 1999, the bubble was beginning to grow and virtually no companies wanted to leave Nasdaq, where a listing had acquired a certain cachet. Few, if any, companies made the move.
With no financial information on the Amex's profits or losses available, it is impossible to assess the price GTCR is paying.
But it clearly is getting the exchange from a motivated seller that wanted to get out, and to do so as quickly as possible.

HEADLINE: Administration Promotes Private Health Plans as Money Saver 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 2 

 BODY:
The Bush administration said today that greater use of private health plans to provide prescription drug benefits and medical services would save money for Medicare.
 Thomas A. Scully, administrator of the federal Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, said private plans would provide "better benefits and lower costs" than the traditional fee-for-service Medicare program. 
 Many economists disagree, and Mr. Scully himself said that the Congressional Budget Office disagreed. 
In an apparent pre-emptive strike, intended to answer the skeptics, Mr. Scully praised the value of private health plans as Congress reconvened today for a month of intense debate on Medicare, the federal health program for 40 million people who are elderly or disabled.
President Bush and many of his allies on Capitol Hill say they want to use drug benefits as an incentive to encourage older Americans to enroll in private health plans. People who stay with the traditional, government-run Medicare program would receive modest drug benefits, while those who join private plans would get much more extensive coverage. 
The Senate majority leader, Bill Frist, Republican of Tennessee, said, "The political environment is right, the legislative stars are aligned" for passage of legislation adding drug benefits to Medicare this year.
But Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic leader, mocked Republicans who argue that private health plans would be more efficient than the fee-for-service Medicare program.
Mr. Daschle said administrative costs accounted for 2 percent to 3 percent of spending in the traditional Medicare program, but could consume up to 15 percent of spending by private insurers.
About 88 percent of Medicare beneficiaries are in the fee-for-service program, which allows patients to go to any doctor or hospital. The Bush administration would encourage people to join networks of doctors and hospitals known as preferred provider organizations, or P.P.O.'s. Most people under 65 with private insurance are in such preferred provider plans. They typically pay more if they go to doctors or hospitals outside the network.
Medicare officials said that 66,000 Medicare beneficiaries had joined P.P.O.'s under a demonstration project begun this year.
Mr. Scully said competition among private health plans, as envisioned by the president, would save Medicare $22 billion over 10 years. Under current law, the program is expected to spend $3.8 trillion in those years.
The budget office "will say that P.P.O.'s cost 10 percent to 12 percent more" than the fee-for-service Medicare program, Mr. Scully said. He asserted that the analysis by the budget office was "fundamentally flawed," but such estimates are normally binding on members of Congress. The budget office refused to comment on Mr. Scully's remarks, saying its estimates were preliminary and confidential.
New evidence compiled by several economists shows that private health plans pay doctors and hospitals more than Medicare pays. So, the economists say, the private plans would probably not save money for Medicare any time soon.
The Bush administration acknowledged that private plans had higher administrative costs than the fee-for-service Medicare program. But it said the private plans could do a better job of managing care, and could thus eliminate much wasteful or unnecessary spending.
Mr. Scully said the administration still believed that Medicare should provide less extensive drug coverage to people in the fee-for-service program than to those in private health plans.
If the drug benefits are equal, he said, 31 percent of Medicare beneficiaries will join private plans, and the remainder will stay in the traditional Medicare program. But if the private plans offer superior drug benefits, as Mr. Bush proposed, 51 percent of Medicare patients will join such plans, Mr. Scully said.
In recent years, many health maintenance organizations have pulled out of Medicare, saying the government did not pay enough to cover their costs. But Mr. Scully said he was "fairly confident" that private insurers would want to participate in the Medicare marketplace proposed by the president.
Among the insurers that have expressed interest, Mr. Scully said, are Aetna, Humana, Cigna, WellPoint Health Networks, the UnitedHealth Group and many Blue Cross and Blue Shield plans.
Under the president's proposal, Medicare would sign contracts with three P.P.O.'s in each of 10 regions.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TRAVEL; 
MEMO PAD

BYLINE:  By JOE SHARKEY 

 BODY:
Getting to Kabul Could Be All the Fun
Most of us think of a business trip as a hectic but usually pleasant visit to a thriving city, perhaps with a stay at a nice Hyatt Regency, room service included. 
 But there are other kinds of business travelers, among them the legions of workers whose business takes them to war-torn spots that are not only dangerous but difficult to reach. 
 Take Afghanistan, where infrastructure rebuilding means a steady flow -- much of it from Washington -- of United States government workers, as well as employees of the World Bank, the United Nations and other multinational organizations. 
"There're a couple of hundred people a week traveling between the U.S. and Kabul," said Kevin Mitchell, chairman of the Business Travel Coalition, a business-travel advocacy group. The journey is usually a study in travel misery, taking up to 40 hours, along multistop routes where armed guards, not flight attendants, sometimes provide the basic necessities.
But starting in mid-July, a new Geneva-based air service, Swiss Skies, will offer twice-weekly regularly scheduled flights to Kabul, in partnership with World Airways, a United States carrier that has long had specialized transportation and air-lift contracts with the United States government.
The 18-hour Swiss Skies flights will be between Washington and Kabul, with a stopover in Geneva, where many multinational relief groups are based. Mr. Mitchell, who has been hired to help market the venture, said that the flights would operate on World Airways MD-11's, featuring business-class service. Fares will be slightly higher than typical current fares for a flight to Afghanistan, but will ensure a safer and far better flight, he said. JOE SHARKEY

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES; 
Dollar Rises on Factory Report And Comments by Bush on Policy

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The dollar rose modestly against the euro yesterday as manufacturing reports suggested that the United States economy was gaining momentum and President Bush was quoted as saying he wanted to stem the dollar's slide.
 A weaker dollar is "contrary to our policy," Mr. Bush said in an interview on Russian television that was made public over the weekend. The dollar's 25 percent slide against the euro in the last year has eroded demand for European exports, deepening the region's economic slump. 
 In New York trading yesterday, the euro settled at $1.1763, down from $1.1779 on Friday. It lost ground against the yen, selling at 118.54, down from 119.30 on Friday.
United States manufacturing improved in May, suggesting that the worst may be over for factories, according to a report from the Institute for Supply Management.
And Mr. Bush's remarks on the dollar led some to conclude that the administration wanted to slow the currency's slide on concern that it might deter foreign investors from buying United States bonds.
"The market, at this point in time, has devalued the dollar, which is contrary to our policy," Mr. Bush was quoted as saying in an interview in Washington last Thursday with the Russian television network RTR, which the White House released on Saturday.
"The policy of my administration," Mr. Bush said, "is for there to be a strong U.S. dollar."
And yesterday at the meeting of leaders of the Group of 8 industrial nations in Evian, France, "Bush affirmed very clearly that he wants a strong dollar," according to Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi of Italy.
Treasury Secretary John W. Snow rattled the currency markets two weeks ago with a comment that the decline in the dollar "really is a fairly modest realignmentof currencies," and thereafter its decline accelerated. Yesterday, though, a Treasury spokesman, Rob Nichols, said in Washington that Mr. Snow "has said he favors a strong dollar" and that he and the president are "clearly in lock step" on dollar policy.
A Japanese portfolio manager, Masahiro Nishida of the Kokusai Asset Management Company in Tokyo, said: "The U.S. appears to be trying to stop a decline in the dollar, as it has dropped quite sharply already. They probably don't want to see a further slide."

HEADLINE: Bringing China In From the Cold 

BYLINE:  By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF; E-mail: nicholas@nytimes.com

 BODY:
The loopiest aspect of the Group of 8 conclave in Evian is the notion that global leaders are confronting the challenges of the 21st century in the absence of the nation that may well dominate the century.
 That's right: China. 
 Even if China's gross domestic product is measured using its official, undervalued exchange rate, its economy is far bigger than those of G-8 members like Canada or Italy -- and almost three times the size of Russia's. If one values China's economy using another approach, purchasing power parity, then it is already easily the biggest economy outside the U.S.
As it happens, France invited China's new leader -- Hu Jintao -- to Evian, where he may have the highest I.Q. in town (he's an engineer with close to a photographic memory, along with a third-rate conscience). But Mr. Hu may be the second most important man in the world, and he deserves a place in a Group of 9. 
On short- and long-term issues that the G-8 grapples with -- from dealing with North Korea to preventing global warming -- the two key players in the world are China and the U.S. And it's ridiculous to include Russia in the G-8 but not China (which adds a Russia's worth of economic output to the world every two years).
Several objections can be raised to expanding the G-8 to include China:
It's a summit meeting for industrialized nations, and China isn't one. It's true that China has more peasants than any country in the world, but it also has more industrialists. Hey, it's China.
China exports more manufactured goods than Canada, Italy or Russia; it is launching a space program to put a man on the moon; its biotechnology is superb (thank goodness it wasn't during the Cultural Revolution, or we would have a billion Mao clones). And while the industrialization of China is still in its early stages, the world needs to wrestle with what that means: if the Chinese come to use as much energy per capita as Americans do, that will amount to more than the total amount of energy now produced worldwide.
China isn't a democracy but a thuggish Communist dictatorship. Yup. I was at Tiananmen Square when troops opened fire in 1989, and all that blood will never be washed from my memory. But today China is not Communist but fascist, in the sense of a nationalistic one-party dictatorship controlling a free-enterprise economy. In any case, the key question is not whether some of China's rulers are thugs but whether they are thugs we can work with. And they are.
China is an irresponsible power that can't be a team player. It's true that China's mishandling of SARS, for example, allowed the disease to spread worldwide. And it has often cheated on agreements and imprisoned dissidents. But China has steadily become more responsible over the years on issues ranging from trade to terror, and in the last few months it has shown real leadership on resolving the North Korean crisis.
President Bush has managed relations with China very well, mostly because Pentagon hawks who had been trying to turn Beijing into The Enemy were distracted by 9/11. There are real risks that we will become enemies -- there could be clashes between the U.S. and China over Taiwan, the Senkaku Islands, the South China Sea -- but they will be lessened if we give China opportunities for global leadership.
Some experts predict that SARS will be to China what Chernobyl was to the Soviet Union: the crack that eventually brings the entire facade tumbling down. I doubt it. Chinese reformers have long urged (behind closed Politburo doors) a freer press, but the party remains instinctively repressive. 
Last week, China sentenced Xu Wei, a journalist, to prison for 10 years just for talking about politics with friends; he said he had been beaten as well. Seok Jae Hyun, a South Korean photographer (who regularly takes pictures for The New York Times) got two years in prison for photographing North Koreans escaping through China.
No, Hu Jintao is no Gorbachev.
He's more like a Franco, a Pinochet, a Park. And, knock wood, the China he rules will follow Spain, Chile and South Korea in fostering the educated middle class that will lead it to democracy.
In the meantime, China is too important to leave out in the cold. As the leaders in Evian struggle over SARS, AIDS, Iran and North Korea, they need China within their ranks, as a member of the G-9.

HEADLINE: THE PRESIDENT'S TRIP: PEACE TALKS; 
Bush, in Egypt, Finds Warmth And Wariness

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER and JAMES DAO

DATELINE: SHARM EL SHEIK, Egypt, June 2 

 BODY:
President Bush arrived in the Mideast tonight for the first time in his presidency, preparing to face Arab leaders skeptical of American intentions in Iraq and to mediate between the Israelis and the Palestinians, a role he has long avoided.
 When Air Force One landed here tonight on the southern tip of the Sinai Peninsula, Mr. Bush was greeted with a hug by the Egyptian president, Hosni Mubarak. But the warm welcome masked undercurrents of wariness. 
 Mr. Bush will be meeting with Mr. Mubarak and Crown Prince Abdullah of Saudi Arabia, King Hamad of Bahrain and King Abdullah of Jordan amid deepening Arab fears that the American presence in Iraq will be lengthy and chaotic. The Arab leaders also worry that Mr. Bush will be insufficiently tough with Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel on the abandonment of Israeli settlements in the West Bank and Gaza, part of the phased peace plan Mr. Bush calls the road map. 
Mr. Bush's personal involvement in the peace effort represents a considerable political risk, but one he said today that he was willing to take. "My expectations in the Middle East are to call all the respective parties to their responsibility to achieve peace," Mr. Bush said this afternoon in Evian-les-Bains, France, during a brief lunch with the French president, Jacques Chirac, in which the Mideast was the main subject of discussion.
Answering critics who have raised doubts that he would risk much political capital on the peace effort, Mr. Bush said he would "make it very clear that my country, and I, will put in as much time as necessary to achieve the vision of two states living side by side in peace." A senior Bush adviser said that now -- after a successful war in Iraq and a year and a half away from the next presidential election -- was "the right moment" for Mr. Bush to make a move.
Mr. Bush himself seemed to try to dampen expectations, saying, "I fully understand this is going to be a difficult process."
But his secretary of state, Colin L. Powell, insisted tonight that this was the right moment to act. 
"The president turned his attention to this issue because he sees that there are these new dynamics in the equation," Mr. Powell said on ABC tonight. "And everybody knows we can't stay where we are. The Palestinian economy has been destroyed. The Israeli economy is in difficulty. Israel doesn't want to keep its troops deployed forever in the cities and towns. So I think all the pieces have come together, and we are here at Sharm el Sheik to take advantage of the new elements in the equation and this window of opportunity that has opened." 
Other American presidents, of course, thought they had a moment here as well -- as Mr. Bush was reminded tonight when his limousine sped past a giant mural of President Bill Clinton at the first peacemaking summit meetinghere in 1996. Mr. Clinton returned four years later but left office with little to show for his efforts.
It is a measure of the tension Mr. Bush confronts here that the Egyptians, while embracing the peace plan, did not want Mr. Sharon on their soil for the first meeting. As a result, Mr. Bush is to move on to Jordan on Wednesday to meet Mr. Sharon and the new Palestinian prime minister, Mahmoud Abbas.
Mr. Abbas will also attend the meeting on Tuesday. Administration officials have embraced him as an alternative to Yasir Arafat, the longtime Palestinian leader whom Mr. Bush has called untrustworthy and has refused to meet. But it is unclear what kind of authority Mr. Abbas has to cut a deal independently of Mr. Arafat, something Mr. Bush will be seeking to explore.
"He is going to be on the world stage as the prime minister of the Palestinian people, standing with the prime minister of Israel and with the president of the United States," Mr. Powell said today, referring to Mr. Abbas. Mr. Powell was speaking aboard his plane as he flew from Rome to join Mr. Bush.
Prior to arriving in this Red Sea resort -- part of the lands Israel seized in the 1967 war and returned to Egypt in 1982 -- Mr. Bush spent much of his day seeking support from European leaders for his Mideast plan. He received that from Mr. Chirac, a significant gesture considering that the French president was among those urging Mr. Bush last year to deal with Mr. Arafat.
A senior Bush administration official who briefed reporters after the meeting in Evian today said that Mr. Bush and Mr. Chirac had a lengthy discussion about Syria and Lebanon, and that Mr. Bush asked Mr. Chirac about the prospects of bringing them into the peace effort. Mr. Chirac was close to Hafez al-Assad, the late father of the current president, Bashar al-Assad.
"He had some interesting ideas about how to make certain that Syria does the right things," the senior official said, without offering specifics. Syria will not be present at the Arab meeting tomorrow, one indication of the sharp fault lines within the Arab world about the Bush plan.
At a news conference, Mr. Chirac said that the European Union's principal foreign policy official, Javier Solana, was considering preparing his own road map to end the hostility between Israel and the closely aligned Syria and Lebanon.
"If there is war between Israel and the Palestinians," Mr. Chirac said, "equally there is war between Israel and Syria and Lebanon." Hence, he said, it was "legitimate" to have a road map for ending that conflict.
He said the idea was "not a French initiative," and that an "eventual initiative" would be undertaken by Mr. Solana under the auspices of the European Union.
At the meeting on Tuesday, the Arab leaders are expected to embrace anew both the peace plan and its recognition of an Israeli state and a Palestinian state existing side by side. Mr. Powell said today that he would also press the Arabs to issue a strong statement against terrorism, an effort to marginalize Arab extremist groups, including Hamas. He met with a number of Arab foreign ministers this evening, hoping to pave the way for a political success for Mr. Bush on Tuesday.
Even as Mr. Abbas prepared to step into the role of a significant Arab leader, there were signs that Mr. Arafat would cast a shadow over the summit meeting even in absentia. Ahmed Maher, the Egyptian foreign minister, said it was "nonsense" for the United States to groom Mr. Abbas, also known as Abu Mazen, as a "rival" to Mr. Arafat. 
"Arafat is the elected legitimate leader of the Palestinian people, and Abu Mazen is the prime minister," Mr. Maher told reporters before a meeting with Mr. Powell this evening, Agence France-Presse reported. 
European leaders have also expressed an unwillingness to marginalize Mr. Arafat. The French foreign minister, Dominique de Villepin, met with Mr. Arafat last week in Ramallah -- a subject that Mr. Bush and Mr. Chirac apparently avoided during their lunch today. 
In Rome today, Franco Frattini, Italy's foreign minister, told Mr. Powell that the European Union would continue to deal with Mr. Arafat. Italy assumes the European Union's presidency on July 1. 
Mr. Powell was careful in his assessment of what the Israeli-Palestinian summit meeting could accomplish. He said he was encouraged by pre-summit negotiations but unwilling to speculate on whether the Israelis and Palestinians could issue meaningful statements -- as they are supposed to do as a first step toward peace -- before the meeting concludes. 
Mr. Bush will have to address several major sticking points in his meetings with Mr. Sharon and Mr. Abbas on Wednesday.
Principal among them is Israeli resistance to dismantling settlements in the West Bank and Gaza, and Palestinian insistence that refugees from the 1948 war for independence have a a "right of return" to what is now Israel.
Mr. Powell sidestepped a question today about which Israeli settlements should be frozen or dismantled, a subject of heated debate in Israel. Israel has settled more than 200,000 of its citizens in the West Bank and Gaza.
But Mr. Powell did say that settlement outposts built since Mr. Sharon took office in 2001 are "not there properly and will have to be removed," adding that they would have to be dealt with "at the very beginning of this process."
Mr. Powell also said he was heartened that Mr. Sharon recently used the word "occupation" for the first time in describing the presence of Israeli forces in Palestinian territory. 
"I think it shows that he recognizes that whichever interpretation you put on it, the occupation of particular cities or territory, it's a situation that is unsustainable over time," Mr. Powell said.

HEADLINE: THE PRESIDENT'S TRIP: CURRENCY; 
Bush Said to Affirm Commitment To a Stronger Dollar Overseas

BYLINE:  By JOHN TAGLIABUE

DATELINE: EVIAN-LES-BAINS, France, June 2 

 BODY:
President Bush gave renewed assurances today that the United States had not deserted its strong-dollar policy, prompting expectations that the dollar may soon gain against the euro. 
 The Group of 8 leaders, anxious to project an image of cooperation after the corrosive disagreements over Iraq, said they were confident of a global economic recovery, probably in the second half of this year. 
 But Mr. Bush and the other leaders -- from Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan and Russia -- made no significant progress in removing differences that would enable them to complete the latest round of trade talks, the so-called Doha round. 
In addition, they were not expected to give a clear signal on how to deal with currency fluctuations. In recent months, the dollar has dropped sharply in value against the euro, upsetting European governments because when it does so, it makes European exports more expensive and slows economic growth.
Italy's prime minister, Silvio Berlusconi, said Mr. Bush denied that the United States was allowing the dollar to fall and thereby make American exports cheaper in order to, in theory, stoke the sluggish American economy.
"Bush affirmed very clearly that he wants a strong dollar," Mr. Berlusconi told reporters. 
That and similar remarks were expected to propel the dollar higher in coming days. 
The dollar has fallen sharply over the past few weeks, most notably after a meeting of Group of 8 finance ministers in the French resort of Deauville last month, at which the United States treasury secretary, John Snow, appeared to redefine Washington's strong-dollar policy.
Mr. Berlusconi said Mr. Bush had also preached the value of a "virtuous deficit" to his Group of 8 counterparts. Italy has been one of several European countries seeking a loosening of strict rules on deficits agreed to by the 12 countries using the euro.
A Japanese official, briefing reporters, said it was his understanding that "they have currently not yet decided whether the exchange rate issue should be included in the final summary," which will be approved Tuesday when the remaining leaders end the meeting.
Mr. Bush and Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain left the meeting today.
The G-8 leaders discussed concerns of possible deflation in several countries, including Japan and Germany, but officials from those two countries questioned the risk of such a decline.

HEADLINE: THE PRESIDENT'S TRIP: GROUP OF 8; 
Summit Leaders Talk Tough On Spread of Nuclear Arms

BYLINE:  By JOHN TAGLIABUE and ELISABETH BUMILLER

DATELINE: EVIAN-LES-BAINS, France, June 2 

 BODY:
President Bush and leaders of the major industrialized countries today called nuclear proliferation "the pre-eminent threat to international security" and suggested that force could in some circumstances be used to meet the threat.
 At the conclusion of a meeting of the Group of 8 leading industrial democracies, the leaders urged North Korea and Iran to curb their nuclear programs, saying they would not "ignore the proliferation implications of Iran's nuclear program." Excerpts, Page A12. 
 The leaders said they had at their disposal a range of tools, like inspections and export controls, to deal with the threat of proliferation. In a clear reference to force, they added that they could employ, "if necessary, other means in accordance with international law." 
The United States has accused Iran of developing nuclear weapons under the cover of its civilian nuclear program, and there has been speculation that it could become the next target of the Bush administration. But today, according to Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi of Italy, Mr. Bush said he had no intention of attacking Iran.
"Bush made a clear statement that the idea of an armed operation by American forces in Iran is completely without foundation," Mr. Berlusconi said. He did not say whether Mr. Bush had addressed the use of force against North Korea. In the past, the White House has insisted that the North Korea issue will be resolved diplomatically.
The leaders called on North Korea "to visibly, verifiably and irreversibly dismantle any nuclear weapons programs." 
Mr. Bush left the summit meeting this afternoon, but not before telling his fellow leaders that he expected the American economy to achieve growth of 2.9 percent in the second half of this year, according to Alfred Tacke, a senior aide to Chancellor Gerhard Schroder of Germany.
The meeting provided the first opportunity for the deep trans-Atlantic rifts caused by the Iraq war to be addressed in person by the leaders involved. The summit leaders' statement avoided any reference to Iraq.
Mr. Bush and President Jacques Chirac of France had a cheerful photo session on a terrace overlooking Lake Geneva before a 25-minute private meeting, their first since the Iraq war divided them. "We can have disagreements," Mr. Bush said, "but it doesn't mean we have to be disagreeable to each other."
Mr. Bush, who had implicitly reprimanded the French as recently as the weekend for the divisions in the Atlantic alliance, seemed to go out of his way to flatter Mr. Chirac. He was particularly solicitous of his advice on the peace talks that the American president will hold with Israeli, Palestinian and other Arab leaders in Egypt and Jordan this week.
"I'm going to meet with Jacques here in a little bit and ask his advice on the Middle East," Mr. Bush said. "He's a man who knows a lot about the Middle East, he has got good judgment about the Middle East, and we will spend some time discussing that."
Mr. Chirac later said it was "possible and probable" that he would travel to the United States before the opening of the United Nations General Assembly in the fall, and that he would then meet Mr. Bush again.
Turning to the world economy, the leaders said the conditions were in place for a revival of economic growth. But they continued to differ on the best means to accelerate the process, with Mr. Bush stressing the value of his new $350 billion of federal tax cuts as an effective remedy, while leaders from Europe and Japan stressed the long-term changes to the structure of their economies now under way.
Mr. Tacke said Mr. Bush had "confirmed that a policy of a strong dollar remains." The president's recent remarks in support of a strong dollar have caused it to stem a months-long slide against the euro.
Mr. Chirac, at a news conference, cited the dissipation of uncertainties following the conclusion of the Iraq war, stable oil prices and low interest rates as among the grounds given by the leaders for their optimism.
Clearly, though, the focus of the meetings was on nuclear weapons proliferation, against the backdrop of the continuing efforts to thwart international terrorism. A senior Bush administration official said the tough language on Iran's and North Korea's nuclear programs was made possible by support from France, Germany and Russia, the nations that had been less than supportive on the war in Iraq. "What's key is that the only two countries named are North Korea and Iran and that the language is very strong," the official said, adding that it was the Russians who suggested that the communique declare that North Korean behavior was undermining agreements curbing nuclear arms. 
The statement on Iran, the official said, clears the way for the International Atomic Energy Agency to deal with Iran on June 16. "Iran's going to be on the griddle," the official said. "This statement confirms it."
Iran's president, Mohammed Khatami, responding to the growing world attention to his country's nuclear program, said today in Tehran that the Islamic republic had no plans to develop nuclear weapons. He noted that Iran was one of the first nations in the Middle East to propose that the region become a zone free of nuclear weapons. 
"All of Iran's nuclear activity is under the inspection of the International Atomic Energy Agency, and we have no intention of obtaining nuclear arms," Mr. Khatami said at a diplomatic reception. "Don't use this as a pretext to pressure and threaten Iran."
A senior administration official in Evian, asked whether Mr. Bush had told the leaders that the United States would not invade Iran, as Mr. Berlusconi said, replied: "I actually don't recall that conversation per se. Iran was talked about in the context of proliferation. He may have said, as I recall, something that that kind of speculation was not warranted."
Most of the G-8 leaders were set to meet one last time on Tuesday morning to summarize the results of their meetings, but with the departure of Mr. Bush, much of the wind had gone out of the meeting's sails. And the bulk of the work has been completed.
On the economy, the leaders discussed trade issues, including the latest the Doha round of trade negotiations, where they are seeking to narrow their differences before a crucial meeting in Mexico, in September. But a French official said that they had only "agreed to be in agreement," and that low-ranking officials would be delegated to resolve remaining differences.
The leaders also approved an action plan on health to help developing nations overcome shortages of essential medications. France had proposed a draft version that included measures like ensuring greater access to generic drugs in developing countries, improving access to branded drugs through differential pricing and stimulating local production and technology transfer. But most of these measures were expunged from the final version at the insistence of the United States, which saw them as a menace to intellectual property rights in pharmaceuticals.

Government Report Faults Detentions After Sept. 11

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR: THE IRAQI JOBLESS; 
U.S. Administrator Seeks to Restore a Broken Economy

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, June 2 

 BODY:
The top American civilian administrator in Iraq turned his attention to this country's shattered economy today, saying that joblessness "is a tremendous problem" but that he would not be "blackmailed" by thousands of former Iraqi soldiers who are protesting their new unemployment.
 "I want to start the process now of turning this economy around into an economy which can offer real jobs with real wages for the millions of citizens who need and deserve them," said the official, L. Paul Bremer III, who is overseeing the reconstruction of postwar Iraq. 
 About 3,000 dismissed Iraqi Army officers protested noisily today outside American civilian headquarters, which are inside a former palace of Saddam Hussein, and some demonstrators issued vague threats of suicide bombings if nobody helped them.
The protests came just two days after others by former workers at what had been the Ministry of Information, the agency that oversaw the vast propaganda and censorship machinery of the former president. 
No one knows exactly how high Iraq's unemployment rate is at the moment, but experts say it may be well above 30 percent and that it is likely to climb higher in the near future.
Baghdad has slowly begun to enjoy regular electricity. But normality has not returned to people's lives, and Iraqis are clamoring with growing insistence for work and money.
Mr. Bremer recently announced that the Iraqi Army and the former government's information ministries would be dissolved and that most employees would be dismissed with a single severance payment.
Those measures come in addition to a broad effort to purge the government of members of Mr. Hussein's Baath Party, and are almost certain to be followed by moves to eliminate thousands of make-work and no-show jobs that were common under Mr. Hussein.
In a wide-ranging news conference today, Mr. Bremer said the United States would spend up to $70 million for a temporary program aimed at collecting trash and rebuilding schools.
He also said the American government would recruit ex-soldiers, though not senior officers, for what he called a New Iraqi Corps that could become operational within the next few months.
But Mr. Bremer refused to soften his opposition to finding work for the tens of thousands of career military officers and other employees of the old Ministry of Defense. Asked whether he was concerned about threats voiced by some of the angry army officers, Mr. Bremer said, "We are not going to be blackmailed."
The more crucial question was whether Iraqi and foreign private investors would begin to fill the vacuum left by the collapsed government, which was by far the country's biggest employer before the war.
Many of Iraq's wealthy exiles, who built up hundreds of millions of dollars in assets outside the country during the past two decades, say that they and other foreign investors consider Iraq too unstable for large investment.
"They are all afraid, and I am concerned that the situation may be getting worse," said one prominent Iraqi business executive who fled the country nearly a decade ago and returned shortly after American forces seized Baghdad.
The initial reluctance arose from the widespread looting and lawlessness that has plagued Iraq since the former government collapsed.
But the latest fear stems from the accelerating pace of guerrilla attacks on American soldiers and the threat of a cycle of retaliation and fresh attacks. "I'm afraid this will lead to a cycle of violence, which will not be good for either Americans or Iraqis," the businessman said today, speaking on condition that he not be identified.
In placing heavy emphasis on Iraq's underlying economic problems, Mr. Bremer appeared to be signaling a new phase in the American-led reconstruction efforts.
He said that daily electricity production in Baghdad, which has been a huge problem ever since the war, had doubled in the past week and that Iraqi oil fields were now pumping about 700,000 barrels a day, still less than one-third of Iraq's prewar capacity but double the level of several weeks ago. Mr. Bremer also made it clear that plans to create a national assembly of Iraqi leaders have been put on hold and that he would maintain his authority at least until basic services and security are restored in the country.
But he acknowledged that Iraqis want to govern themselves as soon as possible.
"I found in my consultations that most Iraqis were anxious to move ahead quickly to establish the interim authority," he said. "We agreed."

HEADLINE: Turnarounds Are Drawing Prospectors To Japan 

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 3 

 BODY:
Proving that there is money to be made in Japan, Wilbur Ross, the American corporate turnaround artist, is selling a regional bank and a credit card company for $410 million, "which is two times what we paid for them in February 2001," he said in an interview here today.
 Under the deal, Bank of Kansai Ltd., owned by the Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group, is to pay 80 percent in cash and 20 percent in stock on July 1 to buy Kansai Sawayaka Bank Ltd. from Nippon Investment Partners, which Mr. Ross controls. 
 The announcement comes as hundreds of American employees of financial firms pack their bags to depart Japan this summer, leaving empty desks in classrooms at the American School in Japan and empty deck chairs by the pool at the Tokyo American Club.
"That's the bull market crowd leaving," said one American who was laid off by a European bank, but reinvented himself as an expert in distressed equities. "The crowd that is staying are much more focused on squeezing costs, filling buildings no one else can fill. It is a different skill set."
Poking around Tokyo's markets for value, foreign investors in May helped push the Nikkei average up 10.7 percent, the biggest monthly jump in 4 years, and a relief after the index hit a 20-year low in April.
"There are stocks listed in Tokyo that are trading at a price per share with no enterprise value ascribed to them by the price, with no value ascribed to the fixed assets, and only a fraction ascribed to their working capital," Mr. Ross said in a telephone interview. "These companies do nothing to make themselves accessible. There are no research reports on them. They don't put out press releases. They don't have outside directors. They are just there."
By buying low and diplomatically installing new management and new practices, an investor can make enterprises like Kansai Sawayaka Bank profitable and attractive to new investors, said Mr. Ross, who is managing a private equity fund that concentrates on turning around small Japanese companies. Six weeks ago, the California Public Employees' Retirement System announced that it would invest $200 million in the fund, which has a goal of $1 billion in investments.
Many of the investment banks that are radically downsizing here had bet on a financial services boom. Mr. Ross said that one essential to making money in Japan is to operate on the premise that the Japanese economy will basically remain flat for the foreseeable future.
But by buying low and reorganizing, value can be added, said Mr. Ross, a former Rothschild Inc. banker who helped reorganize Texaco and Continental Airlines in the 1980's. In South Korea, Mr. Ross is negotiating to buy Kia Steel, which collapsed during the Asian currency crisis five years ago.
In Japan, Ripplewood Holdings, another American investment fund specializing in distressed properties, is also planning a major new purchase. According to a report in the Nihon Keizai, Ripplewood is in the final stages of negotiating the purchase of the land-line division of Japan Telecom Holdings, a sale that could be worth $2.2 billion.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Wilbur Ross runs an equity fund, and sees opportunity in Japan. (Bloomberg News)(pg. W7)

PERSON: GEORGE McDONALD 

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES; 
A Blue Jumpsuit and a Path to Self-Sufficiency

BYLINE:  By LYNDA RICHARDSON 

 BODY:
GEORGE McDONALD walks briskly through the 198-bed shelter for men in Harlem run by the Doe Fund, a nonprofit organization that he founded in 1985. It is payday. Cash. Is that why the men are all smiles, with so many nice things to say? The men are trainees of the fund's Ready, Willing and Able program, the guys in the ubiquitous royal-blue jumpsuits who sweep sidewalks, bag garbage, clear street gutters. They must work for the right to stay in the shelter.
 Mr. McDonald, a tall, garrulous man with bushy eyebrows and horn-rimmed glasses, has driven uptown on a recent afternoon from the brownstone that is his office and home on East 84th Street to give a shelter tour and to champion his initiative to put homeless people to work. 
 His program recently got a big boost when a state appeals court cleared the way for a new 400-bed men's shelter in East Williamsburg, Brooklyn. The Doe Fund will own and operate the shelter in a 22-year, $176 million city contract that dates from the Giuliani administration. The fund will now run three shelters, including one in Bedford-Stuyvesant, out of about 40 shelters for single adults in New York City.
"I have something to offer the guy when he is laying on the street, and that's a hand up, not a handout," Mr. McDonald says. "I'm extremely excited about the opportunity to be able to expand our program by 400 more men, and to be able to help them accept responsibility and move into this great economic system we have, the larger program called America."
Mr. McDonald, who is 59, can't seem to keep still. He rocks from side to side when standing, and stomps his foot or slaps his thigh when sitting. He carries on like a politician.
Not that he hasn't tried that. A former apparel marketing executive, he sought the Democratic nomination for Congress from the East Side in the 1980's before parlaying his crusade for the homeless into the nonprofit fund. While campaigning, he says, he spent 700 straight nights feeding the homeless in Grand Central Terminal. Among them was a diminutive, white-haired woman who came to be known as Mama Doe after she died of pneumonia in the terminal. Mr. McDonald identified her corpse in the morgue, and named the fund after her.
In the shelter on 155th Street, Mr. McDonald is describing how Ready, Willing and Able has trained 1,500 men and women. He takes an interviewer into an intake room, where a robotic machine is testing urine samples for drugs. He pokes his head into administrative offices and dormitory-style rooms where a few men sit on single beds, tidy rows of shoes beneath their feet. He is joined on the tour by his wife, Harriet Karr-McDonald, a former screenwriter who is the fund's vice president, and a shelter director, Alton Johnson.
Mr. McDonald tosses out questions to the men, most of whom have histories of substance abuse and prison. What was the shelter like before the fund took over management from the city in 1996? Was it crime-infested? Were people using crack? The response: You've got that right, Mr. McDonald.
The fact that Mr. McDonald touts a work-for-shelter policy -- the fund pays trainees up to $6.50 an hour -- puts him at odds with many homeless services providers, and so does the fact that trainees get evicted from the shelter if they break rules, like missing work assignments or using drugs.
Mr. McDonald believes he is creating self-sufficiency. And he expects good results from the Williamsburg shelter, even though it drew bitter opposition. Business owners and residents worried that crime would go up in the industrial area. Elected officials criticized the city for selecting the Doe Fund under an accelerated bidding process. The Coalition for the Homeless argued that the shelter was not a wise use of taxpayers' money, which would be better spent on permanent housing.
Mentioning criticism from the coalition elicits a strong reaction from Mr. McDonald, who once volunteered for the group. It sort of reminds one of the old vaudeville routine, "Niagara Falls/Slo-o-wly I turned." His face reddens. He lashes out. He calls the group jealous.
"They obviously know you can't take people from off the street and put them into permanent housing, but they are disingenuous with their criticism," Mr. McDonald said. "It really does get my Irish up, I tell you," he added.
MR. McDONALD says his philosophy stems from his background. "I was a businessman, and brought it to bear on a social problem, and I did that because I wanted to be a politician, and somewhere along the line the politics went away."
In his Upper East Side office, there are pictures of John F. Kennedy and Robert F. Kennedy on the burgundy-colored walls. Mr. McDonald was the statewide director of volunteers for Edward M. Kennedy's presidential campaign in 1980. He says he is a registered Democrat, but describes himself as nonpartisan when it comes to city politics.
Growing up in Spring Lake, N.J., an upper-middle-class enclave, the son of an insurance company executive, he recalls, with some amusement, how the nuns in parochial school used the ruler for more than just measuring. He says they also drilled into him the importance of giving back to the community.
"Why am I this way? I don't know. Go ask the nuns. Go ask God. I know when I see a guy lying in the street, I want to help him up."

GRAPHIC: Photo: GEORGE McDONALD (Keith Bedford for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Coalition Adds New Support For a Harbor Freight Tunnel 

BYLINE:  By JANNY SCOTT 

 BODY:
A proposal to reduce truck traffic in New York City and the region by building a rail freight tunnel under New York Harbor got new support yesterday when a broad group of business, labor, environmental and civic leaders announced that they had formed a coalition to lobby for federal money for the project.
 The coalition, which includes representatives of groups ranging from the Sierra Club and the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce to the state A.F.L.-C.I.O. and the Rev. Calvin O. Butts III, pastor of the Abyssinian Baptist Church, wants Congress to help pay for the project out of a transportation spending bill currently up for reauthorization. 
 The group, called MoveNY, says the tunnel would divert nearly a million truck trips a year from the George Washington Bridge, reduce pollution in city neighborhoods with high asthma rates, cut traffic delays in the region, generate tens of thousands of jobs, save highway maintenance costs and limit the risks of terrorism presented by unscreened trucks. 
"It's clearly technically feasible to do this tunnel," said Francis X. McArdle, managing director of the General Contractors Association of New York and a member of the coalition. "And we believe that it is an economic advantage to this region to make this investment. Not only will it help us to continually grow, but it gives us some opportunities for economic development that we would not otherwise have."
Representative Jerrold L. Nadler, a Manhattan Democrat, has been interested in the project throughout the last 20 years. Skeptics who considered the idea in its earlier incarnations have argued that the reduction in truck traffic would be smaller than proponents contend because most freight would still move by truck within the city. They have also said the city was no longer a competitive location for the kind of high-volume, mass-production industries that rely heavily on rail. 
"It's a 19th-century project that's two centuries too late," said Mitchell L. Moss, director of the Taub Urban Research Center at New York University and a co-author of a 1998 analysis of the tunnel idea. "And this project represents a threat to much more important priorities to the city and the region."
The idea of a rail freight connection by tunnel between New Jersey and the area across New York Harbor has been tossed around since the 1920's, Mr. McArdle and others said. For many years, rail freight was transported across the harbor by float bridge. But even that ended after the merger of the Pennsylvania and New York Central Railroads in 1968 and the subsequent creation of Conrail in 1976.
Now less than 2 percent of all freight coming in and out of the region is transported by rail, compared with 40 percent in cities nationally, Mr. Nadler said. The nearest railroad crossing over the Hudson is 140 miles north of the city in Selkirk, just south of Albany.
"We've got a real crisis now in goods movement, and it's only going to get worse," said Robert D. Yaro, president of the Regional Plan Association and a member of the coalition. "The volumes of freight moving into and through the region are increasing at about 3 percent a year. Over a decade, that's by a third. And you think about what congestion is like on the George Washington Bridge and the Tappan Zee now. There's just no place to put it."
The 19 coalition members range from labor union leaders including Dennis Rivera, president of Local 1199 of the Service Employees International Union; and environmentalists like James T. B. Tripp, general counsel for Environmental Defense, formerly the Environmental Defense Fund; to business leaders like Kenneth Adams, president of the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce; and civic activists like Dr. Rafael A. Lantigua, chairman of the board of directors of Alianza Dominicana, the largest Dominican social service agency in the city.
Dr. Lantigua, an internist and professor of clinical medicine at Columbia University, said he joined the coalition because he has lived in Washington Heights his entire life and works there. He has "no doubt that the amount of bronchial asthma that we see in this area is linked to the pollution of the traffic across the George Washington Bridge."
The tunnel would create a Hudson River crossing connecting freight railroads in New Jersey to unused railroads in Sunset Park, Brooklyn. Mr. Nadler said the most recent estimate of the cost of the tunnel alone was $1.8 billion; the cost of the entire project, including rail improvements, has been put at $7 billion.
Members of the coalition said they wanted to persuade Congress to pay for the design and perhaps the next steps of the project out of the Transportation Equity Act for the 21st Century, a pending bill that is intended to pay for major transportation projects for the next six years.

GRAPHIC: Map of New York shows the location of the proposed rail-freight tunnel: A coalition will lobby for federal aid in building a freight tunnel.

HEADLINE: Chrysler Sees Sizable Loss For Quarter 

BYLINE:  By MICHELINE MAYNARD 

DATELINE: DETROIT, June 3 

 BODY:
Vividly illustrating the toll that incentives are taking on the American automobile industry, the Chrysler Corporation said today that it would post a $1.2 billion operating loss for the second quarter and would be only marginally profitable this year.
 The announcement that Chrysler and its parent, DaimlerChrysler, expected to miss their earnings goals came as automakers announced sales data showing that May was a tepid month over all, despite incentive programs that include big rebates and interest-free loans. 
 Cars and trucks sold at an annual rate of 16.1 million vehicles in May. That was better than the 15.7 million selling rate a year earlier but a marked slowdown both from the sales level at the end of 2002 and from periods recently when dealerships were comparably awash in incentives. 
The figures are one of the earliest formal measures of the economy's health in the wake of the war in Iraq, and auto executives described them as solid under the circumstances. 
"When you consider all that the economy has been through -- the uncertainty clouding the war in Iraq, the equity prices going nowhere, energy prices going up, the uncertainty that was coming through in consumer confidence -- this level of sales is pretty good," said George Pipas, the sales statistician at the Ford Motor Company.
General Motors, outspending its competitors on incentives, said its sales rose 4 percent from a year earlier, the first time this year that G.M.'s sales have climbed. Ford said its sales fell 0.7 percent. Both G.M. and Ford announced plans to cut third-quarter production, on top of cuts in the second quarter.
Chrysler said its sales fell 3 percent in May. But with lower inventories than some of its rivals, the company does not plan to cut production.
On Monday, Chrysler -- which has tried to position itself as a premium brand with an import flair -- reversed its conservative course on incentives and unveiled a sweeping program, offering a choice of rebates as large as $4,500 a vehicle or interest-free financing.
And indeed, DaimlerChrysler said today that Chrysler now was unlikely to earn the $2 billion operating profit this year that was the declared goal of the turnaround effort being led by Dieter Zetsche, Chrysler's chief executive. DaimlerChrysler said it still expected Chrysler to be modestly profitable for 2003. But the parent company, which had said it could beat last year's $5.6 billion group profit, now only expects to match it.
Standard & Poor's immediately lowered its outlook for DaimlerChrysler from stable to negative, calling the quarterly Chrysler loss "staggering." The Chrysler announcement came after the close of American stock trading. DaimlerChrysler shares closed at $31.65, down 11 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Ford said it was reaffirming its second-quarter profit estimate of 70 cents a share. G.M. did not comment on the quarterly outlook. But its chief executive, Rick Wagoner, said at G.M.'s annual meeting in Wilmington, Del., that it might be difficult for the company to achieve its target of $10 a share in annual earnings by mid-decade, because of brutal industry competition.
Under Mr. Zetsche, Chrysler has cut costs and achieved profitability, earning $1.6 billion last year, and $166 million during this year's first quarter.
But Mr. Zetsche, in a telephone interview from Stuttgart, said a series of factors had been devastating to Chrysler's outlook. After May's modest sales decline, sales at Chrysler in recent days have fallen 10 percent or more from levels a year ago; the company, he said, had expected sales to bounce back after the conclusion of fighting in Iraq.
"We didn't see that happening," Mr. Zetsche said. "We didn't see spring momentum building. On top of that, we saw incentive increases."
Though in the past he has likened incentives to heroin, Mr. Zetsche said Chrysler felt it had to expand its spending to match G.M.'s, which he said had risen by $500 a vehicle in the last month. "We never drove it and will not drive it," he said of incentives. But, he added, "we have to somewhat follow it."
In doing so, however, Chrysler must book the cost of increased incentives on the 500,000 vehicles already on dealer lots as well as on future vehicles; Mr. Zetsche would not say how much that would cost the company.
Also, Chrysler will incur an undisclosed charge because incentives have lowered the resale value of vehicles that it buys back from car-rental companies, Mr. Zetsche added.
The timing of Chrysler's announcement -- coming in the final month of the quarter -- raised some analysts' eyebrows, but DaimlerChrysler had recently begun warning that Chrysler was encountering trouble. "Obviously, they've got a feel as for what the month of June is likely to be like, i.e., intensely competitive," said Joseph Phillippi, an industry analyst with Auto Trends in Short Hills, N.J. "It was incumbent upon them to get this out." 
Chrysler's expected loss is the latest demonstration of how vulnerable the company is to shifts in industry winds. Just before Mr. Zetsche came to Chrysler's headquarters in Auburn Hills, Mich., Chrysler lost $5 billion in two months, when it was caught unprepared by an industry slowdown and subsequent expansion of incentives.
Last Friday, Chrysler announced the resignation of its chief marketing executive, James C. Schroer, who is being replaced by a DaimlerChrysler executive, Joseph Eberhardt. 
Mr. Zetsche would not comment today on the departure of Mr. Schroer, who, like him, tried to keep Chrysler out of the incentive spiral. Asked whether he regretted his past reticence on incentives, Mr. Zetsche replied: "If I would have to do it again, I would try to slow the incentive game and not fuel it up. I do believe it's a zero-sum game."
Mr. Zetsche said Chrysler did not see a need to cut production, since it has only a 60-day supply of vehicles, less than the 65-day supply that is considered ideal during the spring selling season. But Ford said yesterday that it ended May with close to 80 days in inventories and would cut third-quarter production by 15 percent, in large part by slowing output of the Ford Taurus and Mercury Sable sedans. G.M. did not disclose its inventories, but it announced a 6 percent production cut.
Officials at G.M. and Ford said that they were optimistic for the fourth quarter and beyond, citing the expected impact of federal tax cuts and their sense that consumer confidence and the stock market were rebounding with the conclusion of the fighting in Iraq.
A number of foreign-based auto companies, meanwhile, reported strong results in May.
Toyota and Honda reported their best May sales in history. The Infiniti division of Nissan said its sales jumped 40 percent, thanks to the introduction of sexy-looking vehicles like the FX sport utility, built on the chassis of the Z350 sports car. BMW, Mercedes-Benz, Audi, Porsche and Hyundai also said sales rose in May.

HEADLINE: ON EDUCATION; 
In the Affluent Suburbs, An Invisible Race Gap

BYLINE:  By Michael Winerip 

DATELINE: MAPLEWOOD, N.J. 

 BODY:
ACROSS America, there may be two or three dozen suburban school districts similar to this one, towns like Evanston, Ill.; Shaker Heights, Ohio; Arlington, Va.; White Plains. They are heavily upper middle class, are racially mixed and feature high quality public schools.
 The high school here, Columbia High, is 51 percent black and sends 77 percent of its seniors to four-year colleges. 
 Five percent are accepted to the Ivy League. A lot of black Columbia High graduates go on to big things. Rhena Jasey went to Harvard, Colin Brown to Princeton, Carla Peterman won a Rhodes, Lauryn Hill won five Grammys. 
From afar, these racially mixed suburbs appear to be the fulfillment of the Brown v. Board of Education desegregation ruling a half century ago. Green and tree-lined, they look like the quintessential level playing field. They seem to make the need for affirmative action passe.
But they are not what they appear to be, as Ronald Ferguson, a Harvard professor, knows from surveying 34,000 seventh to eleventh graders in 15 of these racially mixed suburbs across the nation.
Everywhere, he finds the achievement gap, with whites averaging B+ and blacks C+. Professor Ferguson calculates about half the Gap can be explained by economic differences. 
When the wealth of the 15 towns is dissected into four socioeconomic classes, 79 percent of blacks are in the bottom 50 percent; 73 percent of whites are in the top 50 percent. Fifty-three percent of these suburban black children live with one or neither parent, compared with 15 percent of whites.
Twenty-two percent of the blacks have no computer at home compared with 3 percent of whites. Forty percent of blacks own 100 or more books, compared with 80 percent of whites.
All this spills into these schools. "Teachers see black kids not doing as well academically, getting more incompletes on their homework," Professor Ferguson said. "They interpret that to mean black kids don't care, don't work as hard."
Yet whites and blacks taking similar level courses report that they spend the same time on homework. It is just that the results are different: 38 percent of whites who spend two hours on homework nightly get all their work done; only 20 percent of blacks spending two hours finish their homework -- the Gap.
It would be politically convenient for Professor Ferguson, a black man raising his two children plus a nephew in a Boston suburb, if the Gap could be explained away by economics.
It cannot. When he controls for income, half the Gap persists. Among the richest families, blacks average B+, whites A-. How to explain it?
On a political level, he believes the human damage from two centuries of slavery plus legalized segregation that persisted until the mid-1960's will simply not be undone in a generation, not even in suburbia.
On a personal level, he has looked hard at the data for ways to narrow the Gap.
While 31 percent of whites say that a teacher's encouragement motivates them to work hard, 47 percent of blacks cite teacher encouragement as crucial. Professor Ferguson believes this may reflect the black children's insecurity.
"Even in our own towns, we may feel like outsiders," he says. And so, Professor Ferguson runs seminars for teachers that emphasize the importance of encouraging these children to excel.
If whites and blacks spend the same time on homework, and the black child is not getting as much done, says Professor Ferguson, "that's a skills gap." He works with schools to focus on the points in the curriculum where children fall behind, and to develop smarter ways to teach those lessons.
His research shows that in the years before school, white parents spend more time reading to their children, while blacks devote more to song and play -- the start of the Gap. Professor Ferguson writes, "As a black parent, I acknowledge there might be differences in what we do with our preschool children that would put them on a more equal footing with whites on the first day of kindergarten." 
While he practices that at home, quizzing his 3-year-old with math problems, he is hesitant to speak too much publicly about advising black parents.
"If it shows up in The New York Times, it's like, wait a minute, here's another guy saying to black parents, 'It's your fault.' This needs to be done within the community."
In this community, Robert Marchman, 45, a lawyer with the New York Stock Exchange, has taken on the Gap. He is chairman of the South Orange/Maplewood Community Coalition on Race, which has been sponsoring discussions on the Gap and helped bring Professor Ferguson here.
Mr. Marchman is one of a dozen black dads who run a mentoring program for 30 black eighth graders. "We talk about stuff you hear, like, 'being smart is acting white,' " Mr. Marchman said. "I'll say to them, 'So what does being black mean? To be an idiot?' "
Mr. Marchman himself has bridged the Gap. He grew up in a Brooklyn housing project and when he was a senior, took the SAT, without any preparation. In the high school guidance office, he picked a college by starting with the letter "A" which landed him at Alleghany College.
By law school -- at the University of Pennsylvania -- he was no longer making educational decisions based on alphabetical order.
Last summer, before his older son, David, entered 10th grade, Mr. Marchman bought the boy his first SAT study guide.
While Mr. Marchman played basketball ("that's all there was"), he encouraged David to switch from football to lacrosse, because it is a niche sport that might help get him into a top college.
Though Mr. Marchman has made it to the far side of the Gap, he keeps his guard up. At the start of each school year, he makes appointments to see the teachers of his sons, David and Travis. "I put on a business suit," he says. "I want to set the tone with the teachers. I want them to know we have high expectations." His are black children to be encouraged, he wants the teachers to know.
And though Mr. Marchman no longer needs affirmative action, he supports it, for even in this suburban place, he can see more clearly than most all those children still finding their way across the Gap.

HEADLINE: 10% of Units Have Escaped Rent Limits 

BYLINE:  By JOSH BARBANEL 

 BODY:
More than 10 percent of the New York City apartments covered by rent regulations have gone on the open market or otherwise been removed from regulations since the Legislature began loosening the system in 1993, according to a study released yesterday.
 The study, by the New York City Rent Guidelines Board, which sets rent levels on regulated apartments, found that 105,421 units had been reported by owners to have been removed from regulation for various reasons from 1994 to 2002. 
 The report said that at least 27,326 apartments had been removed from rent regulation under provisions allowing deregulation of apartments renting for $2,000 or more, under changes enacted by the Legislature in 1993 and broadened in 1997. This amounts to 3 percent of the 910,000 rent-stabilized apartments registered in 1993. 
The rest were attributed to 32,660 rental units lost as tenants moved out of co-op and condo conversions, 26,476 related to the expiration of temporary controls linked to tax-abatement programs, and smaller numbers linked to conversion of professional buildings, combining apartments and in some cases, demolitions and fires.
The loss of long-regulated units is a flash point in the debate about the nation's most extensive patchwork of rent regulations, which have been in place in one form or another since World War II. 
Tenant groups see the losses as an indicator that New York is losing its stock of affordable housing and that legislative changes that weakened the laws need to be rolled back. Owners say the shift from regulated to market-rate rents is long-overdue relief from a program providing large subsidies for affluent residents of Manhattan and far smaller benefits in the rest of the city.
The losses of these older stabilized apartments were offset in part by about 30,000 new apartments temporarily added to the rent regulation system when owners voluntarily sign up for regulation in exchange for tax abatements. But the starting rents in these new apartments are market rents that are typically much higher than $2,000 a month.
The numbers were released at a meeting of the board in Lower Manhattan as it took testimony and reviewed reports in preparing for a final vote on proposed rent increases for apartments covered by the rent-stabilization program. The proposed increases, which would cover leases renewed after next Oct. 1, would be 5 1/2 percent on one-year lease renewals and 8 1/2 percent on two-year renewals. The increases, the biggest since 1989, were intended in part to offset large increases in city property taxes. The vote is scheduled for June 19, following a public hearing on June 17.
At the meeting, the board heard testimony about the impact of the recession on lower-income New Yorkers. It was also told by Daniel L. Greenberg, president of the Legal Aid Society, that such large increases would eventually result in his staff's struggling to prevent the eviction of hundreds of families and their fall into homelessness. "You have the powerto keep so many of these people from becoming homeless," he said. 
The estimates of the number of apartments removed from regulation because of high rents were lower than many owners and tenants had projected, but the report also showed that the number of such apartments has been rising, and more than doubled in three years. They increased to 6,406 last year from 3,164 in 2000. Nine out of 10 of these apartments were in Manhattan. 
But the board's staff also stressed that the number of deregulated apartments reported were "the floor," or the lower limit for such numbers, since the number was based on filings by landlords with the state, and since owners have not always been required to report the decontrol of units to the state. (The report does not include the 60,000 apartments still covered by an older and more strict rent control law, which are outside the board's jurisdiction.)
The board's figures include provisions of laws adopted since 1993 that allow for the decontrol of vacant apartments when the legal regulated rent reaches $2,000. There were 24,370 of these deregulations recording in filings by landlords with the state.
In addition, apartments can be removed from regulation when the legal rent reaches $2,000 and the current tenant's income exceeds $175,000 a year for two consecutive years. There were 2,956 such apartments removed from regulation between 1994 and 2002, according to filings with the state.
The debate over rent regulation has always been contentious, extending even to basic statistics and a seemingly simple question of how many regulated apartments exist in New York City.
Building owners previously estimated that 30,000 to 50,000 apartments had been deregulated in the same period through the deregulation of high-rent apartments. But yesterday spokesmen for landlord groups cited the new figures, which were lower than their own estimates, to make their case that vacancy decontrol was ineffective and needed to be strengthened.
"What this report says is that 60 years from now we will still have rent regulations choking the city's economy," said Jack Freund, executive vice president of the Rent Stabilization Association, an owners' group.
Tenant advocates, who had released estimates that up to 100,000 apartments had been lost to deregulation, said that the new numbers on high-rent deregulation were meaningless because many owners did not report changes and many more did not bother to register at all with the Rent Guidelines Board.
"The issue is not just protecting people who currently live in rent-regulated apartments," said Michael McKee, associate director of New York State Tenants and Neighbors Coalition. "It is to keep these apartments affordable for people who come to the city and for children who grow up here and need a home of their own."

GRAPHIC: Photos: The Rent Guidelines Board, left, heard some testimony yesterday, while tenant advocates, above, protested outside City Hall. (Photographs by Ruby Washington/The New York Times)(pg. B3)

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR: SALARIES; 
Cash for the Kurds Is Assailed as Inadequate

BYLINE:  By SABRINA TAVERNISE 

DATELINE: ERBIL, Iraq, June 3 

 BODY:
Thirty million dollars arrived late last week to pay the April salaries of state workers in the independent Kurdish enclave, but the Kurds were disappointed.
 Officials in Erbil, in the western Kurdish zone, said the money received Friday to pay teachers, hospital workers and other government workers amounted to far less than employees formerly received. They also complained because there was no money for the pesh merga fighters, American allies in the war, and warned that local sentiment could harden against American rule. 
 "If they don't pay more than we did, they should at least pay the same," said the finance minister of the western enclave, Sarkis Agha Jan. "We want our people to feel their lives have gotten better since the Americans have come." 
In Erbil this evening, at his streetside shish kebab stand, Fathel Abdulla, 36, a soft-spoken man who has been a fighter since 1991, had angry words about American rule.
"Pesh merga prepared everything for the Americans," he said, sitting in a plastic lawn chair near his grill. "We liberated this area with our blood. Now they act with us like we are cheap, not human, like some kind of servants." 
The fighters have not been paid since January, and Mr. Abdulla started the tiny grill this spring, when he could not make ends meet for his wife and four children. His fighter friends, in similar straits, come to him for food. He pulled out a small notebook with I.O.U. tallies for dinners. In all, he is owed $700, a small fortune. His monthly salary before the war was $100.
Lt. Col. William Butcher, chief of staff for the Office of Coalition Provisional Authority in the north, said the salaries were simplified in order to pay people more quickly and would be adjusted later. 
"This is an interim salary structure developed by coalition authorities in Baghdad," Colonel Butcher said. "It's a good news story. It's difficult to get all the information you need from 18 different provinces and make it exactly right the first time." 
Kurdish officials have criticized American unwillingness to pay their soldiers, who fought in the north alongside the Americans after Turkey refused to open its border. Allied officials in Baghdad were not available for comment tonight.
The region needs the cash badly. Customs revenues, the main source of income for most of the Kurdish region, an independent enclave since 1991, dried up during the war, and salaries have not been paid since March, the month the war began. 
"We are now going through one of the worst economic situations we have ever known," said Nechirvan Barzani, the governor of the western enclave and the nephew of Massoud Barzani, leader of the Kurdistan Democratic Party. "There are no taxes and trade is at a standstill." 
Even worse, revenue from the United Nations oil-for-food program, once a big part of the region's income, has stopped flowing. That money exceeded that of the regional budget and was a very important cushion for the region's economy.
The money came packed in plastic bags, some in denominations as small as five-dollar and one-dollar bills, said Mr. Jan, who added that he expected to begin distribution to employees "in the next few days." 
The cash injection will help ease the financial crunch, but the Kurds are unhappy with the new 10-grade pay scale the Americans devised, which pays much less to employees than before the war, Mr. Jan said.
For instance, a teacher, who before the war received the equivalent of $120 to $410, will now receive $50 and a $30 bonus. The losses will be more severe for highly paid employees. Judges, for instance, will get $250, far less than the $830 they earned before the war.
In all, pesh merga fighters in the western enclave, which is run by the Kurdisstan Democratic Party, number about 63,000, said Sami Abdul Rahman, a senior party official. 
That leaves Mr. Abdulla and others like him with no savings, no insurance, no security and no pay, except what he can earn from selling grilled meat.
"Please print my words," Mr. Abdulla said, squinting in the smoke. "This is not just my problem. We are all in this situation."
