HEADLINE: TURF; 
Empty Nesters Helping New Nesters

BYLINE:  By MOTOKO RICH 

 BODY:
JOSHUA BEATON, a 27-year-old graduate student, was about to sign a lease on a $1,300 one-bedroom apartment in Brooklyn last summer when his father made him an offer he couldn't refuse.
 Mr. Beaton's father, Dr. Howard Beaton, had decided to buy a $315,000 apartment in a new condominium around the corner from his office at New York University Downtown Hospital in Manhattan. Dr. Beaton offered his son a chance to live in it, rent-free, for two years. 
 Dr. Beaton said he wasn't motivated by largess but by good business sense. In fact, he is about to buy a co-op studio apartment for his 24-year-old daughter Audrey on the Upper West Side. 
Dr. Beaton, the chief of surgery at the hospital, said he figured the mortgage payments would be close to what his children would have paid in rent. "I also thought it was a very good investment," he said.
On Valentine's Day, his son moved into the downtown condo. With hardwood floors, 12-foot ceilings and black marble kitchen countertops, it makes him feel "incredibly lucky," he said, sitting beneath a poster for "The Matrix" on a lumpy hand-me-down brown couch. "The alternative was that my dad would give me a certain amount of money, and I would give it to someone else," he said. "This way, the capital is kept inside the family."
Generous parents have helped with down payments and have even bought homes outright for their children for years. But in recent months, as mortgage rates fell and real estate held its own against a roiling stock market, parents have woken up to new investment potential. "It was like all of a sudden, everybody knew: buy apartments for your children," said Elaine Clayman, the Brown Harris Stevens broker who helped Dr. Beaton find a co-op for his daughter, who is starting graduate school in architecture at Columbia in the fall. 
Many parents say they aren't spoiling their offspring; they are making sound financial decisions. "There is no question: this is not a gift to them of an apartment," said Dr. Beaton, who already owns a three-bedroom co-op on the Upper West Side, a house in Connecticut and an apartment in Miami occupied by his in-laws. "I will need my equity back at some point."
JoAnne Kennedy, a president of Coldwell Banker Hunt Kennedy, a real estate brokerage company in New York, said her firm has helped at least 15 sets of parents buy apartments for their children this year, double last year's number. "Families have liquidity, and they just don'tknow what to do with it," she said.
Dan Levitan, a partner at Home Mortgage Acceptance, a broker in New York, estimated that loans to parents buying apartments for their children had risen about 30 percent since last year. Although many co-op buildings refuse to admit buyers whose parents are paying, CitiMortgage, a unit of Citigroup, last year created a type of loan directly aimed at that arrangement, with favorable rates for parents of children who don't have enough income or assets to qualify for a co-op mortgage on their own. 
The trend is not limited to New York. The parent-as-backer became a running joke in one Chicago household this spring when Andrew Levy, 31, and Gayle Littleton, 30, were shopping for an investment property and kept referring to "the investors." "You mean Mom and Dad?" their real estate agent asked. 
The young couple bought a $700,000 brick building in the gentrified Lincoln Square neighborhood and moved into one of its three units in April, renting out the other two. Mr. Levy's parents, Joel and Janet Levy, provided 65 percent of the down payment.
The younger Mr. Levy, a business and legal consultant, and Ms. Littleton, an assistant United States attorney, are using the income from the rental units to cover their monthly mortgage payments. If they sell the building, they will split the proceeds with his parents. 
Joel Levy, a 58-year-old technology executive, said he and his wife wanted somewhere besides Wall Street to invest their money. "It sounds almost greedy," he said, "but we were looking for an investment and they were looking for an investment, and it was a good opportunity."
Brokers from Boston to San Mateo, Calif., report an increase in similar transactions. One of the country's largest home lenders, Washington Mutual, said that it didn't have specific numbers but that it has seen a definite up-tick in loans taken out by parents or jointly with their children. "I'd say we're seeing parents helping out across the board," said Mike Axelrood, a first vice president of Washington Mutual and the regional sales manager of its Chicago office. 
Investing in any real estate these days, of course, is by no means a sure bet. On Monday, a government report showed that the growth in home prices during the first three months of the year had slowed to its smallest rise in five years. "We're obviously closer to a peak than we were," said Karl Case, a professor of economics at Wellesley College, who recently helped his 27-year-old daughter, an adjunct instructor at Brooklyn College, buy a two-bedroom co-op apartment in Park Slope, Brooklyn. 
"I don't think it's a terrific investment necessarily," he added, "but it's not a bad place to park your money."
In New York, parents face a particularly volatile market. Studios and one-bedroom apartments took nearly 10 years to recover from the last recession. Then, starting in 1998, sales prices of one-bedroom and studio condos and co-ops started to rise, climbing 103 percent by March of this year, according to Miller Samuel, a real estate appraisal firm.
Avram Goldman, president of Coldwell Banker Residential Brokerage in the San Francisco Bay Area, said the older generation is taking advantage of low interest rates and the appreciation of their own homes. 
Six months ago, Garold Murphy, a 50-year-old maintenance manager for the Hertz Corporation, refinanced the five-bedroom house he and his wife, Maureen, bought in 1989 about 20 minutes south of San Francisco. They are using some of the proceeds for a down payment on a two-bedroom condo for their 22-year-old daughter, Tara, and her fiance, Luther Boatwright. 
"I wouldn't call it a wedding present," Mr. Murphy said. "It's more of a direct investment." 
Like many real estate arrangements, this one comes with caveats, starting with the fact that the owner often gets to call the shots. In March, Sean Hill, 23, moved into a $515,000 one-bedroom, two-bathroom condo in Midtown Manhattan bought by his parents, Dr. Michael Hill and Dr. Suvimol Hill of Potomac, Md. The immaculate apartment was decorated by his mother, a radiologist, who said that she was eager to unload some of the family's surplus furniture and thought that she and her husband, as owners, ought to decorate in their own taste. "We're not really buying it for Sean," she added. "We are buying it, and he is staying in it."
The apartment, with upholstered dining room chairs and dark wood bedroom furniture, shows little sign of the avid intramural athlete and former MTV video jockey who lives there. Mr. Hill, who is studying for the law school admissions test while working as a paralegal, said he might have chosen a shag carpet instead of the oatmeal-colored area rug his mother installed in the living room. "I also would have chosen a flashier blue or red couch," Mr. Hill said, gesturing at a beige sofa. "But my dad said there's no way you are going to get a red couch."
Mr. Hill hastened to add that he loves the apartment and recognizes his good fortune in paying just $700 a month in maintenance fees and electricity bills for a home that is much fancier than the places his friends pay $1,200 to share.
Dara Pettinelli, 22 years old and an aspiring rock music journalist, similarly noted that if her father, Don Pettinelli of Margate, N.J., buys her an apartment this summer, as planned, she will be far better off than friends who are bunking four or five to an apartment. "I put it into his head that I'll be 'out' with my friends if I live in some penthouse suite in a doorman building while they're living with three other people in Harlem," Ms. Pettinelli said. 
For his part, Mr. Pettinelli, 64, says buying a home for his daughter will make it easier to sleep at night. "I'm concerned about her security and the fact that her profession doesn't demand a large salary at the beginning," he said.
He acknowledges that his daughter would like to live in the West Village, "deep down in the environment of the struggling writers and artists," adding, "I would rather she be on the Upper East Side of Manhattan."

HEADLINE: 3 States Sue E.P.A. to Regulate Emissions of Carbon Dioxide 

BYLINE:  By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
Carbon dioxide emissions from cars and power plants should be regulated as an air pollutant because they contribute to global warming, three Northeast states said yesterday in a federal lawsuit against the Environmental Protection Agency.
 State officials in Connecticut, Maine and Massachusetts said the suit, filed in Federal District Court in Hartford, is the first time that any state has sued the government to compel action on climate change. 
 If the suit succeeds, the E.P.A. will be required to classify carbon dioxide as a "criteria pollutant," under the Federal Clean Air Act, and that would trigger, the state's lawyers say, a process of setting standards for allowable levels in the atmosphere, as the federal government now does for ozone, lead and sulfur dioxide and other gasses.
"Global warming is no longer some abstract threat -- it's real and it's urgent," said Richard Blumenthal, attorney general of Connecticut. "Our lawsuit is a last resort." 
An E.P.A. spokesman, David Deegan, said the agency was still studying the suit and would have no specific comment. But he said that President Bush and Christie Whitman, the E.P.A. administrator, had made their positions clear.
"The president and Administrator Whitman have said that carbon dioxide shouldn't be regulated as a pollutant; the science on it is more complex, and the answers are elusive right now," he said. "They support a flexible approach that will adjust for new information and technology."
Ms. Whitman resigned last month and is leaving her post at the end of this month. The White House has not yet nominated a successor.
The heart of the states' argument, legal experts said, comes down, to a certain extent, to semantics: what exactly constitutes a pollutant? When the Clean Air Act was passed in the 1970's, air pollution meant things would make people demonstrably sick. But as evidence of indirect consequences has grown -- like the chemical combinations that form smog, for instance, or acid rain, which mainly affects aquatic life -- the boundary of what is considered harmful has expanded.
The suit contends that while carbon dioxide does not pose a direct threat to human health, it has passed over the threshold of harm because of its role inglobal warming. The scientific evidence about the buildup of so-called greenhouse gases like carbon dioxide -- and the long-term threats posed by climate upheaval on everything from emerging diseases to economics -- are so firmly established, the states say, that the government has a responsibility to act.
"E.P.A. itself predicts that the problems associated with atmospheric warming will intensify in the years to come," said Steven Rowe, Maine's attorney general. "The agency has a legal duty to act now."
A spokesman for the Edison Electric Institute, a trade group that represents shareholder-owned electricity companies, said the suit, if it succeeds, would hurt the economy without achieving its desired results. Electric power plants and automobiles account for a majority of the carbon dioxide emissions in the nation.
The spokesman, Dan Riedinger, said there is currently no technological means of eliminating carbon dioxide from a power plant's smokestacks. Imposing atmospheric standards, he said, would force plants to switch from burning coal, which produces lots of carbon dioxide, to natural gas, which produces less. But that kind of shift, he said, could bring havoc to the nation's natural gas supply and delivery system.
"To be effective, any policy response to global warming must allow time for new technology," he said.
Many states are starting to address climate change concerns. This year, Gov. George E. Pataki of New York said he hoped to create a regional consortium of states, from Maine to Maryland, to work on the issue. New Hampshire has passed legislation regulating power plant emissions. California passed a law last year requiring reductions in carbon dioxide for automobiles.
"There's a lot of activity, and it's all building," said Ashok Gupta, the director of air and energy programs at the Natural Resources Defense Council, a New York-based conservation group. "At some point, we will be regulating carbon dioxide at power plants, if not in the whole economy. It's a question of when."

HEADLINE: Service Industry Growth Is Brisk; Worker Productivity Accelerates 

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
A gauge of the services industries, the largest part of the economy, rose in May by the most in a year, adding to evidence that growth may be poised to accelerate, a report released yesterday indicated. 
 The index for retailing, financial services and other nonmanufacturing companies from the Institute for Supply Management increased more than expected, to 54.5 from 50.7 in April, the second consecutive expansion. The jump was the biggest since May 2002. Readings above 50 suggest expansion. 
 A companion report from the institute this week showed the biggest monthly gain in manufacturing so far in 2003.
Still another report from the Labor Department said yesterday that the pace of growth in worker productivity in the first quarter was almost three times that of the previous three months, helping to underpin profits. Productivity, a measure of how much an employee produces for every hour of work, rose at a 1.9 percent annual pace, the Labor Department said. That compared with last month's estimate of 1.6 percent and with a 0.7 percent pace of increase in the fourth quarter of 2002. 
"Businesses have clearly worked much harder to get more efficient," said Stephen Stanley, senior market economist at RBS Greenwich Capital Markets in Greenwich, Conn. 
On Tuesday, the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, suggested that economic momentum might increase in the second half of the year, citing gains in stocks and credit markets.
And the Bank of America Corporation, the biggest United States lender to individuals and companies, said that demand for commercial loans was accelerating. Economic recovery "has got to come from the medium- and small-sized businesses who start to invest, start to build inventory, start to buy some technology and hire some of their people back," said James H. Hance Jr., the bank's chief financial officer. "And all of that's beginning."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; 
U.S. Investor Drops Bid For TV Unit Of Kirch

BYLINE:  By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: BERLIN, June 4 

 BODY:
Three months after striking a landmark deal that would have put Germany's largest television broadcaster into foreign hands, a Hollywood investor, Haim Saban, abandoned his bid today after failing to come to terms with creditors of the broadcaster's bankrupt parent, KirchMedia.
 In a joint statement issued by Mr. Saban and Kirch's administrators, the two sides said, "Details of the purchase could not be clarified between the seller, purchaser and the banks within the agreed deadline." 
 They said they would remain in touch and had parted on friendly terms -- a grace note suggesting that the negotiations, which have been through uncounted ups and down, might be rekindled.
For now, though, Mr. Saban's ambitions to take over the broadcasting company, ProSiebenSat.1, seem moribund. KirchMedia said the creditors, which include major German banks, would manage it directly.
Analysts speculated that Mr. Saban, who made a fortune producing children's cartoons like "Mighty Morphin Power Rangers," had found it difficult to line up partners and financing for the acquisition, estimated to be valued at 2 billion euros, or about $2.3 billion.
One prospective partner, the French broadcaster TF1, struggled to win approval for an investment from its board. Mr. Saban also held talks with several leveraged-buyout firms in the United States.
Executives close to Mr. Saban, though, said that the problems had more to do with the changing economic environment, chiefly the strong rise of the euro against the dollar since the deal was announced.
"The euro is 11 percent higher than when we signed the deal," one executive said. "Haim just decided that at these prices, he wasn't going to do it."
Under the terms of the deal, Mr. Saban had until the end of May to hammer out definitive terms. He was also negotiating for control of KirchMedia's film library, one of the largest in Europe.
Mr. Saban flew to KirchMedia's offices in Munich to try to salvage the acquisition. "It was a little bit of a game of chicken at the end," the executive said.
Another complication was posed by the minority shareholders of ProSiebenSat.1. Mr. Saban was seeking exemption from a German regulation that requires the buyer of a controlling stake to offer the same terms to other shareholders. If he had been turned down, it would have added 500 million euros to the price.
Mr. Saban contended that ProSiebenSat.1 was a turnaround project. The company, battered by the advertising recession, reported a loss of 33 million euros in the first quarter. A successful acquisition would have been the first time that a German television broadcaster passed into foreign control.
It is not clear whether the collapse of the deal opens the door for a resumption of talks with Heinrich Bauer Verlag, a German publisher that had emerged as the main rival to Mr. Saban for the assets.
The auction for ProSiebenSat.1 followed the bankruptcy last year of Leo Kirch, a legendary German media mogul who started his empire by buying the German rights to the Fellini film "La Strada." He amassed one of the most valuable film and television libraries in Europe. 
Mr. Kirch's overly ambitious expansion into pay television left him deep in debt to German banks, including Commerzbank and the HVB Group. The auction of his assets, conducted amid one of the worst advertising downturns in postwar German history, has been tortuous.
Mr. Saban, a deal maker who sold his children's entertainment company to Walt Disney and now runs a media investment firm, emerged as an unlikely inheritor of Mr. Kirch's empire.

HEADLINE: Out of the Boat, Into the Condo; 
On Changing L.I. Sound, Waterfront Homes Crowd Out Marinas

BYLINE:  By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
On either side of Evers Marina, in the Bronx on Long Island Sound's western edge, new town houses line up toward the water like penguins marching to the surf. A mile-long stretch of waterfront that only a few years ago had four marinas full of bobbing boats and clanking halyards now has just this one last yard, and one last owner -- Charles Evers, a gruff 60-year-old Bronx native, who, at least for now, is staying put.
 Mr. Evers is unapologetic that one day he, too, will throw in his hand, sell out to a developer, and leave the daily toil of the yard behind. 
 "When I'm done, that's it," he said. "I'll make twice as much money with condos, anyway." 
Long Island Sound, which begins its great arc toward New England from these urban shores -- or ends its arc south, depending on one's point of view -- is cleaner now, scientists say, than it has been in generations. The fishing can be spectacular, even from the concrete fringe of the Bronx. Wade in waist deep, and you can actually see your feet. But that positive change in the water -- largely the result of a sprawling, multifaceted process of environmental management over the last two decades -- is now beginning to fundamentally alter how the land works as well.
The formula is as unsentimental as a variable rate mortgage: the location got better. That makes the land more valuable, and the more valuable use -- waterfront homes in the Spencer Estates section near Pelham Bay Park sell for upwards of $700,000 -- is winning out over the gritty old boatyards that defined how generations of residents connected to the water.
"We found a niche," said Peter Serpico, a co-owner of Cava Construction, which completed 24 two-family homes next to Evers Marina in April, its first big waterfront development -- named, aptly, for the marina it replaced: Sunrise.
"The improvement of the Sound has a lot to do with it," Mr. Serpico said.
Five hundred or so marinas dot the 548-mile coast of the Sound, most of them small, family-owned businesses like Evers Marina, which was founded as a seaplane base in the 1930's by Mr. Evers's father, Carl. They are far more than just places to park or launch boats, cultural historians and planners say. On an estuary with few sandy beaches, because of geology, and limited access to the water, because of politics and history, the yards have been conduit and connector, a shaper of the Long Island Sound experience.
The small-scale nature of the yards made the Sound what it was, a home to eccentric, individual places that remain for the most part as local as the neighborhoods and towns they serve. 
"There's a culture of being independent going back hundreds of years," said Wilbur Woods, the director ofthe waterfront division at the New York City Department of Planning. "And now as they come into modern times, they're getting picked off."
Many of these places, like Evers Marina, are not fancy.
Don't imagine yachts and investment bankers in Topsiders and Vuarnet sunglasses sipping cocktails on the shaded promenade. That Long Island Sound exists, but not here. Think instead of rust and paint and machine oil, and chains and winches and ropes and piles of broken propellers, the collected evidence of age and the sea. Think of retired firefighters and schoolteachers, painting their own small boats, and old salts like Ed McKee, a 75-year-old former carpenter better known as Scooby Dooby for the shout he said he always makes when landing a big fish. Scooby spends most afternoons these days dozing on his boat, which has no sail to take him anywhere, anyway. 
The big fiberglass dome that Charles Evers spends most of his time in at the yard is fairly unusual too. Only a few were ever built, by an inventor in New Jersey who imagined making his fortune selling them to ski resorts in South America. Mr. Evers bought his for a few hundred dollars 30 years ago at a bankruptcy sale when the South American market somehow didn't boom.
"This place is Charlie-land -- it's unique in all the world," said Robert Meredith, an artist who has lived in a converted airplane hangar at the yard for the last year, at Mr. Evers's invitation. Mr. Meredith repairs boats by day -- he is one of the best fiberglass-men in the business, according to Mr. Evers -- and paints by night: canvases filled with exotic, detailed images of birds and foliage that owe nothing, he said, to the real world of the Sound outside his window.
Certainly, there is still a boating business on the Sound. Mr. Evers, in particular, has benefited from the demise of his neighbors. His 150 slips are filled. But marine industry experts say the future is likely to include amenities that Evers Marina lacks, like, say, food. Mr. Evers has no employees, no store and no regular repair shop. He said a man comes to the yard in the summer to sell sandwiches and hot dogs, but he tends to drift in and out at his own hours and only then in the afternoons.
"He's a waste," Mr. Evers said.
The industry is also consolidating, with bigger and better-financed operators buying out the mom-and-pop yards and sprucing them up. The cost and complexity of complying with environmental regulations, especially harbor dredging, has soared, owners say. Many marina owners are also participating in the collective makeover. In Connecticut, yard owners helped the state write a new set of management rules, called Clean Marinas, which take effect this spring, aimed at standardizing good environmental practices. Participants in the program get to fly a Clean Marina flag.
At Evers Marina, an untamed if not quite anarchic spirit was established from the beginning by Carl Evers, a swashbuckling sailor and pioneer aviator who, according to his son, smuggled rum from Cuba during Prohibition, briefly owned a diamond mine in South America, and taught Katharine Hepburn how to fly -- supposedly so she could finagle a meeting with the charming and elusive aviator Howard Hughes, who was one of Mr. Evers's occasional flying partners. The elder Mr. Evers died in 1994 in his early 90's, and had gone to Europe just the year before with his 24-year-old girlfriend, his son said.
Urban planners say that one of the problems in saving the yards like this is that their prickly, independent nature is not conducive to the kind of group action thatgets political results. Over all, the Sound loses one or two marinas every year, according to marine trade groups, with most of those losses in recent years concentrated in and around New York City. Marina jobs, never a big economic force, since employing one's son or brother is not even counted, have followed that pattern of slow hemorrhage. The Bronx had all of 56 paid marina employees in late 2000, according to the New York State Department of Labor. Last year it had 36.
But Mr. Evers said that help staying in business was the last thing he wanted, anyway. His greatest fear, he said, is that the city will follow the lead of towns like Mamaroneck in Westchester County and all along the Connecticut shore, where state coastal management regulations make it harder to simply close up and sell out without addressing issues of public access to the water. In the Bronx, commercial zoning makes a conversion to residential development as simple as filing for a building permit.
And all of that leaves people like Jerry Weitzenkorn with a dwindling set of options. On a recent evening at Evers Marina, Mr. Weitzenkorn, 67, was sprawled under his 27-year-old sailboat named "Was Noch," (German for What Else) painting the bottom sky blue. Paint spattered his clothes and his white beard. He grumbled to himself that he should have sanded before painting this year, but he kept on painting anyway.
"This is my third boatyard in four years, and I'm not alone -- virtually it's happening to everybody," he said. "Guys in this boatyard are already shopping for other places whenever this place is going to close."
Mr. Weitzenkorn, a retired Bronx native who worked as a security supervisor at the New York City Board of Education, says that if and when Evers Marina closes, he will look elsewhere in the Bronx first -- perhaps City Island. But many of the yards there are closing as well, he said. North in Westchester County, his slip rental rates would be far higher. Going south to Queens would mean fighting the traffic over the Throgs Neck Bridge on weekends. With fewer marinas, he also worries that he could not sell his boat anyway, since the next owner would have the same problem of finding a place to keep it. 
At Evers, that nagging question of time haunts just about every conversation: what's next? Or, as Mr. Weitzenkorn might say, what else?
Mr. Meredith, who had been living on a boat until Mr. Evers gave him a place to live, says he believes and hopes he can produce great art. "God willing," he said, "if I can hang in here a couple more years." 
But a deep connection with nature, the cumulative institutional memory of the thousands of journeys on the water that have been launched from this one little place over the decades, persists. 
Mr. Evers, who has been flying since age 9, and he still keeps his four-seater sea plane in the yard, is a student of the sky. He can gauge the upper air visibility by eyeing the radio tower across the water near City Island. And storms, he said, almost always give you some warning if you're careful. On a recent afternoon, the sun was shining and a breeze was blowing from the north. The weather forecast had indicated an approaching system, but there seemed little evidence of it yet.
Mr. Evers stood for a few minutes, gazing in the direction of the wind, as the yard bustled around him, seemingly oblivious.
"The front's coming in," he said. Then he turned and walked back up the pier.

Human Nature
Over many years of settlement, Long Island Sound has been a breadbasket and a dumping ground, a private playground for the wealthy and a symbol of environmental despair.
But when people reached for a new definition -- a repaired, restored, managed Sound -- nature did not respond according to the rulebook.
For every push to achieve a certain end, the whorls of the ecosystem have pushed right back, often in unexpected ways.
This is the second of a summer-long series of articles on the evolving nature of Long Island Sound. The third article will follow scientists gathered in New London, Conn., this weekend for the first Long Island Sound BioBlitz. Over 24 hours, they will gauge the shore's biodiversity and hope for the brass ring: finding a new species.
Additional materials, including a preview of the remainder of the series, can be found on the Web at nytimes.com/lisound.

HEADLINE: 94% of School Budgets Pass, Most of Them More Expensive 

BYLINE:  By GREG WINTER 

 BODY:
Undeterred by the prospect of higher taxes, New York State voters overwhelmingly approved increases in school spending, according to election results released yesterday. 
 Ninety-four percent of the nearly 700 school districts that put their budgets before the voters on Tuesday won approval for them. The passage rate is one of the highest on record, stunning many school officials who had expected far greater reluctance from a public already facing higher state and local taxes. 
 "If I had a choice, I don't think I'd have the voting date two days after a state sales tax increase takes effect," said Robert Lowry, associate director of the New York State Council of School Superintendents. "But that makes it all the more remarkable that this has happened." 
The sweeping approvals mean that, with few exceptions, school budgets will go up by an average of 4.1 percent in the coming academic year, all at a time when the state's contribution to education has shrunk, according to an analysis by the State Council of School Superintendents. 
Much of the growth in school spending comes in categories that the schools lament as being beyond their control: more money for pensions to make up for the sluggish stock market, double-digit increases in health insurance premiums, and higher gas and energy prices. 
To pay for them, school districts will typically raise local property taxes by 7.4 percent, the council's analysis shows, and this week's election effectively granted them the authority to do so. 
State officials admit to scratching their heads over why voters seemed so willing to take on more of the burden during tough economic times, when the Legislature and a majority of counties have already imposed tax increases of their own. 
School budgets almost always fare well at the polls in New York, but at a considerably lower approval rate than this year. The average over the last 30 years is 82 percent and the rate has very rarely been above 90 percent.
Some assert that Gov. George E. Pataki's proposal to cut education spending by more than $1.2 billion this year probably prompted supporters, and the public at large, to rally to its defense. 
Even after the Legislature restored about $1 billion of that money during a protracted battle with the governor, schools are still likely to receive about $185 million less from the state than they did this year, despite rising expenses.
To drive that message home, school boards across the state spent the last few weeks blitzing their constituents with the message that the Legislature's actions, welcome though they were, did not put an end to the financial dilemma.
"We didn't consciously set out to create this impression, but there was some sympathy generated for school districts throughout this six-month saga," said David Ernst, director of research for the New York State School Boards Association. 
Except for a few cities that leave the parrying over school budgets to mayors and city councils -- most noticeably New York City, Yonkers, Rochester, Syracuse and Buffalo -- school districts across the state are required to win voter approval for any substantial increases in their budgets. The votes do not apply to these large cities, often labeled the "Big Five," in which school spending is subsumed by the larger, municipal budget process. 
Elsewhere in the state, however, the approvals covered a broad swath of terrain. All the districts around the capital, for instance, won endorsements for their budgets. The same was true for Rockland County, while in Dutchess County only one district rejected its budget. All but a few school districts in Westchester and Long Island also received approvals, putting an abrupt end to the worries of state officials who expected a fair amount of confusion and resentment among voters. 
"People are saying here, 'We've got some momentum going in our district. We don't want that momentum interrupted, even when it shows up in my property taxes,' " Mr. Ernst said.
The districts rejecting budgets were scattered across the state, with the largest concentrations in Orange, Ulster, Chautauqua and Cattaraugus Counties, as well as several more in eastern Suffolk and Nassau. 

CORRECTION-DATE: June 9, 2003

 CORRECTION:

Although budgets were approved in all districts that the State Education Department lists in its Capital Region, one was rejected in Troy, which abuts Albany but is considered part of a separate region.

HEADLINE: Windmills Sow Dissent For Environmentalists 

BYLINE:  By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: THOMAS, W.Va. 

 BODY:
Vincent Collins, a lawyer from nearby Morgantown, has been vacationing in this scenic area for 35 years. A few years ago, he bought a 1.2-acre lot near here and planned to build a house on it. But once he saw the windmills, and learned of plans for more, he scrapped that dream.
 Soaring above the treetops are 44 sleek white steel cylinders, 228 feet high. Churning on each tower are three glinting fiberglass blades, 115 feet long. Like quills on a porcupine, they spike the emerald spine of Backbone Mountain for six miles along the Allegheny Front. 
 They have also generated huge turbulence within the environmental movement. Proponents of wind farms view those who oppose them as heretics, obstructing the promise of clean renewable energy, while opponents decry them as producing insufficient power to warrant their blight on the landscape. 
For now, the wind farm here is the largest east of the Mississippi, but the wind-energy industry, long a staple of the California landscape, is blowing eastward. Unobstructed winds, favorable economics and the absence of local zoning laws are attracting developers, and soon more than 400 turbines could be sprouting across 40 square miles of West Virginia's most scenic mountaintops.
"I can't believe how large and hideous they are," Mr. Collins said. "When you hear the word 'windmill,' you think Holland and Don Quixote. That's wrong. They look like alien monsters coming out of the ground."
The growing industry has caused a kind of identity crisis among people who think of themselves as pro-environment, forcing them to choose between the promise of clean, endlessly renewable energy and the perils of imposing giant man-made structures on nature.
To some environmentalists, the opposition to wind power from within their ranks not only stifles the growth of a new source of energy but also calls into question the integrity of the environmental movement itself.
Charles Komanoff, a longtime economic consultant to environmental groups, said the opposition by "well-heeled environmentalists," stoked the preconception that they were more concerned about their own backyards than about the common good.
"They want to have it all and they won't brook any trade-off, especially a trade-off that sacrifices their own comfort," said Mr. Komanoff, who is based in New York.
At the same time, the wind farm developers appear to have the environmental high ground.
"We believe in clean energy," said Steve Stingel, a spokesman for Florida Power and Light, which bought the rights to the wind farm here and then built it. The company is the largest generator of wind power in the United States, with 30 wind farms in 10 states.
Wind now accounts for less than 1 percent of all electricity produced in the United States. But the American Wind Energy Association, the industry's trade group, predicts it will grow to 6 percent by 2020. 
The case for wind has been fortified in recent years by advances in technology that make it more efficient and a federal tax credit that makes its financing more feasible.
But the reality for people like Mr. Collins is something else. Windmill farms must be large to be financially viable. Critics worry that beyond the blemish on the natural landscape, these industrial-sized towers can chop up migratory birds. One farm in California was dubbed the "condor Cuisinart," and the ornithologist monitoring the wind farm here just reported that at least two dozen song birds winging their way north had been killed.
Another complaint is that wind farms can do little to reduce overall dependence on fossil fuels, because of the unreliability of constant wind and the inability to store its power.
"They put out such a minuscule amount of electricity," Mr. Collins said. "It's nuts." 
Similar complaints, coming from prominent environmentalists like Robert F. Kennedy Jr., have stalled installation of the nation's first off-shore wind farm, proposed for the waters of Nantucket Sound off Cape Cod. And they have forced the Long Island Power Authority to scrap its plan for wind turbines off the eastern tip of Long Island. But the utility has now proposed putting up to 50 turbines, each 488 feet high, off Long Island's south shore between Fire Island and Jones Beach, two immensely popular summer resort areas.
Mr. Kennedy, for one, said he found "zero" irony in the fact that he had devoted himself to environmental advocacy and yet opposed the wind project on Cape Cod, his Kennedy grandparents' summer home.
"There are appropriate places for everything," he said in a telephone interview. "You would not want a wind farm in Yosemite, and you wouldn't want one in Central Park."
Mr. Kennedy added: "I love wind energy, but let's develop some rules about how you divide up the commons. You're essentially giving the commons over to a profit-making enterprise."
It is not only homeowners with nice views who object to wind farms, but business owners as well. Indeed, it was Wayne Kurker, owner of the Hyannis Marina, who first notified Mr. Kennedy about the proposed project in Nantucket Sound.
"I didn't like the idea that what we consider our Grand Canyon was all of a sudden going to be industrialized," Mr. Kurker said of the wind farm, which would consist of 130 turbines over 24 square miles.
Mr. Kurker founded the Alliance to Protect Nantucket Sound and has been joined by scores of local politicians, chambers of commerce worried about the effect on tourism, and celebrities like Walter Cronkite in opposition to the project.
The main reason wind is taking off now is the huge financial incentive provided by government subsidies. While critics argue that these subsidies are only making developers rich, supporters say they are peanuts compared with subsidies for fossil fuels and they provide much-needed revenue to ailing rural economies while also delivering clean energy.
The main subsidy is the federal tax credit, which is set to expire at the end of the year but is likely to be renewed by Congress. The credit allows windmill companies to deduct 1.8 cents from their tax liability for every kilowatt hour they produce for 10 years. The savings are huge.
For example, Jerome Niessen, president of NedPower, which has received permission from the West Virginia Public Service Commission for a 200-turbine wind farm near here in Grant County, said he expected to generate 800 million kilowatt hours per year, for a tax savings of $16 million a year for 10 years, or $160 million -- on a wind farm that will cost $300 million to build.
NedPower is to pay $500,000 in local taxes, making it the fifth-largest taxpayer in the county. (That is far less, however, than the $3 million the company would have paid just two years ago, before wind energy lobbyists persuaded the government to tax towers and turbines at a lower rate.) The company has also developed a public-private partnership with two local schools, which will earn royalties from the wind farm of about $75,000 a year.
The company will pay local landowners $2,000 to $4,000 an acre to lease the necessary 8,000 acres for the towers. And putting up the towers, which will rise 330 feet high and extend across 10 to 12 miles of mountain ridges, will provide 200 construction jobs for a year and 15 permanent technician jobs.
"Fifteen jobs might not sound like much," Mr. Niessen said. "But if one coal mine after another has closed and if another chicken-processing plant has closed, 15 jobs is a lot."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Economic Report Sends Dow Above 9,000

BYLINE:  By ALEX BERENSON 

 BODY:
The three-month rally in stocks gained new strength yesterday, as a positive economic report sent the Dow Jones industrial average above 9,000 for the first time since August. 
 The gloom that gripped Wall Street this winter, when investors fled stocks amid fears of terrorist attacks and a long war in Iraq, seems to have dissipated. Since March, the Dow average has gained more than 20 percent and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index has risen almost 25 percent. The Nasdaq composite index has soared even more, increasing 29 percent. 
 Yesterday, all three gauges gained more than 1 percent, after the Institute for Supply Management, a group of purchasing managers, said that banks, retailers andother service companies had grown more strongly in May than economists had predicted.
Some skeptical investors say that this spring's rally is based more on hope, and the low interest rates provided by the Federal Reserve and other central banks around the world, than on any solid evidence of an economic upturn. 
In addition, many of the biggest gainers have been highly speculative stocks, like money-losing biotechnology companies that are years from turning profitable. The interest in speculative names is a sign that the rally is unsustainable, the bears warn.
"I don't like the action that's happened," said Charles L. Hill, research director of Thomson First Call, which compiles analysts' profit estimates. "It's too much too fast in the tech area, when there's nothing to support it."
But Mr. Hill's view is the minority. A potent mix of financial and political factors will probably quicken economic growth and drive corporate earnings strongly higher over the next several months, the bulls say.
Oil prices have fallen about 25 percent since early March, giving consumers and businesses more disposable income. In the last year, the dollar has weakened by more than 30 percent against the euro, allowing United States manufacturers to compete more easily with their European counterparts. United States and British troops won the war in Iraq without major casualties and there have been no terrorist attacks in the United States since the war began.
At the same time, the dividend tax cut that was signed into law last week has increased the attractiveness of dividend-paying stocks relative to bonds. And the federal budget deficit could be close to $400 billion this year.
In the long run, big government deficits raise the cost of capital for private businesses, but in the short term, with private demand weak, rising deficits are an important short-term economic boost.
"There's a lot of stimulus that has been put through," said Bob Maneri, who follows banks and financial services companies for Victory Capital Management, which oversees $60 billion. 
Mr. Maneri said that credit problems at most banks appeared to peak this winter and that demand for business loans seemed to have increased at banks that serve smaller companies.
"You're hearing pockets of middle-market small business that are starting to turn up," he said. Still, loan demand at big companies remains soft, he warned.
The Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, has said that he is worried about the risk of deflation, or a general decrease in prices, and that to keep the economy growing, he would keep interest rates low and credit easily available. Despite the enormous deficits, the 10-year Treasury note now yields a mere 3.29 percent, making stocks -- even those that do not pay dividends -- an increasingly attractive alternative for investors.
Yesterday, after the Institute for Supply Management report, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 116.03 points, or 1.3 percent, to 9,038.98. The S.& P. 500 index gained 14.68 points, or 1.5 percent, to 986.24.
The S.& P. 500 is now within striking distance of 1,000; it last attained that level in June of last year. The Nasdaq gained 31.09 points, or 1.9 percent, to 1,634.65.
Retailers and banks led the gains. Wal-Mart, the world's biggest company, rose $1.01, to $53.86. Citigroup gained 77 cents, to $43.02, and J. P. Morgan Chase rose 87 cents, to $34.69. Technology companies also showed strength, with Dell Computer rising 70 cents, to $31.70, and Oracle gaining 56 cents, to $13.58.
"The Dow above 9,000 definitely puts a smile on my face," said Lee A. Scundi, an associate at Stevenson Capital Management, which oversees $200 million. "A couple of months ago, with the Iraq conflict," he said, "there were too many variables on the table. I think investors are starting to look six months down the road and seeing a clearer picture with less variables."
But the skeptics, who include some of Wall Street's most respected investors, remain unconvinced. The rally has been fueled mainly by low interest rates, not economic growth, said William H. Gross, who oversees $300 billion in bond investments for Pacific Investment Management.
"There's been a lot of liquidity provided by our central bank, the Japanese central bank, the European central bank," he said. "The world is awash with funds, and the alternative to not taking the risk is having returns of less than 1 percent."
With rates so low, the recent rally is understandable, Mr. Gross said. But to justify the gains, the economy will have to perform almost perfectly over the next year, with solid growth and almost no inflation, he said. If growth is too slow, the economy may fall into deflation, which leads to even slower growth and will be very hard to reverse once it begins. But if growth is stronger than expected and inflation rises, the Federal Reserve may have to raise interest rates quickly, badly hurting consumers, who as a group are heavily indebted.
"I'm still of the mind that we have a bear market in front of us once this funny money explodes," Mr. Gross said.

Treasury Prices Rise
(By The Associated Press) -- Bond prices rose yesterday, sending yields to new lows even as stocks soared on news of positive economic reports.
The 10-year Treasury note rose 10/32, to a price of 102 25/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 3.29 percent from 3.33 percent on Tuesday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond gained 8/32, to 116 10/32. The bond's yield dipped to 4.36 percent from 4.37 percent.

HEADLINE: ONLINE SHOPPER; 
Cocktail Season on the Virtual Terrace

BYLINE:  By Michelle Slatalla; E-mail: Slatalla@nytimes.com

 BODY:
WHEN I moved last year to Northern California, where the weather is so nice that everyone lives outdoors, it seemed cruel that my house had a backyard barely bigger than a yoga mat.
 But after I started to understand local culture, it made perfect sense. Here there's so much communal open space that you get exhausted from constant forays to hike, bike, swim, ski, kayak or play tennis. The last thing anybody needs is a big yard to mow. 
 Instead, the houses in my neighborhood specialize in outdoor rooms. My house has so many doors opening onto little porches and patios and balconies that the place resembles an Advent calendar.
 Last week, as we headed into summer, the biggest challenge I faced was to furnish the big, sunny balcony on the front of the house. (Yes, I hate me too sometimes.) After consultation with my husband, who agreed that the best use of the space would be for drinking gin and tonics while thumbing through glossy magazines, I took a sensible approach: two chaise longues.
 The obvious solution to this problem was to buy online. It was time to buck the conventional wisdom of all those naysayers who for years predicted that most shoppers would never be comfortable buying furniture online without actually seeing it and touching it first.
 I'm certainly not the first brave shopper to say that this is malarkey. One of the fastest-growing segments of online sales is the home, office and garden category, which includes furniture, and it is expected to reach $10.6 billion this year, up about 40 percent from $7.5 billion in 2002, according to a recent www.shop.org study conducted by Forrester Research. 
 Common sense is all you need to explain the growth. When it comes to large, bulky items like furniture, of course shoppers would prefer a better selection, easy price comparisons and guaranteed speedy delivery to their doorsteps. 
 Outdoor furniture, in particular, is an obvious place to start. For one thing, the risk is relatively low. Because of its lower price and seasonal nature, a chaise isn't as big a commitment as, say, a living room sofa that I would have to look at every day for the next 10 years. 
 The seasonal aspect limits selection in bricks-and-mortar stores. Retailers don't want to devote a lot of precious display space to large items that will only sell well for a few months each year. It makes more sense to store those items in cheaper warehouse space and display pictures online. Target, for instance, last week offered the Kensington aluminum bistro table ($99.99) and a set of two matching folding chairs ($99.99) at its Web site (www.target.com) but not in its stores.
 Even traditional mail-order merchants are more likely to show larger selections of furniture at their Web sites than in their paper catalogs. "The catalog's expensive to print, so we use that as an introduction to customers, to tell them to shop online," said Mike Bibbey, director of e-commerce for Direct Marketing Services, which operates the home furnishings site www.homevisions.com. "We sell a lot more outdoor furniture online than through the catalog."
 Nowadays most sites let you examine furniture from various angles and in room settings. You can get the exact dimensions, see which chairs coordinate with a particular table, then confirm whether the items are in stock and ready to ship. (Shipping charges can be substantial, particularly for bulky items; check before you buy.) By the end of 2002, 61 percent of merchant sites offered a zoom feature, up from 47 percent the prior year, according to a survey of 100 sites by the the E-Tailing Group, an e-commerce consultant company.
 "Anything that helps people visualize how the furniture actually will look at home is the sort of feature that sites are adding," said Lauren Freedman, the E-tailing Group president. "People want to see how a chair operates, how an umbrella works, which cushion fabrics are available."
 At two sites, for example, I found similar polyvinyl chaise longues. At HomeVisions.com, the chaise ("sturdy resin construction") was $69.99, plus $39.99 for a cushion. At domestications.com, a similar "resin" chaise was $59.99, plus $24.99 for a matching cushion. 
 By zooming in at both sites, I was able to compare the chairs side by side onscreen to determine that they were nearly identical.
 Some sites, like www.llbean.com, have taken this concept of enhanced features to a much higher level. The product page for the three-season wicker loveseat glider ($879) told me about materials, the protective finish and maintenance requirements ("to clean, just hose and wipe off"). But that was just the beginning.
 When I clicked on "InDepth," a window appeared in which I could mix and match four furniture colors with six different cushion fabrics. Plus, I could zoom in on the wicker for a closer view of those "fibrous strands" that were "wrapped around aluminum for added strength and durability."
 Never mind that I wasn't in the market for a loveseat glider (wouldn't a gin and tonic be in danger of sloshing?). After about 10 minutes of playing around, I caught myself agonizing over which cushions to pair with the red loveseat, frantically clicking back and forth from the denim stripe to the green.
 Another benefit of the seasonal nature of outdoor furniture is that it goes on sale quickly. Retailers don't want to be stuck with it all winter. For those among us who admire Martha Stewart's design sense -- and really, who doesn't? -- there were tempting markdowns last week. At her high-end www.marthastewart.com site, selected pieces in last year's slate gray color were on sale (woven garden table, marked down from $910 to $745). And at www.kmart.com, which sells her cheaper Everyday line, the Victoria chaise longue was marked down from $149.99 to $135.99.
 By then I was gravitating toward wooden steamer chairs (attractive lines, folds for storage). A search at bizrate.com turned up many candidates, including a teak chair at kruppsdecor.com ($684), a cheaper teak chair at stacksandstacks.com ($249)and a cheapest teak chair at www.overstock.com ($169.99). Sticking to my "low risk" theory, I chose the cheapest option (Overstock.com had a reassuring close-up view of shiny brass hardware fittings and charged only $2.95 for shipping).
 The summer is shaping up nicely. I still need a little table to hold drinks. The gin, I have.

HEADLINE: WHAT'S NEXT; 
Storage Methods Come and Go, but Tape Holds Its Own

BYLINE:  By IAN AUSTEN 

 BODY:
WHEN it comes to storing data, magnetic tape would seem to represent the past, not the future. The basic technology is half a century old, and those rooms full of reel-to-reel tape machines that were once a symbol of computing power are all but gone. 
 But corporations around the world still spend billions of dollars annually on tape cartridges that whirl away, backing up data. While the declining cost of hard drives, optical technologies like DVD's, and research into new storage methods like holography are all potential threats to tape, few storage experts are predicting its demise. "I've been asked if tape will disappear for a long time," said Gordon F. Hughes, the associate director of the Center for Magnetic Recording Research at the University of California at San Diego. "But I fundamentally don't think it's any different than the idea that radio will be pushed out by television." 
 Some researchers, in fact, are doing their best to make sure that tape will never go the way of the dinosaurs by looking at ways to store even more data on it. While at some laboratories this involves the development of new coatings or new drive technologies, for scientists at Ohio State University the solution literally involves smoothing out a tape's rough edges. They are looking at the manufacturing process, working to eliminate irregular edges so they can squeeze more data tracks onto each length of tape.
 Increasing capacity can help reinforce what has always been one of tape's strong points: it is an economical form of data storage in comparison with other methods like hard-disk drives and optical technologies like DVD's. 
 But Dr. Hughes, whose work focuses on hard-drive technologies, said that today, "there's serious cost pressure on tape." 
 While making cost comparisons can be an arcane exercise, Dr. Hughes said that ordinary personal computer hard drives can be less expensive than tape for some short-term storage systems.
 Tape also suffers from a practical shortcoming: unlike the data on a hard drive or optical disc, the information on it is arranged in linear form. A tape has to be wound backward and forward to retrieve or record data, making it slower in operation. 
 But Saurin Shah, the director of advanced technology and applications at Imation, which makes tapes and other storage media, said that tape has benefited from increased concern about protecting data from terrorist attack or natural disasters. It's easier to take a tape cartridge with backed-up data to a secure warehouse than it is to take a hard drive.
 "The ability to send it off-site for storage, that's a key feature for tape," Mr. Shah said. 
 Imation, formerly a part of 3M (which made the first magnetic data tapes), still churns out a small amount of tape in the original reel-to-reel format. But most data tape today comes in plastic cartridges that are roughly the size of a jewel case designed to hold two music CD's. At many corporate data centers, the feeding of blank tapes into drives and their subsequent retrieval and storage is handled by robots. 
 The most advanced tape cartridges hold 200 gigabytes of data. One reason so much electronic material can fit into a relatively small space is that the tape is extremely thin. "Think of it as coated Saran Wrap," Mr. Shah said. 
 Another factor that helps create more capacity is the large number of tracks of data that are squeezed onto the half-inch wide tape. A 200-gigabyte cartridge may use as many as 576 tracks. (To speed the recording of all those tracks, most tape drives have several small recording heads that operate simultaneously.) 
 A paper in the April issue of Tribology Letters (tribology is the study of friction, lubrication and wear) by Bharat Bhushan, a professor at Ohio State, and a graduate student, Anton Goldade, suggests that changing the way tapes are made may be one way to fit even more tracks onto tapes. 
 Dr. Bhushan, who was previously a storage researcher at I.B.M., and Mr. Goldade developed techniques and devices for measuring the straightness of tape edges and the wear caused by running them through drives. With those tools, the researchers found that the edges were not true to begin with and get worse over time. "The edge of the tape has variation of fairly high frequency," said Dr. Bhushan. 
 Tape drives avoid the problems caused by irregular edges by leaving the area near the tape's edges blank. But to go much beyond the current 200-gigabyte capacity, developers will not have the luxury of leaving some of the tape's real estate untouched. "As you start adding more tracks to the tape, the tracks will get closer to the edge of the tape," Dr. Bhushan said. 
 Jagged edges are universal among brands of tape and are largely the result of the way they are manufactured. The magnetic coatings are applied onto sheets of plastic that are, in Imation's case, 25 inches or 30 inches wide. Final tape sizes are created by slitting the bulk rolls with rotating razor-sharp blades.
 Imation tried replacing the blades with a laser. "But it provides a coarser cut than what we can now achieve," Mr. Shah said. 
 When he was at I.B.M., Dr. Bhushan said, researchers tried to chop up the bulk rolls by cooling them to extremely low temperatures before snapping off smaller pieces. "But it's terribly expensive," he said. 
 Instead, the solution may lie in refining current technologies. Some researchers at Dr. Bhushan's labare studying the slitting process in an attempt to discover possible improvements. Others are looking into new plastics that might cut more cleanly. 
 Sharper blades, of course, won't be all it takes for tapes to significantly boost their capacity. Imation is studying whether the high-vacuum evaporation system that is used to coat hard drive discs could be adapted for tapes. That would allow the development of new tape coatings that could hold more data.
 O-Mass, a Norwegian company controlled by Tandberg Data and partly owned by Imation, is developing a new kind of tape drive. Among other things, it should allow an exceptionally high number of tracks by using laser light to read magnetic tapes. 
 Dr. Bhushan, whose research is partly financed by Imation, has little time for suggestions that tape's time has passed. In fact, he predicts that tape drives will still be spinning when other current technologies are gathering dust. 
 "Our estimate is that tape will outlive hard drives," he said.

HEADLINE: THE PRESIDENT'S TRIP: OVERSEERS; 
U.S. Group to Monitor 2 Sides on Mideast Peace Moves

BYLINE:  By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: AQABA, Jordan, June 4 

 BODY:
The Bush administration said today that it would soon send a team of monitors to the Middle East to help the Israelis and Palestinians meet their obligations under Mr. Bush's peace plan and to publicize instances in which they fall short. 
 Mr. Bush said he had chosen John S. Wolf, assistant secretary of state for nonproliferation, to head the monitoring team, which will consist solely of Americans in at least its early phases. 
 "This mission will be charged with helping the parties to move toward peace, monitoring their progress and stating clearly who was fulfilling their responsibilities," Mr. Bush said, after a day of meetings with the prime ministers of Israel and the Palestinian Authority in this Red Sea port town. "And we expect both parties to keep their promises."
Administration officials offered few details about the team or its mission -- or even when it would arrive in the region -- saying it was still being assembled in the United States. But they said it would be relatively small -- about 10 people or so -- and consist mainly of intelligence officials and diplomats. Senior officials have said the team is likely to be based in Jerusalem, but they said that could change.
Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said Mr. Wolf was notified of his new assignment two weeks ago and would arrive in the region "very soon."
He said the American ambassador to Israel, Daniel C. Kurtzer, and the acting consul general, Jeffrey Feltman, would play major roles in helping oversee the monitors. "We're going to have a very strong team here," Mr. Powell told reporters as he prepared to leave Aqaba with Mr. Bush for Doha, Qatar.
The Palestinians have long argued for international observers, saying that only outside monitors can hold Israel accountable to the world for its promises to withdraw from certain occupied territories.
"We welcome and stress the need for the assistance of the international community and, in particular, the Arab states, to help us," said Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian prime minister. "We also welcome and stress the need for a U.S.-led monitoring mechanism."
Israeli officials, on the other hand, have resisted the idea of monitors, saying they would infringe on Israel's sovereignty and its right to defend its citizens. To win Israeli support, the Bush administration promised that all the monitors would be Americans, at least initially. But senior American officials have not foreclosed the possibility of adding to the group monitors from Western Europe or Russia, whose governments helped develop the peace plan, known as the road map. 
"It is an understanding between the United States and Israel that the only party that has proven an honest broker in the peace process is the United States," said Raanan Gissin, a foreign affairs adviser to Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel.
In Mr. Wolf, Mr. Bush selected a 33-year veteran of the Foreign Service who has worked in Australia, Vietnam, Greece and Pakistan. A graduate of Dartmouth College, he was ambassador to Malaysia from 1992 to 1995 and ambassador for Asia-Pacific economic cooperation from 1997 until 1999.
Some Middle East diplomats have raised questions about Mr. Wolf's lack of experience in the region. But administration officials and some outside experts said he had been effective in overseeing compliance with international nonproliferation agreements -- experience that will serve him well in pressing the Israelis and Palestinians to live up to their road map obligations, they said. 
Some experts have also raised questions about whether a dozen or so monitors will be enough to oversee what is expected to be a highly contentious and drawn-out process. Senior administration officials have already lowered expectations for the team, saying Mr. Wolf will not play the prominent role of Middle East envoy, as former Senator George J. Mitchell did for President Clinton.
Middle East analysts said it was wise of the Bush administration to avoid appointing a high-profile envoy. "Better not to have big names with great expectations," said Judith Kipper, director for the Middle East Forum at the Council on Foreign Relations. "You need a professional team working on this seven days a week, on the ground really attending to getting the thing implemented, without big names at press conferences and great fanfare. This is really nitty-gritty stuff."

HEADLINE: OLYMPICS; 
3 Networks Left Vying for Rights

BYLINE:  By RICHARD SANDOMIR

 BODY:
The International Olympic Committee does not know yet where the 2010 or the 2012 Games will be held, but by the end of this weekend, it will almost certainly know how much an American company will pay for their media rights.
 The auction, the first by the I.O.C. since 1994, could bring as much as $2 billion. The outcome could preserve NBC's status as the Olympic network, which it secured with pre-emptive bids in 1995 for the Olympics from 2000 to 2008 for $3.5 billion. 
 If ABC wins, it would represent a return to the arena the network dominated from the 1960's to the 1980's. A Fox victory would symbolize newfound respect; twice, the I.O.C. shooed Fox from bidding for being too inexperienced, although the Olympic committee was also wary of the network's founder, Rupert Murdoch. 
 The competition features powerful media conglomerates -- General Electric, which owns NBC; the Walt Disney Company, the parent of ABC and ESPN; and the News Corporation, the owner of Fox -- all vying for the American rights to traditional media like broadcast and cable television and radio, and newer technologies, like pay-per-view, video-on-demand, Internet and satellite rights, which are hard to place a value on so far in advance.
 The Olympics are prized because no other programming in sports and entertainment virtually assures prime-time victories for 17 consecutive nights. Each corporation, in its bidding, will have to balance several factors: fiscal prudence against a desire to win, and prestige against the anxiety that war or terrorism could interrupt future Olympics, reducing viewership and diminishing advertiser demand.
 "We're very enthusiastic about this," Dick Glover, the managing director of Olympics for ABC Sports and ESPN, said. "The marriage of brands and assets is very good. The Olympics represent the legacy of ABC Sports, plus, with the ESPN brand, it's a real good fit for us."
 During the sealed bidding at the I.O.C.'s headquarters in Lausanne, Switzerland, will one of the networks, gauging its needs against the others, try to separate itself from the pack by submitting a blowout offer, ending the bidding quickly? 
 "Any bid 5 percent better than any other should be a dead winner," said Barry Frank, who is vice chairman of TWI, the television arm of IMG, the sports marketing firm. Frank is also a consultant to the United States Olympic Committee.
 Neal Pilson, a consultant to the I.O.C. on the bidding for the 2010 and 2012 Games, made a $375 million bid on behalf of CBS to win the rights to the 1998 Winter Games in Nagano, Japan. "The purpose of a pre-emptive bid is to shock and awe," he said, adding that if he had offered less, another network's appetite might have been whetted.
 The potential price tag will be staggering, the most paid for any one or two Olympics, unless a sudden spasm of deflation occurs in Lausanne. CBS, which is owned by Viacom, declared that the anticipated price was too steep and dropped out of the competition on Monday. A fifth company, AOL Time Warner, dropped out last month.
 The three surviving bidders will each make a two-hour presentation to an I.O.C. contingent led by its president, Dr. Jacques Rogge. Today, the ABC/ESPN contingent will face the Olympic group in a conference room named for Baron Pierre de Coubertin, the father of the modern Olympics. Fox and NBC will follow tomorrow.
 Later tomorrow, at 2:30 p.m. Swiss time, all three networks will submit their bids in sealed envelopes -- and await the call for one, two or all three to bid higher. Going higher, of course, might erase estimated profits.
 This week's process appears to be the most organized in the strange history of Olympic bidding. Once, organizing committees in the host countries handled all broadcast negotiations, then began sharing it with the I.O.C. The Olympic committee is now in charge, using a process it deems fair to all sides, a reversal of recent history.
 In 1995, by dealing with only NBC, the Olympic committee enraged CBS, which had wanted to bid and had spent $913 million on the 1992, 1994 and 1998 Winter Olympics. Fox was also angry, believing that it had made its own preemptive $701 million bid to the I.O.C., which was ignored.
 NBC had pledged to bid jointly with ABC for the 2000 Summer Games in Sydney, Australia, said Dick Ebersol, the chairman of NBC Sports, but ultimately, Bob Wright, the president of NBC, did not like the $700 million it would have required for an event outside the United States.
 But then the idea of coupling Sydney with the 2002 Salt Lake Winter Games took hold, with a $1.2 billion price tag. "Bob asked me, 'What's the risk?' then told me I could do it," Ebersol recalled. When the I.O.C. agreed, Ebersol was left to apologize to Dennis Swanson, then the president of ABC Sports, who had been stung two years earlier by his bosses at Capital Cities, who had not allowed him to outbid NBC's $456 million offer for the 1996 Atlanta Summer Games.
 The history of Olympic bidding has been filled with bizarre moments. ABC Sports used an English-speaking German cabdriver to interpret during negotiations to purchase the rights to the 1964 Innsbruck Winter Games. In 1984, ABC believed it would get the TV rights for the 1988 Calgary Winter Games for $275 million, then felt betrayed when it was forced to pay $309 million to outbid NBC. The bidding over the rights for the Calgary Games marked a turning point in the extraordinary spiral of Olympic TV rights fees. The cost to ABC for the 1984 Winter Games in Sarajevo had been $91.5 million. Before the Calgary bidding began, Frank, who was then working for the Calgary organizing committee, suggested that everyone invest a dollar in a pool. Madame Monique Berlioux, the I.O.C.'s executive director, bet the final figure would be $132 million. Frank's wager was $236 million, on the high range. ABC ultimately paid $309 million.
 The I.O.C. will choose the 2010 host city next month in Prague. The leading candidates are Vancouver, British Columbia; Salzburg, Austria; and Pyeongchang, South Korea.
 Still, there could be drama this weekend. The I.O.C. might not sell the rights to the highest bidder, but it might award them to the one with the best plans to promote and cover the two Olympics.
 "Money is the most important element, but it's not the only element," Michael Payne, the I.O.C.'s marketing director, said.
 The Olympic committee might also delay a decision if the offers are disappointingly low and efforts to raise the bids are unavailing. 
 "We can say, 'We'll see you in a year,"' Payne said. "We don't have a gun at our head."

HEADLINE: Planned Job Cuts Declined in May, Survey Says 

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Employers in the United States announced plans in May to cut 68,623 jobs, the smallest number of intended layoffs in 30 months and a sign that the worst round of job losses may be over, a private survey has found. 
 Planned job cuts were down 53.1 percent from the 146,399 announced in April and down 19.2 percent from the 84,978 announced in May 2002, according to Challenger, Gray & Christmas Inc., a placement firm based in Chicago. 
It was the fewest since November 2000, four months before the economy fell into recession. 
 Challenger, Gray released its report on Tuesday.
"The 'missing in action' kick-start that will propel the economy out of the doldrums may be close at hand," said John Challenger, the firm's chief executive. 
In the previous four months, companies announced plans to lay off 502,194 workers. 
The slowdown was led by fewer cuts at government and nonprofit agencies. 
Some of the industries that have led the pack in layoffs over the last few years are showing improvement, according to Challenger. Telecommunications and computer companies announced 54,278 job cuts from January through May, down 67.2 percent from the same period last year.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
Virgin Mobile begins a campaign to make itself the premier wireless company for young people.

BYLINE:  By Nat Ives 

 BODY:
VIRGIN MOBILE USA hopes to jump-start its cellphone business among teenage and young adult customers with a campaign beginning tonight during the MTV Movie Awards.
 The spots, which carry the theme "Live without a plan," will seek to demonstrate that the company truly understands young people, down to the kind of billing plans that they prefer. 
 Brand and telecommunications analysts say they think the effort will be a winner because the youth market feels underserved by the big companies like Verizon Wireless and AT&T Wireless. But they cautioned that Virgin would have to speak consistently and carefully to maintain the loyalty of young people, who are considered fickle. And after committing itself so thoroughly to youth, any expansion into the general market would be difficult. 
"The challenge is in the size of the market," said David Martin, president for the United States at Interbrand in New York, part of the Omnicom Group. "They made a strategic bet and if they niche it too strongly, then they've constrained their growth opportunities."
But such problems seem far off for now for Virgin Mobile USA, a joint venture of the Virgin Group, the British venture capital company founded by Richard Branson, and the Sprint PCS division of Sprint. Despite signing up more than 500,000 subscribers since it began operations in August, the company remains among the smallest in its field.
In-Stat/MDR, a research company that compiled data from the companies, said Verizon Wireless led the field, with 33.3 million users. The next-closest competitors are Cingular Wireless, with 22 million users; AT&T Wireless, with 21.1 million; and Sprint PCS, with 15 million.
In its advertising budget, too, Virgin is playing with giants. Although Virgin would not say what it would spend on the campaign beginning today, the money is coming from about $50 million allocated for marketing this year.
By comparison, Verizon Wireless spent $661 million last year advertising in major media, according to TNS Media Intelligence/CMR, part of Taylor Nelson Sofres.
But Virgin does not need to meet the lofty goals of a Verizon or AT&T, analysts said, and rapid growth may be enough to keep its corporate parents satisfied for now.
The campaign represents the first big push from Virgin since it named a new chief marketing officer in January and a new ad agency three months later. Its inaugural campaign last year was criticized for lacking focus and simplicity.
In the new spots, which are straightforward but are shot with a vivid visual style, young people take orders by remote control and nearly drown in confusing bills until Virgin sets them free with a prepaid billing plan, the only plan it offers.
"Virgin Group operates at its best when it comes into a category that's very loud, very confusing and very consumer unfriendly and offers simplicity," said Howard Handler, the chief marketing officer at Virgin. "We wanted to build this company around a very specific audience that wasn't being addressed properly."
The commercials are scheduled to be broadcast at least through the summer on cable channels like the Cartoon Network, Comedy Central, MTV, Much Music and VH1. The campaign will also have ads on the radio, in theaters before movies and online, as well as some form of television programming for the back-to-school season.
The campaign is intended to find young people when they are watching shows alone or with their friends, in unsupervised moments, said Anne Bologna, who is president at the New York office of Fallon Worldwide, which created the campaign. Fallon is part of the Publicis Groupe.
The credibility of the advertising is greater then than during shows that teenagers might watch with their parents, like "American Idol," she said.
Aiming at young people specifically offers one potentially lucrative way into such a bitterly competitive sector, said Gary Stibel, chief executive at the New England Consulting Group in Westport, Conn. "Everybody else is targeting the mass market," Mr. Stibel said.
In every aspect, Virgin is trying to stand out from the phones-of-your-parents, which have traditionally had names like the 6310i, A2218z or SCH-A530.
Virgin is emphasizing handsets with names like the Party Animal and the Super Model (both made by Kyocera). They sell at Virgin Megastores, of course, as well as chains including Best Buy, Circuit City and Target.
The service includes optional features like a Deep Sea Thought of the Day from SpongeBob SquarePants, the star of an animated series on the Nickelodeon cable channel, and the Rescue Ring, which permits users to arrange to receive a call at a time when an escape might be handy -- say, two hours into a blind date.
But cute gimmicks and tie-ins to MTV content, also a major part of Virgin's plans, will pale in importance compared with transparency and consistency, said Austin McGhie, a managing partner for strategy at the San Francisco office of the Sterling Group, a brand consulting company.
To hold the trust of the young, Virgin must ensure that its claims are accurate and that the attitude in the new campaign is consistently delivered from the company to its young customers.
"These guys sniff out inconsistencies very quickly," Mr. McGhie said. 
Keeping customers, moreover, may be complicated by the pay-as-you-go billing system being offered, another analyst cautioned.
With perhaps 30 million people in the target group, Virgin will probably succeed if it can connect and hold onto just two million or three million of them, said Ken Hyers, a senior analyst at In-Stat/MDR.
But without contracts, any or all of them are free to jump to another provider for a better offer, or on a whim.
"Youth is a highly volatile market," he said.
