HEADLINE: TV WEEKEND; 
A Horrific Crime and a Town's Painful Soul-Searching

BYLINE:  By Scott Veale 

 BODY:
The crime was unspeakable: on June 7, 1998, a black hitchhiker was picked up by three white men in an East Texas town and taken into the woods, where he was beaten and chained by his ankles to the rear bumper of their pickup truck. He was dragged nearly three miles along rural roads, his body gradually tearing to pieces before his head and right shoulder were severed from his torso by a roadside culvert. A pathologist later testified that the victim, 49-year-old James Byrd Jr., was probably conscious until the end.
 Five years later, "Jasper, Texas," an earnest, workmanlike Showtime dramatization, dredges up the shock, horror and outrage over one of the nation's most notorious hate crimes. Wisely, the movie plays down the most lurid aspects of the case, which resulted in the conviction of all three men, two of whom had links to the Ku Klux Klan and racist prison gangs. Don't expect a psychological portrait of white supremacists or insights into how the Klan's tentacles can reach into a community. Instead, the film focuses on the aftershocks of the murder in Jasper, a racially mixed town of 8,000 whose tolerant, God-fearing residents become increasingly polarized by the ghastliness of the crime and the ensuing media circus. 
 Which isn't to say there are not gruesome moments: the flashbacks to the beating and dragging and the stark glimpses of the forensic photographs are nearly unwatchable and all the more revolting for their brevity.
For the most part, though, this is a humanizing drama with an ensemble cast headed by Jon Voight as Billy Rowles, the town's sheriff, and Louis Gossett Jr. as the newly elected black mayor, R. C. Horn. After Sheriff Rowles visits the crime scene and realizes he's out of his depth, he consults the local district attorney (Ron White) and calls in the F.B.I. He also hunkers down with his friend Mayor Horn and a community leader (Joe Morton) to find ways to unite residents against the intense media agitation and remind them that Jasper is a peaceful town where the races manage to get along.
Early hopes that federal officials will take over the case quickly fade, prompting the town's civic and religious leaders to hold prayer vigils, rallies, encounter groups -- anything to tamp down the public's growing fear and anger.
The screenplay glides quickly past the gathering of evidence; the killers left a number of clues that made the case easy to crack. In a compact, chilling interrogation scene, the sheriff and the district attorney force the pickup truck's owner, a soggy marshmallow of a man named Shawn Allen Berry (Toby Proctor), to confess to his role in the crime, getting crucial testimony that leads to the death-penalty convictions of the other two killers.
Meanwhile, an armed phalanx of Black Panthers turns up to protest the murder, and by the time the Klan mounts its own rally outside the courthouse, tempers start to crack. Before long, a task force appointed by the mayor presents the sheriff with a long list of grievances. As Mayor Horn grimly says: "We've been pretending all these years. It's all make-believe."
What gives these scenes of social unraveling their punch is the sense that the townspeople are deeply animated by their religion, and that despite all the talk of the need for faith and healing they are being unfairly squeezed between demagogues on both sides while the politicians and the news media fan the flames.
The film, whose gospel-flavored music is by turns mournful and portentous, has some mawkish moments and hokey dialogue. But it gamely tackles knotty issues of race and identity, suggesting that everyone, no matter how devout and well-meaning, carries some kind of racial baggage that surfaces under the right set of pressures.
Sheriff Rowles, for one, comes off as a decent guy who surprises himself by acknowledging that he's against racially mixed marriages ("It's real hard on mixed-race kids") and suggests that maybe the reason that police stop more blacks in Jasper is that they commit more crimes than whites. For his part, Mayor Horn, stirring up a long-repressed memory of a relative's savage beating by white police officers, grows angrier and more strident as the trial progresses.
In fact, the increasingly brittle relationship between the mayor and sheriff is the best thing about "Jasper, Texas." Mr. Voight, who has chomped his share of scenery over the years, turns in a nicely shaded performance, making Mr. Gossett the far more animated actor. It's a treat to watch these two warhorses play off each other, lending nuance to a friendship tested by dimly understood prejudices.
Fittingly, the film closes on an uncertain note after the conviction and sentencing of the first defendant. In a gesture of tentative harmony, the residents of Jasper rip down a fence dividing the black and white cemeteries, even as the economically depressed town votes along racial lines to stop paying salaries to the mayor and the City Council.
We're left with the sense that even if nothing will ever be the same in Jasper, "leastways," as Mr. Gossett's character says, "we ain't pretending no more."

HEADLINE: ON STAGE AND OFF 

BYLINE:  By Jesse McKinley 

 BODY:
Off Broadway, Risky Business
 As Broadway completes its first season with a box-office gross of more than $700 million, the situation Off Broadway is significantly gloomier. 
 Dogged by rising costs, a still-sluggish economy and a weak tourist market, several major commercial productions have faltered, including "Barbra's Wedding," the Streisand-inspired comedy by Daniel Stern, which announced this week that it would close on June 15, far short of recouping. A similar fate met "Adult Entertainment," which closed at the Variety Arts in April before recouping its investment. 
Even shows that had strong reviews are not breaking even, like "The Last Sunday in June," a comedy by Jonathan Tolins, at the Century Center for the Performing Arts, and the musical "Zanna, Don't!" at the John Houseman Theater. Stephen Adly Guirgis's much-ballyhooed drama "Our Lady of 121st Street" at the 399-seat Union Square Theater, one of Off Broadway's biggest, is doing better and breaking even every week, but it still isn't selling out.
"It's a mixed bag," said the understated Ben Sprecher, an Off Broadway theater owner and manager. "Off Broadway is a wonderful place to see a play, a wonderful place to act in a play, but it's not always a wonderful place to produce a play."
Among the many challenges facing commercial productions are ever-increasing costs, which make it hard to mount an Off Broadway production for much less than $500,000. Once open, productions are also facing increased running costs, often nearly $100,000 a week.
"The break-even is dangerously high in most places," Mr. Sprecher said. Off Broadway's expenses are so high, in fact, that some producers are opting to take their chances on Broadway rather than Off.
Consider "Avenue Q," the puppets-gone-bad musical, which got boffo reviews during a run at the 125-seat Vineyard Theater and will jump to the Golden Theater on Broadway next month, rather than another Off Broadway house.
Jeffrey Seller, one of the show's producers, said that a number of factors contributed to going to Broadway but that finances were a major part of the decision. "Believe me, when you have a break-even of $90,000 Off Broadway versus say, $250,000 on Broadway, it often makes more sense to go to Broadway," Mr. Seller said. He explained that Broadway houses are bigger and Broadway ticket prices higher, thus allowing for more income to cover costs.
Tourists are also easier to reach on Broadway than Off. "In the case of musicals, I think you're always better on Broadway," he said.
There have been a few commercial hits Off Broadway, including "Talking Heads," at the Minetta Lane Theater, and "The Exonerated," at 45 Bleecker Theater. "Tea at Five," which was going strong at the 499-seat Promenade, is closing next month, but only because the Promenade is booked with another show, a new musical called "The Thing About Men," which is a commercial production.
Indeed, for all the challenges of Off Broadway, producers keep showing a willingness to gamble, especially with plays. This week, for example, producers announced that beginning in September, the Variety Arts would be home to "Omnium Gatherum," with a veteran Broadway production team that includes the set designer David Rockwell ("Hairspray") and the lighting designers Jules Fisher and Peggy Eisenhower. Its price tag? A mere $800,000.

Salvaging 'Little Shop'
Jerry Zaks is wasting no time in trying to save "Little Shop of Horrors." The musical revival canceled its planned August Broadway opening this week when producers decided they did not like the direction the show was headed in an out-of-town tryout in Coral Gables, Fla. The director, Connie Grappo, was dismissed and Mr. Zaks, a four-time Tony winner, was asked to take over.
He said yes, and by midweek he had already had casting notices circulated to agents' offices around town, for casting of all roles. No word yet on whether the show's design team would be kept around, but the producers -- led by the Routh, Frankel, Viertel, Baruch Group -- has apparently not given up on Broadway.
The production is holding the Virginia Theater and has registered a new, Oct. 9 opening night with the League of American Theaters and Producers, which oversees all Broadway openings.
John Barlow, a spokesman for the show, wouldn't talk dates but confirmed that Mr. Zaks "is holding auditions for 'Little Shop' this month for a possible production opening this fall."

Braving the Stage
Who knew that Heather Graham -- she of the Austin Powers movies, "Boogie Nights" and thousands of adolescent fantasies -- wanted to be in the theater?
The answer, apparently, is someone connected with Playwrights Horizons, which approached Ms. Graham last month with a script for "Recent Tragic Events," Craig Wright's play about a blind date on Sept. 12, 2001. The role is Waverly, a spirited advertising executive.
Ms. Graham read the script and decided on the spot: "It was one of those strange things, and you're, like, 'What?!? This is a perfect fit. It was so close to my real personality."
Ms. Graham had attended a Playwrights show last season and said she had been looking for something good to do, regardless of the medium. She did a few little stage things in Los Angeles, she said, but she hasn't acted onstage in New York.
That's about to change. She'll begin rehearsals in early August; previews start Sept. 5. Is she nervous?
Not really. "It might sound stupid," she said, "but I think this is so well written, I don't think I can mess it up."

Along the Way
* Andre De Shields will appear in Derek Walcott's drama "Dream on Monkey Mountain" at the Classical Theater of Harlem beginning Oct. 2.
* The Rattlestick Theater Company at 224 Waverly Place in Greenwich Village will present "St. Crispin's Day," a new comedy by Matt Pepper that takes "Henry V" from the soldiers' point of view, beginning June 14.

HEADLINE: Europe's Bank Cuts Interest Rate by Half-Point 

BYLINE:  By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, June 5 

 BODY:
Heeding the pleas of desperate European exporters and nervous public officials, the European Central Bank cut its benchmark interest rate half a percentage point today.
 The decision, which was widely expected, was aimed at tempering the recent rise of the euro against the dollar and easing the pressure on European exporters, who fear that their goods are being priced out of the American market. 
 It is also a tonic for Europe's biggest countries, where economic growth has all but vanished. Three of the 12 countries that use the euro -- Germany, the Netherlands and Italy -- are on the brink of recession. 
"This gives people in Europe the confidence that someone cares," said Martin W. Hufner, the chief economist at the HVB Group in Munich. "It will counteract somewhat the effect of the rising euro."
The Bank of England left its key rate unchanged today at 3.75 percent, reflecting Britain's somewhat brighter prospects. Sweden's central bank matched the European Central Bank's half-point cut. Neither Britain nor Sweden uses the euro.
Analysts noted that a single rate reduction would not be a cure-all for Europe's economic problems, which are deeply rooted and which will require politically painful fiscal policies and overdue economic reforms.
The euro surged in value today after the move was announced, instead of falling, as currency traders turned their attention to the United States, where the Federal Reserve is expected to reduce rates later this month.
A cut of similar size by the Federal Reserve would preserve the former disparity in the cost of borrowing between Europe, where the benchmark rate is now 2 percent, and the United States, where it is 1.25 percent. That gap is one reason many investors have switched their holdings from dollars to euros.
Still, the European Central Bank's action today was decisive, even historic -- bringing interest rates down to a level not seen here since at least World War II. The bank's president, Wim Duisenberg, left the door open for further cuts.
"If the United States has room for maneuver, with lower rates than we have, then you can imagine we have not exhausted our room for maneuver," Mr. Duisenberg said at a briefing in Frankfurt.
Critics found fault with the bank for refusing to budge before now and said that it remained too focused on inflation when the biggest danger facing Europe, particularly Germany, is deflation, a cycle of falling prices.
"I do think they waited too long, but that's been the problem with their strategy all along," said Allan Saunderson, the chairman of EuroZone Advisors, a consulting firm in Frankfurt that follows the bank.
Some of the frustration with the bank stems from its increasingly pivotal role in Europe's economic fortunes. Political leaders in Germany, France and other countries have struggled to push through even incremental reforms. They are also hamstrung by strictures written into the pact that set up the monetary union; those rules block member nations from using deficit spending to revive consumer demand.
"You can't push on a string," Mr. Hufner said. "The rate cut helps, but it is not a recipe for economic development."
Mr. Saunderson said the size of today's cut -- and the apparent alacrity with which the 18 members of the bank's governing council agreed to it -- suggested that the bank might adopt a more aggressive stance in the face of Europe's deepening troubles. "We're seeing quite a substantive move," he said.
Mr. Duisenberg said the decision was driven by new statistics showing that inflation in Europe receded to 1.9 percent in May. That is below the 2 percent level that the bank has set as its chief objective. With a rising exchange rate, which makes imports cheaper, and stable oil prices, Mr. Duisenberg said, the inflation rate could fall even further next year.
Compounding this is Europe's faltering economic performance. Mr. Duisenberg said Europe did not regain its economic footing after the war in Iraq ended. Growth is so sluggish, he said, that the bank will have to scale back its projections for the rest of this year and for 2004.
Statistics released by the European Union indicate that growth in the euro zone came to a halt in the first quarter. The problems are most acute in Germany, Italy and the Netherlands, where the economies are contracting.
A recession in Germany is likely to last for the first half of this year, according to a new report by the IfW Kiel Institute, an influential German economic research group. It projects no growth for the whole year.
Germany's woes have been aggravated by the euro, which has risen 14 percent against the dollar this year, and 26 percent in the last 12 months. That has dented the profits of major exporters like Volkswagen.
Mr. Duisenberg acknowledged the damaging effect of the exchange rate, saying, "the significant and rapid appreciation of the euro over recent months will dampen external price competitiveness."
But he did not seem all that chagrined, noting that at current levels, the euro is trading close to its long-term average rate. A "strong and stable" euro is a policy goal of the central bank, he added.
Mr. Duisenberg also joined a chorus of public officials in disputing that Europe faces the prospect of deflation. "There are currently no forecasts indicating any deflationary risks," he said.
A recent report by the International Monetary Fund stirred alarm here because it asserted that Germany was facing a considerable risk of deflation. Mr. Duisenberg questioned why the fund compared inflation rates of individual European countries, when they share a common currency.
"I never have seen the I.M.F. publishing a paper on inflation differentials in California, New Hampshire, Texas and Ohio," he said tartly, in a rare departure from his usual tone of studied moderation.

HEADLINE: Using Technology to Develop Arab-JewishTies 

BYLINE:  By ETGAR LEFKOVITS 

DATELINE: NAZARETH, Israel 

 BODY:
Can Israel's drive to develop its technology sector as the nation's economic crown jewel help overcome generations of animosity between Arabs and Jews?
 That's the hope, distant and romantic as it may be, of Israel's first state-supported Jewish-Arab high-technology incubator, which was privately founded in 2002, not long after Israeli-Palestinian tensions erupted again into open violence. 
 "Arab-Jewish economic cooperation is the first step to peace," said Nasri Said, an Israeli Arab, who now serves as a vice president of New Generation Technology, as the incubator is called, after spending four years studying the local high-technology market for Israel's Ministry of Industry and Trade.
The venture was started by five Israeli Arab businessmen with their Jewish partner, Davidi Gilo, an Israeli entrepreneur who now lives in California. 
The idea behind the operation was to focus primarily on fledgling Arab entrepreneurs in Israel, giving them the opportunity to research and develop their ideas by recommending them to the trade ministry and providing needed financial backing to start a business.
Despite all the obstacles, the incubator is moving forward, with its first venture a striking example of how some of the most promising new ideas spring from the traditional roots of the region.
Sobhi Sauob, an Israeli Arab from the formerly nomadic Bedouin minority, hopes to develop a better treatment for diabetes, starting from extracts derived from plants known in local folklore as herbal remedies for diabetes and other diseases.
"Because of our history of living close to the land, and our using plants and herbs from nature both as food and medicine," Dr. Sauob, who has a Ph.D. in biomedical engineering, said, "we know what kind of plant is good and what kind is bad."
For Dr. Sauob, who comes from a small village on Mount Tavor, the N.G.T., in nearby Nazareth, was in the right place at the right time. His venture was the first promoted by the incubator to win approval from the chief scientist in Israel's trade ministry.
The project will receive $500,000 from the government, to be paid over six years, as well as a $100,000 grant and full financial support from N.G.T. for the first two years of operation.
Already, test-tube and animal testing of Dr. Sauob's herbal extracts are under way. If successful, they are expected to be followed by clinical tests on humans later this year.
N.G.T. "is not like all the other incubators in Israel," Dr. Sauob said.
Indeed, N.G.T. stands out in many ways from the 23 other technology incubators in Israel. 
Of the five Israeli Arabs who provided the initial financial backing, two are Nazareth building contractors, Caid Abu-Ayash and Muhammad Abed. 
One, Omar Masarwa, works in agriculture; another, Tamim Yasin, is a gas retailer, and the fifth, Ahmed Dabah, is a major meat supplier in a partnership with a son of Prime Minister Ariel Sharon as the biggest sheep supplier in Israel.
Together with their Jewish partner, Mr. Gilo, they shared a common goal: to give a much-needed economic boost to Israeli Arab entrepreneurs. As a group, they invested $1 million to $2 million in the incubator.
"Officially the Arab citizens have equal rights as citizens in Israel, but in a practical sense this is not true," said Sharon Devir, N.G.T.'s Jewish chief executive. 
Mr. Devir said he was attracted to the privately owned, but government-subsidized incubator as an opportunity for practical Jewish-Arab cooperation and "not just the political talk" about coexistence.
Like the company's original investors, N.G.T. is jointly run by Jews and Arabs with a Jewish president and an Arab vice president. The clientele is a mix of Arabs and Jews, and this the company says, gives it an edge among the 1.2 million Arabs who live in Israel.
Mr. Devir says that for Arab business owners being able to work with Jewish and Arab managers is a big plus. "You have a situation where you have an entrepreneur looking for funds, and in presenting their ideas to a company that they have worked on for years, it is almost like they have to undress themselves and come out in the naked," he said. "Trust is a big issue."
Of the 100 entrepreneurs who approached N.G.T. with various projects since it was started last year, about 40 percent were Arabs, 60 percent Jews, Mr. Devir said. Most were rejected, but 10 were accepted and forwarded to the Ministry of Industry and Trade for its approval. 
The ministry's chief scientist has given approval to two of the three projects it has reviewed in full.
As it happened, the two that were accepted by the ministry -- including Sauob's herbal approach to cure diabetes -- were from Arab entrepreneurs, while the one that was rejected was from a Jewish businessman.
The Israeli Arab vice president of the company, Nasri Said, said that he was initially surprised by the decision to establish such a venture during the current economic and political turmoil in the Middle East. But he insisted on being optimistic.
This is "a first step," he said, "towards true equality for the Arab sector."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Shares Hold Steady as Investors Limit Their Profit-Taking

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Investors set aside disappointing employment data and lackluster retail sales reports yesterday, limiting their profit-taking in a market that eked out incremental gains and kept stocks at their highest levels in months.
 The gains, albeit small, sustained a rally that drove the Dow Jones industrial average Wednesday to its first close above 9,000 in nearly 10 months. The Dow finished virtually even yesterday, but the number of advancing issues significantly outnumbered decliners. Advancing issues led decliners on the New York Stock Exchange by a three-to-two ratio. 
 The Dow closed up 2.32 points, at 9,041.30. On Wednesday, the Dow rose more than 100 points, closing above 9,000 for the first time since Aug. 22.
The broader market also finished higher. The Nasdaq composite index gained 11.36 points, or 0.7 percent, to 1,646.01. The Nasdaq is trading at levels not seen since May 2002.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbed 3.90 points, or 0.4 percent, to 990.14. It was last that high in July.
At the end of yesterday's trading, the Dow had risen 20.2 percent, the Nasdaq had gained 29.5 percent and the S.& P. had climbed 23.1 percent since March 11.
Analysts said that despite the limited nature of the gains, the fact that there was not a broader sell-off indicates a growing sentiment by investors that the market is rebounding.
"We've been in a long and deep bear market and investors feel like the worst is over, and what appeals to them more than anything is some of the stocks that have gotten hit the worst," said Richard E. Cripps, the chief market strategist for Legg Mason of Baltimore.
Investors have been encouraged by better-than-expected first-quarter earnings, signs of economic improvements and upbeat assessments of the economy by the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan.
"People are anticipating that the economy is going to continue to grow -- slowly, but nonetheless we are coming up from a very depressed level," said Richard A. Dickson, senior market strategist at Lowry's Research Reports in Palm Beach, Fla.
Even so, investors remained cautious, awaiting the government's release this morning of May jobless figures.
"You have to see strong numbers for us to be convinced that the economy is in a true comeback and not just going up on air," said Stephen Carl, head of United States equity trading for the Williams Capital Group.
Yesterday, disappointing employment data and lackluster retail sales for May prompted some investors to sell stock and lock in profits. The Labor Department reported that the number of American workers filing new claims for jobless benefits climbed to a five-week high last week, indicating that companies are still contending with an economy that is struggling for footing.
New applications for unemployment insurance rose by a seasonally adjusted 16,000, to 442,000 for the workweek ending May 31, putting claims at their highest level since the week ending April 26. 
Major retailers reported that sales at stores open at least a year rose modestly in May. But rainy weather in certain regions and a weak job market limited spending for yet another month.
Among yesterday's decliners, Abercrombie & Fitch stumbled 52 cents, or 1.8 percent, to $28.77 after reporting that its May sales at stores open at least a year fell 7 percent, double the 3.5 percent decline analysts were expecting.
But the AnnTaylor Stores Corporation rose $1.24, or 5 percent, to $28.48 after raising its quarterly forecast and reporting a gain in May of 9.4 percent at stores open more than a year, well ahead of the 0.1 percent decline analysts were expecting.
In the bond market, the price of Treasuries fell. The 10-year Treasury note declined 12/32 , to a price of 102 13/32 . The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 3.34 percent from 3.29 percent on Wednesday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond dropped 24/32 , to 115 18/32 . The bond's yield rose to 4.40 percent from 4.36 percent.

HEADLINE: Requests for Jobless Benefits Increase 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 5 

 BODY:
The number of American workers filing new claims for jobless benefits climbed to a five-week high last week as companies coped with an economy that is struggling to regain its footing.
 The Labor Department reported today that new applications for unemployment insurance rose by a seasonally adjusted 16,000 to 442,000 for the workweek ending May 31. The increase pushed claims to their highest level since the end of April. 
 "The labor market obviously is still contracting, but like the rest of the economy, it likely will recover step by halting step," said Oscar Gonzalez, an economist at John Hancock Financial Services.
Separately, the nation's largest retailers reported modest sales gains for May. 
In another report, factory orders fell 2.9 percent in April, the largest decline in 17 months, the Commerce Department said today. The decrease was more than the 1.8 percent drop economists were forecasting. 
Manufacturing, which has slashed jobs and cut production, has been a major trouble spot for the economy. However, a more forward-looking report released Monday suggested that manufacturing might be poised for a turnaround. In that report the Institute for Supply Management said factory activity declined at a much slower rate in May, offering a heartening sign to economists. 
Last week's rise in jobless claims surprised economists, who were predicting they would fall to 421,000. However, some of last week's increase probably reflected seasonal adjustment difficulties related to the Memorial Day holiday, a Labor Department analyst said. 
Even so, for 16 consecutive weeks new claims have been running above the 400,000 mark, a level associated with a largely stagnant job market, economists say. 
The more stable four-week moving average of claims, which better adjusts for week-to-week fluctuations, rose last week by 3,000, to 430,500, the highest level in two weeks. 
The nation's jobless rate jumped to 6 percent in April as businesses cut 48,000 jobs. The economy has lost a half million jobs in the last three months, a decline usually associated with recessions.
Economists predict the unemployment rate rose to 6.1 percent for May and that another 30,000 jobs were eliminated. The employment report for May will be released on Friday.

HEADLINE: Compensatory Time Bill Retracted in House 

BYLINE:  By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 5 

 BODY:
In a rare victory for unions and Democrats in the Republican-controlled House of Representatives, the House leadership withdrew a bill scheduled today for a floor vote that would have allowed businesses to offer compensatory time instead of overtime to an estimated 80 million workers.
 The bill's sponsors said they were postponing consideration of the measure, the Family Time Flexibility Act, until they could muster the votes required for passage. But a senior Republican aide said the backers were so short of votes that the measure was not likely to return, adding, "It will probably just fade away." 
 Proponents called the bill a way to give parents, particularly women, more time with their children by allowing those who work more than 40 hours a week to forego overtime in favor of days off. Opponents said it would benefit big business under the guise of helping workers.
Companies are now barred from offering compensatory time under a 1938 law, theFair Labor Standards Act, which covers 80 million of the 150 million workers. Professionals, administrators and executives are not covered.
Labor groups lobbied heavily against the measure, saying it would take billions of dollars in overtime pay out of employees' pockets and enable companies, in effect, to dictate how the workers are paid and when they may take time off. 
"After pushing this bill for months, the Republican leadership finally realized that not all of their members would blindly go along with unraveling the basic right to overtime pay," said John J. Sweeney, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. 
Mr. Sweeney called the measure "a brazen attempt to give employers more control over the pay and schedules of their employees."
The bill would allow workers to bank up to 160 hours of time a year. They would be paid for whatever banked time was not used by Dec. 31. The bill specifies that workers can choose when to take their time, unless managers say it unduly disrupts operations.
Business leaders, including the United States Chamber of Commerce, pressed hard for the bill, which they said had numerous protections to insure that compensatory time would be voluntary. The business leaders noted that the bill had a five-year sunset provision, meaning that Congress would have to vote on re-enacting it after that time.
"Union leadership may have scored a short-term political victory, but it comes at the expense of those rank-and-file employees who want the voluntary choices provided by this bill," said Randel Johnson, vice president for labor, immigration and employee benefits at the chamber.
The withdrawal of the measure was a startling turn in the House, where Republicans typically exert tight control. Representative Nancy Pelosi of California, the Democratic leader, pronounced herself "very pleased that the unity in the Democratic Party" had resulted in the withdrawal. 
She said the bill would have set back labor law 100 years. 
"These are fights that were made at the turn of the century," she told reporters. "And by the 1930's, the 40-hour workweek was implemented, and if you if you worked people longer, you paid them overtime. Now they are saying, 'Work for free, and then they will give you time off some other time in the future.' "
The National Organization for Women, which opposed the bill, said employees counted on overtime income to meet basic needs and described the bill as a sham that represented "a serious step backward in protecting the rights and economic security of hard-working families."
The chief sponsor of the legislation, Representative Judy Biggert, Republican of Illinois, said it would favor working families, particularly working mothers.

HEADLINE: Senate Adds Rule to Energy Bill to Double Ethanol in Gasoline 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 5 

 BODY:
Drivers in every state but Hawaii and Alaska could be pumping gasoline containing ethanol by 2012 if a plan approved today by the Senate becomes law.
 The proposal, incorporated in a broad energy bill, would change how refiners blend gasoline and how they meet clean-air requirements. It would require doubling the use of ethanol, to at least five billion gallons a year, in what would be a boon to corn farmers. 
 Methanol is made mainly in the Midwest from corn, although it can be produced with other grains and biomass. Under the bill, refiners in every state except Alaska and Hawaii would have to use it.
The measure, approved 67 to 29, would also ban the use of another gasoline additive, methyl tertiary butyl ether, or M.T.B.E., a derivative of natural gas that can contaminate supplies of drinking water. M.T.B.E. has been added to gasoline in many states since the 1970's to increase the octane rating and make the fuel burn more cleanly. 
Refiners would have more freedom to blend fuel because the measure would also end a requirement that gasoline contain at least 2 percent oxygen in areas with air pollution problems. Although the rule has been credited with achieving significant reductions in tailpipe pollution, refiners say they can produce cleaner gasoline without it.
Opponents said expanding the use of ethanol could lead to gasoline shortages and price surges in regions without ethanol plants. The ethanol industry says it does not anticipate problems meeting increased demand under the plan, which would be phased in over eight years.
A proposal by Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California, a leading opponent of the ethanol rule, would have given states the final say in requiring ethanol. The plan failed by two to one. A proposal by Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, to exempt the Far West and Northeast was defeated, 59 to 26.
The proposed requirements, reflecting a compromise developed by interests that represent farmers, oil companies and environmentalists, were inserted in the broad bill.
The House called for a similar expansion of ethanol production in a bill that it passed in April. But the House rejected a ban on M.T.B.E., saying market forces and action by states would phase out the product. At least 17 states have acted to ban or sharply reduce the additive. The White House has strongly supported ethanol.
Backers of ethanol said the bill would help energy independence by displacing up to 250,000 barrels of oil a day by 2012.
"It increases fuel supply, stimulates economic growth and spurs development of domestic ethanol fuels," Senator Christopher S. Bond, Republican of Missouri, said. "There are tremendous economic benefits."
As the Senate began debating the fuel rules this week, the ethanol industry issued a report commissioned by the National Association of Corn Growers that estimated that doubling the use of ethanol would add $1.3 billion a year to farmers' incomes and create 214,000 jobs while lowering the cost of gasoline.
Opponents argued that refineries in California and the Northeast, far from ethanol plants, might have trouble obtaining it. Exempting the Northeast and Far West would resolve the problem, some Democrats from those regions said.
The ethanol proposal was introduced by Senators Bill Frist, the Tennessee Republican who is majority leader, and Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic leader. 

CORRECTION-DATE: June 7, 2003

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about Senate approval of a plan that would change the way refiners blend gasoline misidentified an additive made from corn, and the headline misstated an objective of the plan. The additive is ethanol, not methanol. The plan would double its use, to at least five billion gallons a year; it would not double the amount of ethanol in gasoline.

HEADLINE: Chicago Journal; 
Debating a Distant Homeland's Future

BYLINE:  By MONICA DAVEY 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, June 5 

 BODY:
Though much of the city has not heard of it, there is an election beginning here Friday.
 It is open to only 9,000 people, all of them Polish citizens who live in Chicago and hold Polish passports. It is about issues mostly of concern on another continent. Still, the debate is passionate inside the cluttered storefronts that line Milwaukee Avenue, the diagonal street that slices through one of the nation's largest Polish-American neighborhoods. 
 For weeks, the Polish-language newspapers and AM-radio talk shows have been filled with debate over the question that will be asked here, in Polish, on a simple paper ballot: should Poland join the European Union?
That might seem an odd question to whip up people who in many cases left Poland years ago. But it has proved consuming. Today, as he stood inside his delicatessen, where all shapes and shades of garlicky sausages hang from the wall, Kazimierz Cygan was still weighing which way to vote. Millions of Polish citizens, in their home country and in the places they live now, are expected to cast ballots before the end of this weekend.
Mr. Cygan, 45, is one of thousands of people who signed up to vote in Chicago, and he said he had heard pitches from all sides in recent days: from friends, from his wife, and from the Polish television news station that plays all day in his store. Even his priest has weighed in, Mr. Cygan said, advising parishioners to vote their conscience.
That advice did little to solve Mr. Cygan's confusion.
He has lived in Chicago a long time, almost two decades now. But he said his ties to Poland, where he grew up on a farm, remained firm. He feels a sense of duty, then, to help shape his country's future. But what should that future look like?
"Everybody is talking, 'but I don't know what to do," he said. "People say the E.U. will be better, ultimately, for people in Poland. If everybody benefits from this, then yes, I am for it. But will it only help the top? I worry about how it may affect the little guys in Poland, the farmers, right away. And I worry that we're going to lose independence."
Polls suggest that the referendum will pass, so long as nearly 15 million Poles cast ballots, to meet the requirement that 50 percent of eligible voters vote.
But it is hotly debated here, where those who favor membership in the E.U. see it as the best way to improve Poland's economy swiftly, while those who oppose it say they fear that Poland's traditional values, on issues like religion and abortion and divorce, could be eroded.
"The Polish community of Chicago is deeply divided over this," said Mariusz Brymora, Poland's deputy consul general in Chicago. "It is an extremely hot issue for them. They want to have a say about what is going on."
For more than a century, Polish immigrants have come to this city, giving it a reputation as the biggest Polish city outside of Poland. That reputation, in turn, has drawn still more Polish immigrants. The latest census figures show that more than 700,000 people in Illinois identified themselves as having Polish roots.
At the crowded intersection where Central Park Avenue meets Milwaukee Avenue -- a spot T. Ron Jasinski-Herbert of the Polish National Alliance calls "the most Polish corner in Chicago" -- nearly all the signs are in Polish, from the beauty salon to the bar. Shop owners speak Polish, and they post Polish-language flyers for everything from apartments-for-rent to missing cats.
Behind the counter in the Pasieka Bakery, Mary Bobek, 43, said she had decided not to vote. She came to Chicago 14 years ago and the question has little bearing on her life now. "I live here," she said.
Many other people will also not be voting, because they are second- and third-generation Americans. But there are those who are not, and Polish government officials have worked for weeks to make sure they can cast their ballots.
After a publicity drive that ended with faxed and e-mailed registrations still arriving at the midnight deadline on Tuesday, 9,000 Polish citizens signed up for the voting that will take place at six churches and centers around Chicago on Friday and Saturday. 
The thousands of votes cast here will be dwarfed, of course, by the millions in Poland. But people in Poland will still be watching, as much for symbolic reasons as any other.
"America has a special place in the hearts of Polish people," Mr. Brymora said. "Almost everyone in Poland has a relative in America. So the interest in what Americans choose is quite natural."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
European Central Bank Cuts Rates by Half a Point
The European Central Bank cut its benchmark interest rate half a percentage point. The decision, which was widely expected, was aimed at tempering the recent rise of the euro against the dollar and easing the pressure on European exporters, who fear that their goods are being priced out of the American market.
 Interest rates in Europe are at a level not seen there since at least World War II. But the president of the European Central Bank, Wim Duisenberg, above, left the door open for further cuts. World Business, Section W. 

Senate Approves Child Tax Credit
The Senate voted to give an increased child tax credit to millions of low-income families who did not receive it in the new tax law. A1.

Bipartisan Deal on Drug Coverage
Several senators announced that they had reached a bipartisan agreement on legislation to provide prescription drug coverage to the elderly, through the traditional government-run Medicare program and through newer private health plans. A30.

Payment Expected Soon in Lawsuit
The nation's retailers may receive money from the settlement of a debit-card lawsuit involving Visa U.S.A. and MasterCard International sooner than expected. C3.

AOL Cancels Auction of Book Unit
AOL Time Warner canceled the auction of its book publishing division because it could not attract a high enough price. C5.

Intel Revises Revenue Forecast
Intel expects sales of $6.6 billion to $6.8 billion for the second quarter, compared with earlier estimates of $6.4 billion to $7 billion. C6.

ImClone to Reapply for Approval
Shares of ImClone Systems rose 12 percent after the company said that it would reapply this year for approval of Erbitux, the cancer drug rejected in December 2001 by the Food and Drug Administration. The application could mean that the drug could reach the market by early next year, months before some analysts had expected. C2.

Stocks Continue to Head Higher
Stocks continued to climb, with the Dow Jones industrial average rising 2.32 points, to 9,041.30; the Nasdaq composite index gaining 11.36 points, to 1,646.01; and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbing 3.90 points, to 990.14. C6.

A New Weather Supercomputer
The nation's most powerful supercomputer for weather forecasting is scheduled to go online today. C4.

Europe Wants More From Microsoft
European competition regulators are seeking more evidence in their investigation of Microsoft, a move expected to delay further the five-year-old antitrust inquiry. C4.

Claims for Jobless Benefits Rise
The Labor Department reported that the number of American workers filing new claims for jobless benefits climbed to a five-week high last week. C4.

Retailers Say Sales Jumped in May
Sales at retail chains rose 1.5 percent in May from May 2002, according to the Goldman, Sachs index. C3.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate; 
Rezoning Spurs Park Slope Condos

BYLINE:  By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
Along the side streets between Fourth and Fifth Avenues in Park Slope, Brooklyn, new condominiums are rising. The buildings are not only expanding the stock of housing in the neighborhood but also pushing its residential boundaries westward, a process expected to extend to largely commercial stretches of Fourth Avenue under a recent rezoning. 
 Four projects between the avenues will add 150 condos by the end of the year, said Peter Noonan, a vice president at the Brooklyn office of the Corcoran Group real estate company. 
 Construction is under way on a 46-apartment second phase of the existing 36-apartment Park Slope Estates, with plans for more units at the corner of Fourth Avenue and Second Street. At 675 Sackett Street, a 38-unit apartment building is nearing completion. Construction continues on a 16-apartment project on Garfield Place, and on another with 50 units on Carroll Street. 
The activity, Mr. Noonan said, is moving toward Fourth Avenue because that is where there are old commercial buildings and sites to redevelop. Libby Ryan, a broker at of the Brooklyn office of William B. May, said the new developments were "close to pricey brownstones that routinely sell for $2 million, and in the last 18 months boutiques and cafes have replaced run-down shops along Fifth Avenue."
Another factor, industry professionals say, is a rezoning of 110 blocks of Park Slope, including a stretch of Fourth Avenue, that took place in April. It had been in the works for a decade. 
That rezoning puts height and other restrictions in place on blocks where the three- and four-story brownstones for which Park Slope is known predominate. Along much of Fourth Avenue, however, an area dotted with three-story walk-ups, auto repair shops and gas stations, the new zoning allows buildings of up to 12 stories.
The Brooklyn office of the city's Planning Department has projected that 1,100 residences could be built along Fourth Avenue under the new zoning, 440 of them in the next decade. 
The City Council and the Bloomberg administration have set aside $6 million to stimulate construction of below-market-rate housing along Fourth Avenue. The action was in response to community concerns that the rezoning did not require developers to build any such units.
Carol Abrams, a spokeswoman for the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development, said the $6 million was expected to be allocated through several existing housing programs and to take different forms, including tax-exempt bond financing and low-interest loans. In return, developers would reserve at least 20 percent of the units for residents whose incomes do not exceed a specific earnings ceiling. Estimates are that the public money would generate at least 130 below-market-rate units, Ms. Abrams she said. 
Brad Lander, executive director of the Fifth Avenue Committee, a community group, said he was skeptical that developers would take advantage of the incentives since "they would make much more building all market-rate apartments." 
When Boymelgreen Developers completed the first 36-unit phase of Park Slope Estates on Second Street in 2001, it was testing the market for condos. "We go to the edge of a neighborhood, build something special and extend the neighborhood," said Benjamin Klein, the company's director of operations. 
The first two- and three-bedroom units, in six connected four-story buildings, sold for an average of $400 to $450 a square foot, or $510,000 to $850,000. Now the company is nearing completion on a second 46-unit phase called Cityview Gardens. 
The latest two- and three-bedroom units will have 1,200 to 1,350 square feet; duplexes will have up to 2,400 square feet. The apartments will be in 10 five-story buildings: six on Second Street and four on Third Street. The structures will overlook a central courtyard. Sales are expected to start in three or four months at $450 to $500 a square foot. 
Mr. Klein said that because of the recent rezoning, his company planned to move forward within the next three to six months to develop the adjacent Fourth Avenue property with a 12-story building with about 75 units. 
Construction continues at the four-story condo building on Sackett Street, called Park Slope Terrace. 
Sales began last month for the 38 two- and three-bedroom apartments, which have 1,020 to 2,745 square feet. So far, 28 have been sold for $370 to $402 a square foot on average, or $405,000 to $955,000, said Mr. Noonan of Corcoran, the project's sales agent. Initial occupancy is expected in December.

CORRECTION-DATE: June 14, 2003

 CORRECTION:
An article on June 6 about new condominiums in Park Slope referred incompletely to the marketing arrangement for a building under construction in the Park Slope Terrace development. It is being marketed by the Corcoran Group and the Aguayo & Huebener Realty Group, not by Corcoran alone. Peter Noonan of Corcoran is a sales agent for it, but not the only one.
An article on June 6 about new condominiums in Park Slope, Brooklyn, included erroneous sales prices from a developer for the first 36unit phase of Park Slope Estates. Two- and three-bedroom apartments there sold in 2001 for $350,000 to $695,000, not $510,000 to $850,000. A letter from residents on June 20, questioning the figures, went astray at The Times.

HEADLINE: Duped And Betrayed 

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN; E-mail: krugman@nytimes.com

 BODY:
According to The New Republic, Senator Zell Miller -- one of a dwindling band of Democrats who still think they can make deals with the Bush administration and its allies -- got shafted in the recent tax bill. He supported the bill in part because it contained his personal contribution: a measure requiring chief executives to take personal responsibility for corporate tax declarations. But when the bill emerged from conference, his measure had been stripped out.
 Will "moderates" -- the people formerly known as "conservatives" -- ever learn? Today's "conservatives" -- the people formerly known as the "radical right" -- don't think of a deal as a deal; they think of it as an opportunity to pull yet another bait and switch. 
 Let's look at the betrayals involved in this latest tax cut.
Most media attention has focused on the child tax credit that wasn't. As in 2001, the administration softened the profile of a tax cut mainly aimed at the wealthy by including a credit for families with children. But at the last minute, a change in wording deprived 12 million children of some or all of that tax credit. "There are a lot of things that are more important than that," declared Tom DeLay, the House majority leader. (Maybe he was thinking of the "Hummer deduction," which stayed in the bill: business owners may now deduct up to $100,000 for the cost of a vehicle, as long as it weighs at least 6,000 pounds.)
Less attention has been paid to fine print that reveals the supposed rationale for the dividend tax cut as a smoke screen. The problem, we were told, is that profits are taxed twice: once when they are earned, a second time when they are paid out as dividends. But as any tax expert will tell you, the corporate tax law is full of loopholes; many profitable corporations pay little or no taxes.
The original Bush plan ensured that dividends from such companies would not get a tax break. But those safeguards vanished from the final bill: dividends will get special treatment regardless of how much tax is paid by the company that issues them. 
This little change has two big consequences. First, as Glenn Hubbard, the former chairman of the president's Council of Economic Advisers and the author of the original plan, delicately puts it, "It's hard to get a lot of progressivity at the top."
Translation: wealthy individuals who get most of their income from dividends and capital gains will often end up paying lower tax rates than ordinary Americans who work for a living.
Second, the tax cut -- originally billed as a way to reduce abuses -- may well usher in a golden age of tax evasion. We can be sure that lawyers and accountants are already figuring out how to disguise income that should be taxed at a 35 percent rate as dividends that are taxed at only 15 percent. Since there's no need to show that tax was ever paid on profits, tax shelters should be easy to construct. 
Of course, the big betrayal was George W. Bush's decision to push this tax cut in the first place. There is no longer any doubt that the man who ran as a moderate in the 2000 election is actually a radical who wants to undo much of the Great Society and the New Deal.
Look at it this way: as the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities points out, this latest tax cut reduces federal revenue as a share of G.D.P. to its lowest level since 1959. That is, federal taxes are now back to what they were in an era when Medicare and Medicaid didn't exist, and Social Security was still a minor expense. How can we maintain these programs, which have become essential to scores of millions of Americans, at today's tax rates? We can't.
Grover Norquist, the right-wing ideologue who has become one of the most powerful men in Washington, once declared: "I don't want to abolish government. I simply want to reduce it to the size where I can drag it into the bathroom and drown it in the bathtub." Mr. Bush has made a pretty good start on that plan.
Which brings us back to Senator Miller, and all those politicians and pundits who still imagine that there is room for compromise, that they can find some bipartisan middle ground. Mr. Norquist was recently quoted in The Denver Post with the answer to that: "Bipartisanship is another name for date rape."

HEADLINE: Harvard Chief, at Commencement, Vows Change 

BYLINE:  By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 5 

 BODY:
Speaking on Harvard's 352nd commencement day, Lawrence H. Summers, the university's president, pledged today to reshape the undergraduate experience, including the core curriculum. 
 Beneath an ashen sky, Mr. Summers spoke proudly of Harvard's many strengths but also said that undergraduate students craved more contact with senior faculty members and that improvement was needed in the mentoring system. 
 Of the first overhaul of the curriculum in 30 years, he said, "No organization, and certainly not one as creative as Harvard College, should ever go more than a generation without reassessment and renewal."
The college has disclosed few details of the curricular overhaul, which will be a subject of prolonged study.
Ernesto Zedillo, former president of Mexico, who received an honorary doctor of laws degree, used his speech to praise the United States for leading the creation of international institutions in the first half of the 20th century. But he also cautioned Washington against acting unilaterally and abusing its position as the world's sole superpower.
"All the nations on earth, even the most powerful one, need the multilateral system," he said.
In accordance with Harvard tradition, the speeches by Mr. Summers and Mr. Zedillo were given at the Harvard Alumni Association's annual meeting, which followed a ceremony this morning to award graduate and postgraduate degrees.
The ceremony opened with a call to order by the sheriff of Middlesex County, and the first speech was a salutatory address given in Latin by Charles B. Watson Jr. 
"Now after reading through innumerable books, after writing endless papers, finally, we have arrived at this day on which, finally relieved from all your cares, you get to hear me speaking in Latin," Mr. Watson told his classmates, according to a translation provided in the program. 
In addition to Mr. Zedillo, there were 10 other honorary-degree recipients: Gary S. Becker, winner of the 1992 Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science; Elliot Forbes, emeritus professor of music at Harvard; Norman C. Francis, president of Xavier University in New Orleans; Ellsworth Kelly, painter and sculptor; Mary-Claire King, geneticist; Donald E. Knuth, computer programming pioneer; Linda Nochlin, art historian; Philip Roth, the novelist; Robert G. Stone Jr., longtime Harvard trustee and fund-raiser; and P. Roy Vagelos, former chief executive of Merck & Company.

HEADLINE: Scientists Say Flooding Mine Will Derail Lab 

BYLINE:  By KENNETH CHANG 

 BODY:
Scientists behind a proposal to turn a former gold mine in South Dakota into a vast underground laboratory said yesterday that they would abandon their proposal if the mine was allowed to flood.
 That would effectively derail the project, which South Dakota leaders have hoped would spur an economic and scientific renaissance for the state. The 300 miles of tunnels at the Homestake Mine in Lead would be ideal for experiments studying geology, deep-earth microbes and subatomic particles known as neutrinos. 
 The owner of Homestake, the Barrick Gold Corporation of Toronto, says that next week it will turn off the pumps that remove 500 gallons a minute of water from the 8,000-foot-deep mine.
In a statement released yesterday, scientists led by Dr. Wick C. Haxton, a professor of physics at the University of Washington, said that allowing the mine to flood would delay the project by several years, potentially damage the structural integrity of the tunnels and contaminate any possible microbe studies.
"Worse," the scientists wrote, "we do not feel we can make a reasoned argument for tens of millions of additional funding for dewatering, when the condition of the mine after dewatering and even access to the site are currently matters of speculation."
Just last Friday, the National Science Foundation released a report from mining geologists and engineers that concluded Homestake was the best site for an underground laboratory compared to competing proposals for Soudan Mine in northeastern Minnesota and a tunnel into Mount San Jacinto near Palm Springs, Calif. The panel also urged Barrick to keep the pumps running at the mine.
The scientists said that if they withdrew their proposal, they would then put their efforts to building an underground laboratory elsewhere. "Our commitment to the science demands that we do so," they said.
Barrick has said it is willing to donate the mine to the state, but is not willing to remain liable for accidents or environmental problems that occur at a future laboratory. The company has also argued it is more economical to allow the mine to flood now and empty it later, especially since the National Science Foundation has not yet committed to building an underground laboratory.
The earliest that any money could be available for the construction of a laboratory is late 2005, as part of the federal budget for the 2006 fiscal year.
Vincent Borg, a spokesman for Barrick, called the scientists' threats an "11th hour red herring." The scientists did not raise concerns until a few weeks ago, Mr. Borg said, and the science foundation panel declined Barrick's offer to provide information about the mine's antiquated infrastructure.

HEADLINE: DRIVING; 
A Car Show Just for 'Orphans'

BYLINE:  By GEORGE P. BLUMBERG 

DATELINE: YPSILANTI, Mich. 

 BODY:
RAILROAD tracks split the Depot Town section of Ypsilanti, but trains highball through and don't stop anymore. Out on the edge of town, General Motors' giant Willow Run plant stands shuttered. This is postindustrial America. What better place for a group of ghost cars to sputter back to life?
 Early last Sunday morning, in Riverside Park here, the ghosts were chuffing and purring to their assigned spots. An antique car show is nothing unusual, but this one had a particular eccentricity. It was devoted to orphans -- famous models that fizzled and died out. The people exclaiming over each other's machines are devoted to cars that, gradually or quickly, were rejected so emphatically by the public that their makers had to give up on them. 
 "I collect cars nobody wants," said Larry Claypool, a mechanic from Frankfort, Ill., who makes his living repairing a famous orphan: the Corvair, the 1960's Chevrolet model that helped make Ralph Nader's reputation when he reviled it in his book "Unsafe at Any Speed." At this event Mr. Claypool was showing a 1966 Skoda, a sedan from Czechoslovakia that didn't make it in the United States. It lined up with odd-looking Edsels and Corvairs, ancient but stately Packards and Duesenbergs, heavily chromed DeSotos and an attention-getting 1948 Davis with just three wheels. Over yonder was a Hupmobile, a car last made in 1941, and down the way was a Franklin, a brand that went out of production during the Great Depression. 
Mr. Claypool's Skoda had been found by a friend in Berlin. It's about the size of a Dodge Neon but looks like something from the early industrial age. The Skoda is still made, but it was never imported in large numbers to the United States, so it's a real rarity and is permitted under the show's rules for foreign cars. Mr. Claypool paid $1,500 plus shipping for his Skoda. "My orphans are never worth lots of money, so I can collect more of them," he said.
Randy Mason, a former curator at the Henry Ford Museum and Greenfield Village, who had a Studebaker and a Hudson at the show, explained the psychology of the orphan collector. "People who own unusual cars like Studebakers and Nashes identify with the underdog," he said. "We're kind of making the statement that we salute the cars and companies that didn't make it, but tried hard."
Linda and Dale Milliman, who were showing a 1959 Edsel, an example of the Ford Motor Company's most famous failure, had dressed for the occasion in period garb, he in leather jacket and ducktail haircut, she in rolled-up jeans and flame-red sneakers. Their everyday car is aPontiac Aztek, reviled by many as the ugliest car currently sold. "We drive the two most hated cars on the road," Mr. Milliman said.
Their Edsel was a four-door Ranger sedan, with the strange vertical grille. "We think the styling is neat," Mrs. Milliman said. "The more exaggerated the better."
"Our attitude," her husband added, "is, 'O.K., we'll drive this flop.' "
Ypsilanti's Orphan Car Show (this was the seventh) is not a high-toned concours d'elegance, like the one at Pebble Beach, where perfect examples of rare million-dollar cars are featured, and men wear blue blazers and women large picture hats. And it's not a frenzied auction like Barrett-Jackson, where profit rules.
This event, said Jeff Godshall, the senior design manager at DaimlerChrysler and a fan of orphan cars, is "like the 'Our Gang' comedies where the kids go to the barn and say, 'Let's put on a show.' " The admission fee for spectators was only $3; to register a car, it was $12.
There was a parade, with gaggles of orphans rolling past a set of bleachers at 15-minute intervals while Mr. Godshall and other automotive historians told each group's story, brand by brand.
Not every ghost car, the proud owners will be quick to tell you, was a bad machine. Some were elegant and beautiful, innovative in mechanics and design, but failed to modernize or yielded to more nimble competition.
The general rule at the Ypsilanti show is that an entry must represent a nameplate that no longer exists. Most were made by companies now dead, but there are exceptions, like Ford's Edsels and DeSotos, which were made by the Chrysler Corporation. Defunct models of existing brands, like the Chevrolet Corvair, can get in only if they were made in Ypsilanti. Foreign models, even those still made, are allowed if they are no longer sold in the United States.
Jim and Sue Watch of Royal Oak, Mich., swear devotion to the 1975 Fiat Spider they brought to the show. The Watches were philosophical about the gibes they have endured -- Fiat, which stopped importing cars to the United States in 1983, suffered from a reputation for mechanical unreliability summarized in the joke that the name stands for "Fix It Again, Tony." Their Spider, Mr. Watch said, "has only 20,000 miles on it, and so far no trouble."
The Watches prefer the Ypsilanti show to all-Italian car shows. "We feel more at home at this orphan car show than we do at the Italian Happening show each year -- there, we're just a throwaway car on the bottom of the pecking order," Mrs. Watch said. "We're more loved here."
Many of orphan cars had unusual design and engineering features. "These cars were influenced to a large degree by the personalities of the men who ran the companies, willing to go out on a limb," said Mr. Godshall, the Chrysler design chief. "Powel Crosley, for example, was a 6-foot-4-inch man who was a champion of his tiny cars. And George Mason, a portly man, introduced the Rambler range of smaller cars at Nash."
It was an orphan car that inspired Mr. Godshall to become a designer. He received a book in 1954 about the Cord 810 and 812 and was immediately intrigued. The brainchild of Errett Loban Cord and designed by Gordon Buehrig, the Cord had front-wheel drive combined with striking, low-slung looks. "It was hollow, rolling sculpture," Mr. Godshall said, "the most beautiful car ever made."
A Cord 812 was on display, a sleek 1937 supercharged maroon phaeton owned by Charlie and Edie Saganek of New Boston, Mich. It was one of about 200 of this model that were built, and one of about 2,500 Cords produced altogether. Gleaming exhaust pipes emerged from the hood and traveled through the fenders; disappearing headlights could be cranked open from the dashboard. Mr. Godshall was right; it was beautiful.
Watching a girl about 10 years old who was agape, nose to nose with a tiny 1952 Crosley, Bill Chapin, 54, whose forebears ran Hudson and American Motors, asked, "Do you think anybody under 35 knows who Bob Hope is?" With news outlets pondering the question on Mr. Hope's 100th birthday, it seemed like a good time to ask the same thing about Crosleys and Studebakers. "Who is going to know those names anymore if we don't run this show as a living history?" Mr. Chapin asked. 
For lovers of these automotive underdogs, the defense endures well past the end.

COLLECTORS' ITEMS
Some Automotive Names That Are No More

ABOUT 2,500 nameplates have come and gone in the American auto industry alone, according to Randy Mason, a former curator at the Henry Ford Museum and Greenfield Village in Dearborn, Mich., leaving their owners with orphaned vehicles. Here are a few of them and the years in which they were made:

HUPMOBILE -- Innovative medium-priced sedans and roadsters. Good quality but sales faltered. 1909 to 1941.

CROSLEY -- Powel Crosley, a manufacturer of radios and appliances, was ahead of his time with this very small economy car, produced in Cincinnati. 1939 to 1952.

PACKARD -- Large, imposing cars, once the epitome of luxury; fell on hard times after putting out lower-priced look-alikes. 1903 to 1958.

PIERCE-ARROW -- Some call it America's finest car, with outstanding mechanics. Made in Buffalo; a victim of the Depression. 1901 to 1938.

STUDEBAKER -- Low-priced but with styling that set it apart. Made in South Bend, Ind. 1902 to 1966.

FRANKLIN -- High-quality car made in Syracuse by H. H. Franklin, a pioneer in modern metal die casting. Its air-cooled engine made it a favorite of doctors, who needed reliability for house calls made in all weather, and aviators, including Amelia Earhart and Charles Lindbergh, who liked the similarity to aircraft engines. 1902 to 1934.

CORD -- Pioneered front-wheel-drive and aerodynamic design. Auburn, Ind. 1929 to 1937.

DUESENBERG -- Imposing, high-performance luxury cars, with straight-8 engines. Made in Indianapolis. 1920 to 1937.

KAISER -- First made in Ypsilanti, Mich., by Henry J. Kaiser, famous for efficient production of World War II troop ships, and Joseph Frazer, the head of the Graham-Paige car company. Later models had stylish, fashion-designer interiors and striking paint schemes. 1947 to 1955.

MAXWELL -- First made in Tarrytown, N.Y. Walter P. Chrysler bought it and changed it into a Chrysler. 1905 to 1925.

HUDSON -- A solid car in the Buick class. Overengineered and overbuilt. 1909 to 1957.

TERRAPLANE -- Replaced the Essex in 1932 as Hudson's lower-priced division; many speed and endurance records; discontinued in 1938.

NASH -- Known for its smaller Rambler, introduced in 1950. Merged with the faltering Hudson in 1954 to become American Motors. 1918 to 1957.

REO -- Started by Ransom E. Olds after a disagreement with his Oldsmobile investors; they had the rights to his name but not his initials. Lots of speed and endurance. 1905 to 1936.
 GEORGE P. BLUMBERG

CORRECTION-DATE: June 10, 2003

 CORRECTION:
An article in Escapes on Friday about discontinued car lines misidentified the last manufacturing site of Studebaker. The company was making cars only in Hamilton, Ontario, when it went out of business in 1966. Its plant in South Bend, Ind., closed in 1963.

HEADLINE: THE MIDEAST TURMOIL: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK; 
In the Homebody Wake: Lots of 'Bush Slept Here' Places

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

DATELINE: DOHA, Qatar, June 5 

 BODY:
President Bush's aerobic seven-day, six-nation trip, which ended today with a visit to American troops here, took him from the concentration camp sites of Poland to the czars' palaces of St. Petersburg, a global economic conference in the French Alps and Middle East peacemaking on the edge of the Red Sea. For a president who does not love to travel, the trip was Clintonian -- two countries nearly every day and a new bed to sleep in most nights. 
 By the time Mr. Bush rallied the troops this morning at the UnitedStates Central Command forward headquarters in the 115-degree moonscape here, the victor in the war on Iraq was clearly on a high, pumped up by the palpable sense in both Europe and the Middle East that the American president had new powers to wield. 
 "We've seen a lot of fine sights, but there is no finer sight than to see the men and women who wear the uniform of the United States of America," Mr. Bush told hundreds of whooping soldiers. 
The trip put Mr. Bush in such a merry mood that for the first time in his presidency, he summoned reporters on Wednesday up to the front of Air Force One for a 45-minute post-mortem on his meeting in the Jordanian port city of Aqaba with Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel and the new Palestinian prime minister, Mahmoud Abbas. 
At one point in the meeting, Mr. Bush told reporters, he suggested that the three leave the round table behind and talk on the lawn of the summer palace of King Abdullah of Jordan. They did, for half an hour.
"What I wanted to do is observe the interplay between the two -- did they have the capacity to relax in each other's presence, for starters," Mr. Bush said in the 747's conference room. "And I felt they did. In other words, it was -- the body language was positive. There wasn't a lot of hostility and suspicion."
Mr. Bush added: "And obviously I'm not going to betray any confidences, but it was a very interesting and positive conversation, is the best way to say it. I didn't need, for example, to be Mr. Chatty."

The Trick to Being Cool
Observers who saw Mr. Bush, Mr. Sharon, Mr. Abbas and King Abdullah II make formal statements Wednesday behind four outdoor lecterns set up in front of the Gulf of Aqaba could not help but notice that the four men, all clothed in suits and ties, did not seem to break into unattractive sweats under the sweltering midday sun.
The cool, composed images of the leaders were hardly an accident: White House operatives had gone so far as to run tubing from a quiet, out-of-sight air-conditioning unit under the platform where the leaders spoke. The tubes blasted cool air up through vents constructed at the foot of each lectern, a better-than-nothing solution that kept viewers' minds on the statements of peace rather than on heavily perspiring brows.
"It was still toasty," one White House official said. "But every little bit helps."

Fleischer's Star Turn
Karl Rove, the president's powerful political adviser, was ubiquitous on the trip, but it was Ari Fleischer, the White House press secretary, who drew the fans.
The balding Mr. Fleischer, whose televised noon briefings have turned him into an unlikely media star, was the White House adviser who was the most mobbed by the troops at the United States Central Command today. While Mr. Fleischer posed for pictures and shook hands, Mr. Rove stood by, largely neglected, until he hit upon a role for himself.
"Get your photograph with Ari Fleischer!" Mr. Rove began to shout to the soldiers. "Step right up!" Mr. Rove then cheerily grabbed the soldiers' cameras and took their pictures with Mr. Fleischer, a role he does not normally perform for Mr. Fleischer at the White House.
The day before on Air Force One, Mr. Rove had been talking so loudly that his voice floated in through the open door of the conference room where Mr. Bush was recounting his Middle East meeting to reporters. The president, who likes order, gestured to his national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice, to make Mr. Rove quiet down.
"Karl, I can hear every word you're saying," Mr. Bush said jokingly, but withauthority, as if reining in a rambunctious little brother.
Asked today what he did when he got the presidential message, Mr. Rove instantly replied, "I shut up."

Safe and Sorry, Too
Security is always intense on a presidential trip, but the French went to new lengths at the economic summit meeting of the world's leading industrialized democracies in Evian-les-Bains, the midpoint of Mr. Bush's travels.
To reach the meeting, White House reporters were herded onto a ferry across Lake Geneva, a peaceful ride made less peaceful on the way back by nervous French security police officers who ordered reporters to stay close to their luggage, or else. 
When one reporter left her bag unaccompanied, the police placed what appeared to be a small detonator next to it and threatened to blow it up. A short time later, when reporters had left their bags en masse for a briefing on an upper deck by Sean McCormack, the National Security Council spokesman, an angry French policeman in a black jumpsuit began shouting Mr. McCormack down, yelling that the correspondents were no longer standing near their luggage and "not taking security seriously." 
The man in the black jumpsuit then demanded an immediate end to the briefing, with more threats of the imminent destruction of cameras and computers. At that point, Mr. McCormack acquiesced, deciding that he could wait for another moment to convince everyone that despite their past differences, France and the United States could work together in perfect harmony.

HEADLINE: A Nobel Peace Laureate Under Attack 

 BODY:
A year ago there was hope that democracy might come to Myanmar. In May 2002, the military junta released Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the world's most famous political prisoner, after 19 months of house arrest. The government promised to grant its citizens full freedoms and agreed to hold talks about opening up the political system. These gestures won Myanmar, formerly known as Burma, a reprieve from international pressure while the world waited to see whether the promises would be kept. They were not, and sanctions are once again needed to force the government to keep its word. 
 There have been no talks. More than 1,200 political prisoners remain in jail, many of them elderly and sick. The harassment of Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi and her party, the National League for Democracy, has gradually increased, culminating on Friday in a violent attack on her traveling convoy that killed 4 and injured 50, according to the government (the opposition says the figures are much higher). There are reports that Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi suffered face and shoulder injuries. The junta must allow the outside world to see her. She and 18 members of the National League, some badly hurt, havebeen re-arrested and are being held incommunicado -- "for their own protection," the government implausibly reports. The junta has closed National League headquarters all over the country. 
 Since February, the junta has blocked entry to the United Nations envoy for Myanmar, Razali Ismail. He has suddenly received permission for a visit and is due in Myanmar today. But if he cannot visit Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi, he should leave immediately.
The junta may have carried out its crackdown because it believes that the world's attention is focused elsewhere. But officials are also terrified by Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi's support. As she travels in Myanmar, she draws crowds in the tens of thousands.
Her popular support makes her an intolerable threat at a time when living standards have eroded to their worst levels since the late 1980's, when a nationwide revolt resulted. Professionals can no longer afford rice. The widespread collapse of the banking system has shut down many businesses and infuriated depositors who have lost their savings.
The junta's spectacular corruption and mismanagement are mainly responsible for its economic troubles, but they do make the threat of more sanctions unusually potent. This week Senator Mitch McConnell, a conservative Republican, and Representative Tom Lantos, a liberal Democrat, introduced bills that would extend a visa ban for paramilitary officials, freeze the American-held assets of the nation and top officials, and bar imports from Myanmar. Many of these exports go to America and Europe. Europe, which already has a visa ban, should now block Myanmar's exports as well. The junta has had a year to demonstrate that its opening was genuine. Now all ambiguity is gone, and the world's response must be equally decisive.
