HEADLINE: Media Deals? Don't Expect Many Here 

BYLINE:  By HARLAN J. LEVY

 BODY:
BEFORE the Federal Communications Commission cast its vote last Monday to discard most of its anti-monopoly media ownership rules, newspaper brokers like Maryland-based W.B. Grimes & Company began getting ready to make deals.
 Starting more than six weeks ago, Grimes began a mass mailing campaign to every daily newspaper publisher in Connecticut and every other state, trying to drum up business. "The daily newspapers in Connecticut are good candidates to acquire television stations in their daily markets," said Larry E. Grimes, the company president, on the eve of the vote. 
 In that vote, the F.C.C. generally lifted the ban on a single party owning a TV station and a newspaper in the same market and raised the limit on the number of TV stations any one party can own. It used to be capped at stations serving 35 percent of all TV households in the country. Now it's 45 percent. 
When the agency eased its rules on radio station ownership in 1996, it resulted in a wave of deals. But that's unlikely in Connecticut this time around, according to media analysts, broadcast owners, newspaper publishers, and industry observers. Many predicted there would be a series of less noticeable, smaller-scale changes, although there may be a blockbuster deal or two.
"In reality, nobody knows," said Stephen Effros, a former F.C.C. lawyer, now a media consultant in Washington. "That has been the history of virtually every major ownership rule change."
Mr. Effros cited the most recent one, the cable television-newspaper cross-ownership rules that were eliminated over a year ago.
"The same special interests who were saying this would lead to massive consolidation in local communities made the same arguments then, but there is no evidence whatever that it actually happened."
The new rules, as they pertain to Connecticut, wipe out the ban on a company owning a newspaper and a TV station in markets with more than nine stations, like the Hartford-New Haven market, where there are 10. Also, the rules allow a company to own two TV stations in a market with five or more stations, as long as both stations are not among the top four.
Connecticut has one major market, ranked 28th, which includes a broad area stretching across the New Haven, New London, Norwich, Hartford and Waterbury areas. The market covers much of Hartford, Litchfield, Middlesex, New Haven, New London, Tolland, and Windham Counties, the F.C.C. said.
In Connecticut, the Providence-based LIN TV Corporation owns the only ABC affiliate, WTNH-TV, in the state, and UPN network affiliate WCPX-TV, both in New Haven. The NBC network owns the state's only NBC station, WVIT-TV in West Hartford, and Spanish-language WRDM-TV in Hartford. The Iowa-based Meredith Group is a single owner in Connecticut, with the state's only CBS affiliate, WFSB-TV in Hartford.
The Chicago-based Tribune Company also has a duopoly, owning the sole Fox affiliate WTIC-TV and Waterbury WB affiliate WTXX-TV, as well as The Hartford Courant and the alternative weekly, the Hartford Advocate. The new rules permitting duopoly and single ownership of both a newspaper and a TV station thus allow Tribune to maintain status quo.
But having a duopoly in Connecticut won't prevent these major players from selling or buying stations, or swapping them for those in more advantageous markets, said George Reed, managing director at the Media Services Group, the Ponte Vedra, Fla.-based broadcast broker.
"If you look at the list of owners in Hartford, you've got some pretty big TV companies in that market, like Meredith, LIN, Tribune, NBC, all of which understand the economics of duopoly," Mr. Reed said.
For the last few weeks, calls have flooded consulting houses, including at BIA Financial Network, the Chantilly, Va.-based national media consulting firm. Mark Fratrik, a vice president, said Connecticut was ripe for several deals.
"What could happen is that the Paxson station, WHPX-TV Channel 26 in New London, may be purchased by the CBS affiliate Channel 3 or NBC," Mr. Fratrik said. NBC now owns 34 percent of Paxson Communications, the Florida-based "family" program network, and has an option to buy the rest, Mr. Fratrik said.
Mr. Reed said that WHPX-TV was "the most logical target."
Neither Paxson nor NBC returned telephone calls seeking comment.
"Meredith is a big player in television," Mr. Fratrik said. "They may want to swap Channel 3 with other companies outside Connecticut, someplace else where they own another TV station." Then again, Meredith may stay put, Mr. Fratrik said, "since Hartford is one of their biggest markets."
Meredith would not comment on its plans.
"There are all sorts of things we could and couldn't do," said Douglas Lowe, an executive vice president, "but I know of nothing planned for Connecticut."
Mr. Lowe said he had not heard any merger talk concerning any of the network stations. "Tribune is probably tapped out since it already owns two Hartford stations," he said.
LIN also said it was not planning moves. LIN isn't selling WTNH-TV, "and it's unlikely that we would invest in newspapers," said Deborah Jacobson, a vice president. The rule changes, she said, "would enable us to take our strategy, which is to own strong news stations and partner with a second station affiliated with Fox, WB, or UPN, to additional markets. "Mr. Effros, the former F.C.C. lawyer, said that the smaller media groups logically are the ones most likely to want to expand.
"Big owners such as Disney, G.E., the News Corporation, Viacom, and Time Warner are less likely to make massive purchases," he said, while "the next tier," such as Gannett, Media General, and Tribune, is.
The Bridgeport TV station, WSAH-TV, an affiliate of the Shop at Home shopping network, is for sale, its owner, the Summit America Corporation of Naples, Fla., said. Summit owns five affiliates.
With the new rules, "We think the interest in our stations will be dramatically accelerated," George Ditomassi, Summit president and chief executive, said. "Our options become greater and more pronounced. We have had a number of inquiries about purchasing either single stations or the group. "We think that station prices have been depressed over the last 18 months, and that's beginning to change."
The New York Times Company said it was well positioned to benefit from the rule changes. "We believe valuations will be higher for broadcast properties," Catherine J. Mathis, a spokeswoman for The Times, said. "There may be opportunities to expand our broadcast group through tax-efficient swaps or other arrangements."
Other companies already in Connecticut that could make moves include the New Jersey-based Journal Register Company, which owns the New Haven Register and a collection of shoreline and central Connecticut weeklies; Dow Jones & Company of New York, which owns the Danbury News-Times; Media News Group of Denver, which owns the Connecticut Post in Bridgeport; the Virginia-based Gannett Company, owner of The Norwich Bulletin, and Entravision Communications of Los Angeles, owner of Spanish-language stations WUVN-TV, Channel 18, and WUTH-TV, Channel 47, both in Hartford. 
Most media companies surveyed, including Tribune, Journal Register, Entravision, and Media News Group, would not comment on their plans.
However, "Media News has publicly stated that they'd be interested in owning television stations," said James Rutherfurd, executive vice president of investment banking at Veronis Suhler Stevenson, a New York-based media merchant bank. Karen Pensiero, a spokeswoman for Dow Jones, said the company won't seek a TV station.
"Dow Jones is not in the business of owning and operating radio or TV stations in Connecticut or anywhere else in the U.S.," Ms. Pensiero said.
And The Washington Post has "no current plans to acquire anything," a spokesman, Patrick Butler, said.
The rule changes might make media deals easier, Tara Connell, a Gannett spokeswoman, said. Gannet already owns 100 newspapers and 22 TV stations in 19 markets. "Right now there's not that much on the market, and we're not expecting that much to go on the market because of this, but we will look at whatever comes along, as we always have," Ms. Connell said.

HEADLINE: IN THE SCHOOLS; 
3 Graduates Already In the Driver's Seat

BYLINE:  By MERRI ROSENBERG; E-mail: wested@nytimes.com

 BODY:
DURING the commencement season this year, Westchester County's nine colleges turned out close to 4,500 newly minted graduates, hopeful despite the daunting prospect of beginning a career in a particularly unwelcoming economy. 
Here are stories of three members of the class of 2003. 

Broadway Bound
 By the time she earned her bachelor's degree in theater arts and film from Purchase College, Melissa Mazdra, 23, had the kind of working stage credits that could make veteran stage hands envious. 
 She already has an Equity card and her resume includes production experience in the Broadway shows of "Man of La Mancha"; "Take Me Out"; "The Play What I Wrote" and "Amour." She'll be returning to New York City in August to be an assistant technical supervisor on Broadway.
As a member of the production management team, Ms. Mazdra is involved in everything that has to do with the technical side of a show, from scenery and lighting to costumes and sound. Her responsibilities include managing budgets, dealing with unions and hiring the people who do the actual work of building the sets, running the lights and controlling the sound effects.
"At the end of my junior year, the dean of my department asked me if I wanted to intern with Gene O'Donovan, who teaches a production management course," she said. "My first semester, I was working all day from 8 to 5 or 11 at night."
Ms. Mazdra, a St. Louis native, added: "I thought I wanted to do stage managing. I did a little performing in high school, but have always been backstage. Purchase is one of the best turnaround schools in the nation, with a lot of people who are working in theater."

Altered Vision
For Nicholas M. Esposito, 24, a 2003 graduate of Pace University in Pleasantville, earning his degree meant facing a rare challenge. 
When he was a sophomore, Mr. Esposito suddenly became blind as a result of a rare genetic disease, Leber's hereditary optic neuropathy. The disease's rapid onset forced him to withdraw from college for several months so he could learn how to learn as a blind person. Instead of taking his college courses in English literature, Mr. Esposito followed a curriculum at the Lighthouse for the Blind that included working with adaptive technology, learning Braille and receiving occupational therapy.
"When I was out of school, I was eager to get back," said Mr. Esposito, who initially returned to Pace taking two classes until he was able to resume full-time studies in 2000. By using a voice-activated computer program, Mr. Esposito who does retain some peripheral vision, has been able to write papers. Other students helped out when he needed it, serving as note-takers and readers for him. And with the assistance of his Labrador retriever, Guthrie, as his guide dog, Mr. Esposito has been able to negotiate his way around campus or on public transportation. He worked as a student teacher at Woodlands High School, where he taught English, as part of the process for obtaining secondary school certification through Pace. .
"I look at blindness, and try to see it as a blessing," said Mr. Esposito, a guitar player with a steady gig at the Black Whale on City Island. He plans to pursue a graduate degree in English literature from Lehman College and become an English teacher. Though the first couple of months were difficult, he said blindness "sorts out the external, misleading aspects and the superficial judgments that the eyes may make." 

Crossing Cultures
Kristin Leong, a Hawaii-born resident of Washington State, went to Sarah Lawrence College because of its blend of arts and academics. 
As an undergraduate, she worked for the college's career news publication, editing, designing and writing. She worked as an intern at Conde Nast, for Teen Vogue and Vanity Fair magazines, The Feminist Press and Massachusetts' NARAL (National Abortion and Reproductive Rights Action League). On campus, Ms. Leong founded a multicultural and trans-racial adoptee student group, drawing upon her experiences as the child of a Chinese father and Caucasian mother. She also continued her volunteer work, collecting one of the college's Virginia Woolf Briscoe fellowships that recognize both academic achievement and a commitment to community service.
She'll return to Seattle for the summer for a paid internship with an art gallery that focuses on unknown Asian sculptors before moving to Australia next January for a work-abroad experience. Ms. Leong says she is committed to remaining in the nonprofit sector.
"My experience with Conde Nast was great, but it underscored that I need to stay in nonprofits," she said. "I really love print media, and would like to work for something like Ms. or The Feminist Press. It feels grass roots. Artistically, it's important for me to mesh my left and right brains."

HEADLINE: IN BUSINESS; 
Fixing the Leaks and Filling the Till

BYLINE:  By CARIN RUBENSTEIN 

DATELINE: PURCHASE 

 BODY:
THE decision to institute a $5 parking fee for those attending concerts at the Performing Arts Center at Purchase College, while less controversial than the proposal to close the Indian Point nuclear plant, caused its own hailstorm of disgruntlement here.
 The man responsible for this incendiary action: Thomas J. Schwarz, 58, who was appointed in April to be the sixth president of Purchase College. 
 Mr. Schwarz explained the other day that the money-making idea had been floating around for years, but nobody had been willing to take the inevitable criticism. 
"I took the flak," he said cheerfully in an interview in his office at the college. 
As a lifelong Manhattan resident, "It had never occurred to me that free parking is considered a birthright in the suburbs," he said. By charging the local arts audience to park, Purchase College expects to raise a much-needed $200,000 next year for scholarships and academic programs, he said. 
It was Mr. Schwarz's determination to raise money, his detail-oriented ability to put a precise financial accounting structure in place and his willingness to place tight controls on spending that got him the job. 
Now more than ever, New York State officials are demanding that college presidents in the public university system raise money from private sources, said Robert L. King, chancellor of the State University of New York, who hired Mr. Schwarz and who applauds his aggressive fund-raising efforts.
With 64 schools and 403,000 students, New York has the largest comprehensive university system in the country, one that is just beginning to tap private donors, according to Mr. King.
"In Mr. Schwarz's time as interim president, he was pretty quick to take up the reins and to address the financial issues," Mr. King said. Mr. Schwarz was appointed interim president of Purchase in August 2002.
A divorced New York lawyer with two grown children who once earned a seven-figure salary as a partner at Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, the former owner of Mission Possible, a Mission-style antiques store in Washington, and a former mayor of tiny Ocean Beach, on Fire Island, Mr. Schwarz was an unlikely candidate to lead Purchase, a public institution with 900 employees and an annual budget of $47 million.
A graduate of Hamilton College, a private college in Clinton, N.Y., and of Fordham University School of Law, Mr. Schwarz was not familiar with the financial needs of a public university, nor was he welcomed at first by the faculty and staff at Purchase. When Mr. Schwarz arrived, the school was in a severe financial crisis, and "people were frustrated and upset about the situation," said Deborah P. Amory, the faculty's departing presiding officer and an associate professor of anthropology. 
"Mr. Schwarz was an out-of-the-box candidate, and given the crisis, there was a lot of distrust because he lacked traditional academic credentials," she said.
At the time, the school faced a $5 million deficit and the 500-acre campus was dotted with 30-year-old buildings with leaky roofs and skylights and clogged drains. Since then, Mr. Schwarz has nearly erased the deficit, and he has organized a campus renovation program: the drains are being replaced, the music building and several lecture halls are being rehabilitated and residential areas are being landscaped.
In addition, he has worked to rebuild morale at the school, and to heal the rift between the arts faculty and the liberal arts faculty, Dr. Amory said. Mr. Schwarz "is a believer in participatory democracy, who listens before he decides," she said. 
His cramped, cluttered office is decorated by a lone dying plant, file-filled storage boxes, loose papers and student art, including a huge painting of Siberian huskies (for which he has a special fondness), but Mr. Schwarz still looks the part of the natty New York lawyer. 
"I'm having a great time," he said. 
Mr. Schwarz moved his office from a distant administration building to one more centrally located, and he makes a point to eat in the dining hall and to wander around the campus to talk to students. 
He bought a large photograph from an art student: a haunting color portrait of the boy's working-class parents. Mr. Schwarz also found himself accompanying a sobbing student to the registrar's office to help her change a course that would allow her to work one job instead of three. (Until he did, nobody would let her make the schedule change.)
"If that's not why you're doing this job, you ought to be doing something else," Mr. Schwarz said, as he strolled across the near deserted campus, from which many of the 4,000 students have left for the summer.
Aside from organizing the school's accounting procedures, Mr. Schwarz has become involved in the school's $25 million capital campaign, fund-raising among alumni as well as among his former colleagues in the wealthy New York legal community. His goal is to make sure that the three branches of the school, Purchase College, the Performing Arts Center and the Neuberger Museum together "should have $200 million at the end of a significant amount of time," he said, with at least $100 million by the time he retires.
"We have to be more creative than schools with large endowments in how we use our money," Mr. Schwarz said, adding that he has learned to do a lot with little. Faced with an aging biology laboratory that was not equipped for computer stations, for instance, the science staff built computer stands out of metal pipe, for a cost of about $20 each. "In the private world, they would have ripped out the lab and rebuilt it, spending a few hundred thousand dollars," he said. 
The total state budget for Purchase was $32 million this year, but that is the same amount as last year, according to a spokeswoman, Geraldine Sanderson. The continuing legislative battle in Albany makes it seem likely that the school could receive even less next year, Mr. Schwarz said. 
Individual campuses do not petition the state for financing, said Margaret Sullivan, vice president for external affairs and development. The Purchase College Foundation was created to augment New York State's contribution, since "philanthropy has become increasingly important to all public institutions of higher learning," she said.
"While we will always expect to be funded by New York State, we will absolutely rely on our constituency of community, alumni, foundations, and corporations to enhance our academic programs," she added. 
The downturn in the economy will probably make it increasingly difficult to attract students able to pay the rising tuition at Purchase, Mr. Schwarz said, meaning that raising money for the school is more important than ever. In-state residents pay $3,400 a year tuition at Purchase; out-of-state residents pay $8,300 a year (both pay $800 in mandatory fees). Since the state budget is still being negotiated, the tuition for next year has not been determined.

HEADLINE: THE LAW; 
Counting Up the Costs of a Death-Penalty Trial

BYLINE:  By YILU ZHAO 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS 

 BODY:
HOW much does it cost to hold a death penalty trial? New York State spent at least $1 million in its defense of Dennis Alvarez Hernandez, a Honduran immigrant convicted of killing his girlfriend and two of her young children in Yonkers, according to the lead defense lawyer, Robert J. Aiello. The trial was the first capital punishment case in Westchester since New York reinstated the death penalty in 1995.
 The Westchester District Attorney, Jeanine F. Pirro, would not specify how much her office spent on prosecuting the case, although she said it was much less than the defense's expenses. 
 A jury convicted Mr. Alvarez, 24, of six counts of first-degree murder in early May at the Westchester County Court in White Plains. 
When the same jury could not agree on a sentence for him, they handed the sentencing to the presiding judge, Kenneth Lange, effectively sparing Mr. Alvarez's life. In New York State, only a jury has the power to sentence someone to death.
The cost to defend Mr. Alvarez, legal scholars said, was about the average amount that some state courts, including New York, Connecticut and Colorado, spend to represent death penalty defendants. 
"It's a very expensive proposition," said Stephen Bright, a scholar on the economics of death penalty trials and a visiting professor at Yale Law School. "Justice costs money."
The costs added up, said the lawyers for the defense. Mr. Aiello, as the lead defense attorney, was paid $125 per hour, and Michael Spiegel, the associate attorney, was paid $100 per hour, according to a fee scale determined by the state court. (First-year lawyers in major law firms are often paid about $250 an hour.) Both Mr. Aiello and Mr. Spiegel each spent at least 2,000 hours preparing for the case in the months since September 2000, when the killings took place. Lawyers' fees are estimated at about $500,000, according to the defense lawyers.
Then there were the fees for the experts. The psychiatrist who explored Mr. Alvarez's mental state: $350 an hour. The toxicologist who decided his blood alcohol level: $250 an hour. The forensic pathologist who determined the victims' cause of deaths: $450 an hour. The crime scene reconstructionist: $300 an hour. The mitigation specialist who looked for extenuating grounds: $150 an hour. 
There were also routine costs for paperwork. The court transcripts of the pretrial hearings and the trial alone -- a 20,000-page document at $3.75 a page -- cost $75,000. 
The defense lawyers, based in New York City, set up an office in White Plains during the seven-month trial and stayed in a hotel during the week. 
The team also traveled several times to Honduras, where Mr. Alvarez grew up, to interview witnesses.
A 1998 federal study showed that the average cost of representing a defendant in a federal death penalty case that was resolved in trial was about $270,000, although legal scholars say the costs have grown astronomically since then. 
In Texas and Virginia, where capital punishment cases are handled as routine criminal cases and tried more swiftly than in New York, the cost of defense in each case is almost never higher than $250,000, Mr. Bright said. Both Texas and Virginia have come under intense criticism for providing indigent death penalty defendants poor representation.
"New York should be proud of the fact that it gives people adequate justice," Mr. Bright said.
The costs incurred by the lawyers prosecuting Mr. Alvarez are difficult to tabulate. Both George Bolen, the General Trial Bureau chief in the district attorney's office, and Patricia Murphy, the Homicide Bureau chief, who tried the Alvarez case, are two of the most experienced prosecutors working in the District Attorney's office. During the seven-month trial, both devoted most of their time on this case, according to Ms. Pirro's office, although neither received overtime pay.
Routine costs like photocopying and telephone charges are absorbed into Ms. Pirro's $20 million annual budget.
The prosecutors also traveled to Honduras to interview witnesses. 
Last summer Mr. Alvarez offered to plead guilty to all charges in exchange for a sentence of life in prison without parole, and Ms. Pirro rejected the offer. 
"This is the murder of three people; these victims were slaughtered," Ms. Pirro said in an interview in her office last week. "If the death penalty shouldn't be applied in this case, then when?"
Just how much Ms. Pirro spent on the Alvarez case has become a point of contention between her office and her critics.
"You tie up two of your bureau chiefs for seven months, and does that count as a cost?" questioned Kevin M. Doyle, the head of the New York Capital Defender Office. "You have at least seven lawyers involved, and does that count as a cost?" 
Although Ms. Pirro said that only two lawyers, Ms. Murphy and Mr. Bolen, worked on the Alvarez case, the court transcript shows that a total of five lawyers from her office spoke before the judge and two others investigated the case.
Mr. Doyle's agency, created by the 1995 Death Penalty Statute, helped Mr. Alvarez's defense lawyers to prepare for the case. 
Ms. Pirro had her own criticism of Mr. Doyle.
"They stayed in a hotel and opened up an office for six months," she said, "And that's all taxpayers' money."

HEADLINE: No. 1, With a Bullet 

BYLINE:  By JULIA C. MEAD 

 BODY:
CAROL KOTSOPOULOS, 41, of Manhasset, was beaten repeatedly over the 17 years of her marriage to Nikolaos Kotsopoulos, 42, before the abuse escalated to murder on May 4, 2002. Mr. Kotsopoulos was convicted on May 21 and faces 25 years to life in prison. 
 The Suffolk police said they were called innumerable times to the Wyandanch home of Amelia Higgins, 46, and her husband, Calvin L. Higgins, 42, before May 1 of this year, when they said Mr. Higgins stabbed his wife to death, then tried to kill himself. Every 15 seconds in this country, a woman is beaten by her husband or boyfriend, and every day from three to four women are murdered by men who claim to love them. These numbers have not changed much over the last few decades. To catalog murders, attempted murders and beatings as part of a recent trend specific to one place is dangerous and misleading.

Laurel Eisner
Executive Director
Sanctuary for Families
Manhattan
 The volume of messy, complicated divorces on Long Island has outpaced the rest of New York State for years and continues to rise. Court orders of protection have hit an all-time high. And now Suffolk authorities report a startling uptick in homicides and attempted homicides by estranged lovers or divorce-court litigants trying to circumvent the legal process.
What happened to love?
"I think people are just miserable," said Lynne Adair Kramer, a matrimonial lawyer and president of the Suffolk County Bar Association. "The economy's terrible. Relationships are under pressure. Drug and alcohol abuse are escalating. Married couples can't look forward to the same retirement and comfortable future that they once expected to spend together."
Overall homicide rates on Long Island continue to decline. Article, Page 7. But Ms. Kramer and other Long Island lawyers agreed that a higher level of tension contributes not only to the divorce rate but also to domestic violence and marital homicide.
Other factors may be at work. Karen Malcomson, the North Fork program director for the Family Service League, said the marital and family counseling agency, which has offices across Suffolk, had a noticeable leap in business since the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, 2001.
"The impact at first was astounding because of the loss of human life and the ongoing threat," Dr. Malcomson said. "But then there is the continuing, everyday loss of a sense of safety, well-being, optimism and joy."
That lingering disharmony can be displaced onto one's job, children and marriage.
"There's less energy to work on a marriage, more of a tendency to say 'Let's just dump it,"' Dr. Malcomson said.
Lt. Jack Fitzpatrick, the Suffolk police homicide squad's commander, counted two marital homicides in the county in 1999, three in 2000, and two in 2001. In 2002, the figure jumped to four. In 2003, with more than half the year still to go, there have already been three.
In Nassau, there were four in 1999 and again in 2000, then the number spiked to nine in 2001 and dropped off to six last year. There has been just one so far this year, said Lt. Dennis Farrell, the commander of Nassau's homicide squad.
Neither could identify any clear link to divorce, though both asserted one exists. "Divorce can certainly be a catalyst to murder, as can other events, but sometimes those very same factors trigger suicide," Lieutenant Farrell said. "What triggers homicidal rage in one person may trigger despair in another."
The low number of matrimonial homicides makes trends hard to ascertain, but the number of orders of protection is clearly at the highest level ever. The Suffolk sheriff's domestic violence unit served 4,513 such orders in 2001 and 4,803 in 2002, and expects even more this year. Exclusion orders, requiring the immediate removal of one spouse from the family home, went from 499 in 2001 to 564 last year. 
Compare that to 1994, when deputies served 2,549 protective orders plus 296 exclusion orders. "The numbers are just phenomenal," said Alan Otto, chief of staff to the Suffolk sheriff, Alfred C. Tisch. "I would expect them to level off, but who knows when that'll happen." 
Capt. Lawrence Schnurr of the Nassau County Sheriff's Department said 2,349 orders of protection were served last year and 979 through May of this year. Last year they served 690 exclusion ordersand 287 through May 2003.
Captain Schnurr said figures for past years were not immediately available, but added, "I feel confident in saying there has been a steady increase over the past few years."
Contested divorces are likewise increasing on the Island, which already appeared a divorce-prone region.
For years, Suffolk ranked second statewide, ahead of all five New York City counties and behind only Erie County, according to the state Office of Court Administration. However, a quirk in how Erie defined "contested" camouflaged the reality that Suffolk has actually had the highest volume for years, said Peter Sorrento, the statewide matrimonial court clerk. That was borne out in 2002, when Erie adjusted its definition, shoving Suffolk up to first place. Nassau has consistently ranked just behind Suffolk.
"For all intents and purposes, they've been one and two, always, in terms of pending cases," Mr. Sorrento said.
The trend in both counties, but especially in Suffolk, had been toward a gradually expanding backlog and a struggle to meet the Office of Court Administration's goal of closing out each case within a year of filing.
In 2001, the last full year for which figures were available, 1,684 Suffolk couples filed for contested divorces and another 1,612 cases were disposed of, Mr. Sorrento said. That represents a rise in new cases since 1998, when 1,613 were filed, and a drop in closed cases, from 2,048. Though Suffolk has the most Supreme Court justices dedicated solely to matrimonial work -- nine, compared to Manhattan's five -- Mr. Sorrento said 30 percent of its contested cases miss the one-year deadline. Nassau, which has five matrimonial justices, maintains about a 28 percent noncompliance level, he said.
"Suffolk's not doing too bad for a county with such a high volume," said Mr. Sorrento, adding that the same is true of Nassau. "And, where there's so much for litigants to fight over, the courts can't always comply" with a deadline.
He agreed with judges and divorce lawyers that Long Island couples generally have more assets and debts to be divided than litigants elsewhere, and more child custody disputes. Divorce lawyers contend those issues, more than any court delay, pose the greatest source of frustration, anger and, in extreme cases, violence.
"Without a doubt, the paper moves more slowly, and there's a definite need for more matrimonial judges," said Harvey A. Arnoff, a Riverhead lawyer. "I don't think we've ever had better judges than we do now, but the volume is enormous and the financial issues are becoming more convoluted and complex."
Mr. Arnoff and other attorneys contended that equitable distribution laws, adopted more than 20 years ago, spawned an industry of forensic accountants and economists who help determine the dollar value of a spouse's professional license, business or pension, lengthening the time it takes to get a divorce decree. Justice delayed is justice denied, which only fires up the hostility that may already exist between divorcing couples, he observed.
"But violence, that doesn't just come from frustration with the system," Mr. Arnoff said. "That's a function of a more violent society."Actually, violent crime in America has been on the decline over the last decade or so, but the statistics, at least on the Island, do not show the same trend for domestic violence. 
Consider the remarkably toxic divorce of Albert Ermmarino, 44, and Joanne Riccardo, 42. Connetquot High School sweethearts who married in 1984, they founded Padock Auto Body, in Brookhaven, which bankrolled an accumulation of assets and Mr. Ermmarino's moderately successful racing career on the Nascar circuit.
With two teenaged daughters, three houses, a pair of valuable race cars, a prime commercial property and the business to battle over, their divorce has raged on for four years. Settlements were reached, then came unglued. Other personal relationships were poisoned: Mr. Ermmarino was beaten by his nephew, John Merschoff III, during a family argument, and Mr. Ermmarino's brother, Rocco, testified for his soon-to-be ex-sister-in-law. A trial ended in January, and a judge's decision is awaited on how the couple's assets are to be divided.
"It's possible to wrap up a case in a year, even one like this whose file comes in boxes," said Rudolph H. Cartier Jr., Albert Ermmarino's lawyer. "Unless, that is, the clients get involved in internecine warfare, locking each other out of the house, stopping the mortgage payments, and other crazy stuff."
He said his client was impatient more with delays caused by his wife changing lawyers than from any court backlog, but the Suffolk district attorney's office said he tried to speed up the process through illegal means.
According to prosecutors, Mr. Ermmarino told a hit man he was fed up and stood to lose too much money. He allegedly handed over $400 and two restored vehicles, a 1953 Ford pickup and a 1973 Mercedes Benz, as payment for the murders of his wife, brother and nephew. The hit man turned out to be an undercover police officer. Mr. Ermmarino is now in jail, charged with conspiracy to commit murder.
Mr. Cartier said Mr. Ermmarino is innocent but confirmed that, in divorce court, "emotions run significantly higher and the tolerance level significantly lower than in any other type of litigation."
Judith Otter's case against her former husband, Gary Pagar, has inched its way through Family and Supreme Court in Manhattan and Suffolk, town courts in East Hampton and Southampton, the Appellate Division in Brooklyn, for seven years and counting. Her attorney is now hauling the case back to Brooklyn, and Ms. Otter, who lives in East Hampton, said she has never been angrier with her ex-husband and the courts.
"It would be a comedy of errors if it wasn't so sad," she said. "The system has let me down every step of the way."
She estimated she has made more than 60 court appearances. Mr. Pagar, who lives in Manhattan and was once a wealthy investment banker who now claims to be destitute and unable to find a decent job, has been handed two orders of protection and has been repeatedly arrested for missing court dates and child support payments for their 14-year-old daughter. He once served 60 days in jail.
Twice since April, Justice H. Patrick Leis III has released Mr. Pagar with just a warning to resume support payments. Ms. Otter holds $180,000 in judgments for unpaid support and said she has received just $5,000 in the past three years.
She broke down in court on April 11, sobbing uncontrollably. "I find it totally, absolutely disgusting that he can get away with it one more time," she said.
Supreme Court Justice Alan D. Oshrin, who is Suffolk's administrative judge and practiced matrimonial law before taking the bench, agreed that Suffolk's cases tend toward the complicated, combative and lengthy, but declined to speculate on why they are so plentiful.
"The problem is, you have two people who couldn't get along and, if they could compromise, they wouldn't be in court," he said. "It's a dilemma that gets worse before it gets better."

 CORRECTION:
"No.1, With a Bullet" June 8 mistakenly classifies cases of marital abuse and homicide as part of a pattern of "messy, complicated divorces" on Long Island rather than what they are: domestic violence.
When a husband beats his wife for 17 years and then kills her, as was the case with Nikolaos and Carol Kotsopoulos, it is highly irresponsible to blame it on the struggling economy and resulting pressures on relationships.

HEADLINE: LONG ISLAND VINES; 
Wine Center Weighed

BYLINE:  By HOWARD G. GOLDBERG 

 BODY:
The Long Island Wine Council has hired ConsultEcon, a Cambridge, Mass., company, to determine if there is a need for a regional wine center, and, if so, is to "examine the project's economic viability and potential locations," according to Marco Borghese, the council president. A grant from the Empire State Development Corporation is financing the study.
 Instinctively, outsiders' smart money might well bet that, in the long term, such an East End tourism destination will be -- or should be -- in the cards. 
 Whether the feasibility study commissioned by the council, the wine industry's trade association, reaches the same conclusion could be a different story.
In an era when Internet information is crucial to travel, a visitors center would be a logical extension of both the council's own Web site (www.liwines.com) and the mosaic of wineries' sites that taken together easily piece together a profile of the wine region for tourists.
Almost certainly, travel to Long Island by wine aficionados from other states will rise, partly spurred by sun-and-fun articles in national newspapers and general interest magazines that routinely treat the wineries and the high marks their wines get as part of today's East End vacation story.
Wine-country visitors like to ship bottles home, and, step by small step, doing so is becoming easier. Legal restrictions on interstate shipments of wine are slowly crumbling under an onslaught of litigation by critics of restraints of trade.
Increasing numbers of state laws that allow limited or reciprocal shipments by vintners in wine-producing states make it possible and feasible for boutique producers to ship goods out of state. 
The North and South Fork wine industry, of course, is dominated by small producers like Palmer, which years ago broke out of insular sales patterns and began selling in other states. Schneider, a younger producer, now sells in California. Every step Wolffer takes suggests that its long-term goal is to be recognized everywhere as world class. 
In California and in Europe, visitors' centers are common, and indispensable. You come away from orientations about regions and their wineries with piles of maps and literature about nearby wineries, their products and restaurants that feature them with local cuisine.
It's one thing for a red-wine lover to learn abstractly in, say, Wine Spectator, that East End cabernet francs are comers. It could be more memorable to step up to a bar in a visitors center and taste one's way through a brace of them at a nominal fee. Then, on to the wineries to contrast and compare armadas of merlots. HOWARD G. GOLDBERG

HEADLINE: EDUCATION; 
A Dress Code With Teeth

BYLINE:  By ROBERT STRAUSS 

DATELINE: MIDDLE TOWNSHIP 

 BODY:
WHEN Matthew Buesing would come home to visit from time to time, he would see changes - not such subtle ones, he said - at Middle Township High School, where he had graduated in 1999.
 "We used to say, 'Our strength is our diversity,"' said Mr. Buesing, who recently graduated from George Washington University. "But then we heard about ethnic slurs and racial issues and things about poorer people. And fights and just plain lack of pride in the community." 
 He said he did not know what was causing the change in attitude in this district of about 3,000 students, which includes the interior of Cape May County -- a mixed bag racially and economically -- as well as the wealthy beach towns of Avalon and Stone Harbor. But he did know he wanted it to change back. 
 So Mr. Buesing, while still an undergradute, was elected to the school board, and with his colleagues he started down that road last month by implementing a stringent dress code.
 While the new regulations, which will go into effect at the start of school in the fall, do not mandate uniforms, they do seem to reach back to the 1950's and an era more reminiscent of the Doo-Wop architecture in nearby Wildwood.
 Come fall, male and female students alike will have to wear collared shirts, turtlenecks or sweaters. Dress pants and khakis will be allowed, but only in tan, navy blue or black. Jeans, T-shirts, tank tops and anything that "exposes the back, chest, shoulders or midriff," according to the new code, is out. Gone will be the recently fashionable "hoodies" or hooded sweatshirts, baseball caps, sweatpants and cargo pants. Shirts are limited to four basic colors -- white, gray, navy and light blue -- as well as black and orange, the Middle Township school colors. No stripes. No plaids.
 School board members and district officials insist that the restrictive code will cut down on disciplineproblems, freeing the staff to teach instead of spending time searching for weapons or drugs in baggy clothing.
 "It is definitely a character issue," said Daniel Money, a member of the Middle Township school board who is also principal of the Burlington County Institute of Technology, a magnet high school in Westampton. "I think you level the playing field for kids when you raise some standards in living and in dress, and this is what we are trying to do."
 Mr. Money added: "It's not a uniform, as some might characterize it. That would not be appropriate for a community-based school. We are giving choices, but we are setting standards."
 But Angela Plagge, who has one daughter who graduated with Mr. Buesing and two others headed for the high school in the fall, is not so sure. While Ms. Plagge said she applauded the notion of fewer distractions, she questioned whether such a restrictive code would serve that purpose.
 "Frankly, my biggest complaint is that this is a rule for the kids who don't follow the rules already," she said. "There is already a dress code, and my kids and most of the kids follow it. Why should they be penalized and have to buy a whole new set of clothes? The kids who don't follow these rules will find new ways of breaking rules."
 Mr. Money countered with personal experience: the results achieved when he imposed a similar dress code three years ago at Burlington County Institute of Technology.
 "There we based the argument on the idea that you only have one chance to make a good first impression and many of our students have to go out and get jobs, so that is important," he said. "It helped out in many ways. You aren't coming in to class in hoodies or pants hanging below your buttocks or baseball caps. You can't hide."
 He added: "All the excuses of whatever - looking at girls with bare midriffs, even - are gone. There is just more time to be academically prepared."
 At the school board meeting last month when the code was passed by a 7-1 vote of the school board, several parents and students threatened to go to the American Civil Liberties Union to support them in a lawsuit. But Deborah Jacobs, legal director of the New Jersey chapter of the A.C.L.U., said last week that so far no one had reached out to her.
 "Legally, there is not much recourse for things like this," Ms. Jacobs said. "If they said they wouldn't educate your child because you didn't comply, perhaps there could be something. But in practicality, these things are a difficult fight."
 Ms. Plagge said it was not a lawsuit she was after --just what she said was common sense.
 "I have a lot of trouble with the idea that wearing a uniform of sorts will encourage a sense of unity and pride," she said. "That is an idealistic and lovely thought, but it is naive." 
 Around the state, there seems to be little clamor to follow Middle Township's lead. The state Department of Education requires each district to have a dress code, though there are no particular guidelines. And Michael Yaple, a spokesman for the New Jersey School Boards Association, said his organization had not heard of any other district -- except for Mr. Money's school -- that had such a restrictive dress code.
 "Boards consider uniforms, but in general, dress codes are not so strict as they were years ago," Mr. Yaple said.
 In Wildwood, for example, the dress code prohibits "doo-rags," hats and sunglasses in school and bans beach attire like swimsuits underclothing and flip-flops. But there are no restrictions on colors, and students are allowed to wear shorts.
 Gail Cohen, a spokeswoman for the Cherry Hill School District, said: "We have never really had a problem with our dress code. Styles change, and we have to be aware of that."
 T-shirts and jeans are part of today's informal uniform today even at the prestigious Lawrenceville School -- where blazers and ties were required before the dress code was abolished about 30 years ago. The policy there states, "Dress at Lawrenceville is not formal, but students are expected to dress in a way that respects the standards and academic purpose of the school." In other words students can wear shirts or pants of any color, including jeans and T-shirts without printing, and even team uniforms on game days.
 Back in Middle Township, Mrs. Plagge said there was a big difference between a ban on bare midriffs, which was part of the old dress code, and the restrictions of the new code, especially financially.
 "All right, you say these clothes don't have to cost much, which may be true," she said. "But then, you know as soon as the kids come home from school, they're going to flop these on a chair and put on what they used to wear. That means we have to have two sets of clothes every day."
 She went on: "Then they are talking about this leveling the playing field. But you can buy khakis at K-Mart or khakis at J. Crew, and don't tell me that kids don't know the difference. You can have $200 sneakers or those with holes in them."
 But Mr. Buesing's mother, Karen, who is the assistant superintendent of schools in Middle Township, said the dress code was just the first step in instilling a renewed sense of pride in education in the district. "This is a K-through-12 thing and it will take time for parents and kids to adjust," she said. "Frankly, a lot of the people upset are juniors or parents of juniors, but God forbid you spend your last year in school looking nice."

GRAPHIC: Photos: A stringent -- and controversial -- dress code will go into effect in the Middle Township School District in the fall. (Photographs by Mary Godleski for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Uneasy Lies the Crown In a Divided Senate 

BYLINE:  By LAURA MANSNERUS 

DATELINE: TRENTON 

 BODY:
SOME political careers in Trenton ended on Tuesday, and some will crash in November. But one casualty that will cause no mourning is the odd marriage of John O. Bennett and Richard J. Codey. 
 As co-presidents of the evenly divided Senate, the two have led it through 16 months of lockstep legislating. And the Senate has led Mr. Bennett and Mr. Codey though 16 months of political frustration. 
 "Neither Codey nor Bennett has put their imprint on the legislative agenda the way they would have wanted to," said Stephen Salmore, a political scientist at Fairleigh Dickinson University who has served as a consultant to Republicans. "It's hard to be a strong personality if you can't back it up with a majority." 
 Amid the polite plodding in the upper chamber, the primary elections last week launched an official struggle for control of the Senate, a battle expected to be long, ugly and expensive. Many say it will show how deeply partisan the business of Trenton has become.
 Yet in some way the resolution will provide relief for the two leaders, who have problems all their own. Mr. Bennett, the Republican, damaged by news reports of irregularities in his billing of local governments that hired his law firm, finds his own seat in peril. Mr. Codey, the Democrat, has to bind together a party that just witnessed brawls in several crucial districts. 
 "On balance, the Democrats have more work to do today than the Republicans," said Ingrid Reed, the director of the Eagleton New Jersey Project at Rutgers. But referring to Mr. Bennett, she added, "Republicans are going to have to decide whether they think he can carry through to November." 
 Gossip about the leaders' weaknesses has been persistent, though much is mere scenario-drawing and fueled by alliances of the moment, which in Trenton shift as fast as those at the popular youths' cafeteria table. 
 Mr. Bennett is fighting rumors that he will withdraw from the race or give up his leadership post under pressure from fellow Republicans. As for Mr. Codey, recent reports had him losing support in his caucus as well, although a couple of Democratic candidates who might have opposed him in a post-election leadership fight were defeated on Tuesday. 
 Over the next few weeks, each has to hold together his caucus, with not a vote to spare, in the fight over the budget. Then starts an election campaign in which the two men, who have become friends, will be trying to unseat each other. 
 In addition to each other, they have a common and formidable enemy in George E. Norcross III, a former Camden County Democratic chairman and Commerce Bancorp executive, who has amassed considerable influence in South Jersey and throughout the state.
 Obviously, each party aims to take control of the Senate. Less obviously -- because to say so openly would offend party solidarity -- some legislators have come to believe that shared control is worse than none at all.
 "The first choice is that their party be in control," said Jon Shure, president of New Jersey Policy Perspective, a research organization here, and a Democrat. "The second choice is that the other party be in control,and the third choice is this."
 Mr. Bennett and Mr. Codey alternate months presiding over the Senate, but they post bills to be voted on by mutual consent; if they cannot agree on the maximum of 30, each may choose up to 9 of his own.
 Together, the two Senate leaders have produced legislation limiting jury awards in medical malpractice cases, restricting campaign contributions and rewriting the auto insurance law. 
 Nonetheless, many in the Senate and many more outside say there was much more to be done.
 "Over all, it's worked out poorly," Senator John H. Adler, a Democrat, said. "My sense is that both parties have managed to find a way to avoid dealing with some of the hardest issues. We haven't slowed the growth of local government or the property tax, haven't found a fairer way to tax New Jersey residents, haven't done a lot legislatively to deal with sprawl or New Jersey's economy."
 Senator Joseph M. Kyrillos Jr., the state Republican chairman, said, "It's amazing that we've been able to do what we've done, although I'm not sure we've accomplished much." 
 Since both parties have a reasonable shot at winning control, Mr. Shure said, legislative business has turned into a kind of perpetual campaign.
 "What's happening in New Jersey mirrors what's happened in Washington," Mr. Shure said, "which is legislative governance has taken a back seat to legislative politics." 
 But Mr. Salmore sees a bigger leadership vacuum in Trenton. 
 "In general, I think the quality of the leadership in both parties is not as good as it was 10 or 15 years ago," he said. "There's no strong personality down there. There is no strong, effective leader that is setting an agenda in Trenton. It's a matter of local warlords." 
 He added that neither Mr. Bennett nor Mr. Cody had "articulated a coherent agenda, an articulation of where they want state policy to go."
 And to make matters worse, he continued, "The Democrats are afraid to cut taxes and the Republicans are afraid to cut spending." 
 Both Senate presidents protest that the legislative process has been surprisingly orderly, and some outsiders agree. Many members say, too, that the Senate has been more productive than the Assembly, where the Democrats have a 42-to-37 majority.
 "We've been able to get things done, all 40 of us," Mr. Codey said. "But despite that, I have one marriage -- it's been a very successful one -- and I don't need this one. I want a divorce." 
 As for Mr. Codey, his own fortunes improved with the primary election results last week. Democratic candidates backed by Mr. Norcross and another Democratic power broker, former state Senator John A. Lynch, who would also like to install someone other than Mr. Codey in a Senate presidency, lost in Monmouth and Hudson counties. 
 Now, said state Senator Raymond J. Lesniak, Mr. Codey's leadership is "absolutely, totally secure."
 "If certain things had turned the wrong way," Mr. Lesniak said, "it could have been in jeopardy."
 Mr. Bennett, on the other hand, is not assured of his own seat in November. He is still fending off the Monmouth County Republican chairman, who says he is not electable, and his home-county newspaper, The Asbury Park Press, which has reported that he overcharged one town he served as municipal attorney, charged unusually high fees for reorganizing the town's municipal code and gave part-time staff jobs to his mother and his mother-in-law.
 Reflecting on his straits, Mr. Bennett said: "I say to Codey: 'You're an Essex County Democrat. You're used to this. I'm a Monmouth County Republican. I'm not used to this."' 
 Mr. Bennett maintains that Mr. Norcross, with whom he quarreled last summer over a proposed sports arena in Newark, vowed to destroy his political career. He says Mr. Norcross gave The Asbury Park Press information that would look suspect, although both Mr. Norcross and the newspaper have dismissed the accusation. 
 He also says Mr. Norcross, through political committees where he has allies, is prepared to pour $2 million into the campaign of Mr. Bennett's opponent, Ellen Karcher. 
 Mr. Norcross declined to comment, but Richard McGrath, the spokesman for the Democratic State Party, said Mr. Bennett was not the object of a vendetta but simply one more beatable Republican. 
 "He's just drawing a bogeyman to make himself a victim," Mr. McGrath said. "His wounds are self-inflicted."
 Mr. Bennett also claims Governor McGreevey as an enemy, although the Democratic governor was publicly sympathetic to the Republican leader when, as the accusations against him piled up in March, many in the State House predicted his demise. 
 Mr. Bennett splashed his primary campaign brochures with the governor's "hit list" of leading Republicans that the Democrats hired researchers to investigate. And Mr. Bennett opened his victory speech Tuesday night with a shout: "I'm proud to be No.1 on the governor's hit list!" 
 Mr. Bennett's margin of victory, 58 percent to 42 percent for his conservative opponent, Rich Pezzullo, clearly buoyed him. Still, he must overcome a discouraging trend even among Republicans: Mr. Bennett's own latest poll, a survey of likely Republican voters taken on May 19, showed that 30 percent viewed him unfavorably, twice as many as did in February, before the newspaper's reports began. The number who viewed him favorably was barely changed, at 56 percent. 
 His Republican colleagues have been publicly supportive, if circumspect.
 "John had a great victory last night and can rightly feel good today," Senator Kyrillos said on Wednesday. "He's shown a lot of steeliness, and he's won his district for a long time." 
 He then added, "I'll leave it at that." 
 In the general election, with four or five closely contested Senate races, the Democrats will have the advantage on spending. They plan to have about $15 million available as against about $8 million that the Republicans are expecting.
 In addition, for more than 40 years the sitting governor's party has lost seats in every midterm election, a pattern that makes the Senate, and perhaps even the Assembly, attainable by the Republicans -- particularly in a year when painful spending cuts will be necessary to make up a budget shortfall that the governor estimates at $5 billion. 
 Any senator who may be angling for the next Senate presidency -- and part of the reason that few are expecting a coup is that no names have been circulating -- will have a chance to achieve a higher profile as the budget is negotiated. 
 The budget must be approved by the end of this month, when all 120 legislators leave Trenton until November. The negotiations will require deal-making, grandstanding and an opportunity for unprecedented cooperation in a divided Senate.
 As Senator Adler put it, "I expect everybody to be obstructionist."

LENGTH: 327 words

HEADLINE: June 1-7; 
OTHER NEWS

 BODY:
NASA's problems go farbeyond falling foam, according to an early outline of the report by the independent panel investigating the accident that doomed the shuttle Columbia and its crew. 
 The outline portrays the fatal Columbia mission as the tip of an iceberg of problems that include communications breakdowns and an increasingly complacent attitude toward warning signs. Budget pressures and administrative shuffles add to the pressure on the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, the report suggests. 
Attorney General John Ashcroft urged Congress to give the authorities still greater power to pursue terrorism suspects. But the USA Patriot Act, as the sweeping antiterrorism law that grew out of the Sept. 11 attacks is known, has led to official votes of protest from more than 100 communities because of civil liberties concerns.
The United States and South Korea agreed gradually to reposition American troops far away from the demilitarized zone that separates North and South Korea to make them less vulnerable to attack by the North.
In the most sweeping reform of its own management in three decades, the New York Stock Exchange will disclose how much it pays its chairman, Richard A. Grasso, and remove Wall Street executives, including a friend of Mr. Grasso, from the committee that sets his pay. Mr. Grasso and other senior officials of the exchange will also step down as directors of companies whose shares are listed on the exchange.
The unemployment rate rose to 6.1 percent in May, its highest level in nine years, but the pace of layoffs has slowed over the last two months, suggesting that the economy might have stabilized and could begin adding jobs this summer, forecasters said. 
 A bipartisan majority of the Senate Commerce Committee indicated that it would vote to overturn some of the deregulatory media-ownership rules adopted last week, but their efforts face an uphill battle, particularly in the House of Representatives.

HEADLINE: Grand Allusions in Botswana 

BYLINE:  By John Leonard; John Leonard reviews books for Harper's Magazine and The Nation, movies for "CBS News Sunday Morning" and television for New York magazine.

 BODY:
 MORTALS
By Norman Rush.
715 pp. New York:
Alfred A. Knopf. $26.95.
 From six years with the Peace Corps in Botswana, Norman Rush has now produced three books so full of brainwork, contour, sinew and laser light that we don't want to leave home without him: we would never notice or feel as much. In the stories in "Whites" (1986), expats shopped for meaning at a Dark Continent spiritual garage sale. "Mating" (1991) was a joy ride, a book of wonders about true love, star-crossed anthropology and a matriarchal Shangri-La in the Kalahari desert. "Mortals" is a disillusionment, a black comedy of blown covers, botched intimacies, bad manners and worse politics in a southern Africa on which, as if it were a sand screen, the West projects its own dementias. 
So "Mortals" isn't another "Mating" -- no windmills, solar panels, dung carts or boomslangs. Not every novel, even by Norman Rush, can be a parable of sex and utopia, an allegory of Mother Africa, a romance of political economy and a rewrite of Botswana's social text in discursive feminism. Many of us felt about "Mating" the way its hero, the "radical decentralist" Nelson Denoon, felt about revolution: "Every- thing we want in a society is what we find brought out in people in the moment of insurrection. Spontaneity! Spontaneous hierarchy! Self-sacrifice! Staying awake all night! Working until we drop! Audacity! Camaraderie! The carnival behind the barricades." For 12 years, even though we should have known better, we've been waiting for a sequel. But "Mortals" is more keening than camaraderie, less a carnival than a curse or purge. 
We do learn from "Mortals" what finally became of Tsau, Denoon's commune in the Kalahari. It is still run by women, but Germans have contracted them to grow and harvest grapple plants, or devil's claw, an ingredient of an aphrodisiac concoction that sells well in international health-food stores. So Tsau has turned into a one-horse company town like Hershey, Pa. 
And 330 pages into the new novel, the hero and heroine of the old one actually show up for a cameo, campaigning against dowry murder, on a stop between India and Zimbabwe. They are less thrilling than we remember. Nelson Denoon, injured while trying to videotape an attempted wife-burning, needs a wheelchair and an oxygen tank. His "mate," who does most of the talking and finally has a name (Karen), is dressed down in a drab tunic and a man's wristwatch. But we are delighted to see them, because by the time Nelson and Karen Denoon arrive in "Mortals," Ray and Iris Finch have already frazzled our nerves. In "Mating" we rooted for Nelson to realize that Karen was as smart as he was and for Karen to decide that Nelson was worth the risk of her autonomy. In "Mortals," we want to avert our eyes as Ray and Iris spend 700 pages throwing away 17 years of marriage. 
"In Africa," thinks Ray, "we're all in costume, look at us." 
Ray and Iris are falling apart from too much of each other, in spite of their cloud trees and house servants, their goat stew and sandalwood, their piggeries and termites. Ray, whose English Lit teaching job at a fancy private school in Gaborone is a cover for his contract service to the C.I.A., as well as a way of imagining himself to be more complicated than he really is, more of an "array" of alternative possibilities, is soon to leave for the north, where some violent trouble is partly his fault. Iris, a decade younger than her husband, "free-associating through the universe of her disappointments," will presently adulterate with a black American doctor, Davis Morel, who, when he isn't treating her mind and body, campaigns to "lift the yoke of Christian belief from Africa." 
Although "Mortals" covers a lot of ground, except for excerpts from a manuscript by Ray's gay brother, Rex, who is dying of AIDS back in the States, and tape recordings of people being spied on, we are stuck inside Ray's head. And it isn't as roomy as Nelson's or Karen's. While he is sometimes obliged to think about Rex, the brother he never loved, or Boyle, his new C.I.A. section boss who did things in Guatemala so terrible that he can't even brag about them, or Kerekang, the dagga-smoking social reformer who quotes Tennyson as often as Ray quotes Milton, mostly Ray obsesses about Iris. She is "his one great friend, his sufficing friend, his pivot and anchor." He wants "to float her in love" so that she will open up "like those paper flowers." Not only, without her, is the world "unintelligible to him," but she is also "uniquely funny." 
(One must say that the evidence for this is inconclusive. Ray, a besotted spouse, dotes on certain Irisisms the drive-by reader is likely to find less than hilarious. He quotes, for instance, her quip that "You must be History because you just repeated yourself." His brother, Rex, seems funnier, describing a Mexico "as frightening as Grace Jones and frightening in somewhat the same way she is. It's sort of beautiful but you get the feeling it wants to bite you." And Ray can be funny, too, especially when hungry, eating the names of writers -- Rice Edgar Burroughs, Oats Joyce Carol, Salmon Rushdie, Spuds Terkel and Bacon Francis.) 
After a while, Ray's uxoriousness seems creepy even to Iris. And when he suspects that she is having an affair, professional paranoia morphs into a persecution complex. His watchfulness, not to be distinguished from spycraft, stalks and suffocates. "You turn into a kind of crouched thing," Iris says, "a crouched listening beast, listening for what everything I say might mean, beyond the simple thing I said itself. . . . It feels like suction." On the other hand, Iris isn't exactly supersubtle, or morale-building, when she says to Ray one night in bed: "Do you know that I don't know if your penis is particularly large or not?" Or when the book she packs for him to read on his trip north is "Madame Bovary." 
"Lately," thinks Ray, who has always hated intuition, coincidence, luck and odd conjunctions, "he was looking too closely at everything around her. It was fear. It felt valedictory." His undercover operations aren't working out much better than his marriage, even if he still feels that "working for the agency resembled working for a giant pharmaceutical more than anything else. Sometimes the pharmaceutical giant got it wrong. It put out the Dalkon Shield, say. But the overall effect of the pharmaceutical was to provide help against disease and suffering, wasn't it?" He consoles himself by recalling passages from D. H. Lawrence, Gerard Manley Hopkins and William Empson: "The true man, the suffering man, is both rebellion and obedience, the ecstasy of apostasy and the hell of inevitable compliance. . . . We are all of us Milton, rebelling and complying and rebelling and complying until we die exhausted."
So far, even in Botswana, we are still on a Cheever/Updike adultery coordinate, with some of Evelyn Waugh's Guy Crouchback to bloody the waters with martyrdom referents. The satiric sendup of postcolonial pretension is equally familiar, from Orwell in Burma to Durrell in Egypt to Burgess in Malaya to Paul Scott in India. So is the spook spoofery, straight out of Graham Greene's Havana and John le Carre's Panama. About Davis Morel's thesis that Christianity is nothing more than "organized regression" and obedience training, intended to infantilize Africans, Rush is as shrewd and hilarious as he was about socialism in "Mating" (with I think a wicked wink at similar sentiments in Nietzsche and Machiavelli). And he is just as postmodern as he is postcolonial when he implies that living in literature is dangerous -- that what looks like "a midden of thought-gems so acute, so beautiful, so apt" as to amount to a how-to manual for the world of action is actually, alas, just another playacting script or delusional system like the cover stories, conspiracy theories and false-bottomed narratives of the clandestine intelligence agencies. 
"Chopping ashes," Iris early on explains to Ray, who thought he knew everything. "Kgabatlela melora. It's what the Batswana say about someone who's doing something really pointless. I guess our closest equivalent would be 'pounding sand,' but that doesn't really capture it in the same way." All the whites in this story seem to be chopping ashes as if they were making art. 
Stop here if you read novels for the plot twists. Now, in the lunatic north, everything gets real and hairy: scorched earth, slaughtered cattle, wild Boers and a brand-new C.I.A. wet dream about Communism's making a race-based comeback with the diamonds and gold of "Mandelaland." Whether or not Kerekang's modest protest movement represents a genuine threat to the ever pliable government of Botswana, the C.I.A. has called in white South African paramilitaries to kill it. Ray, there to observe in his customized Land Cruiser with the money and weapons stashed in a tool chest, is instead held hostage and then tortured by these gangsters. And who should come to check up on him but his wife's lover, the "part-time Antichrist," Dr. Morel with his black medical bag and his own opinions about John Milton, who is likewise arrested, held hostage and tortured. Neither Freud nor Wilhelm Reich can do them any good, much less Wordsworth, Blake and Coleridge, Joyce and Jean Cocteau, Wagner and Matthew Arnold, Yeats and Harold Pinter, Thoreau and Samuel Beckett -- although all of them are mentioned. 
Suffering and fraternity at last . . . but now we must must talk about pilgrimage and levitation, sacrifice and salvation -- about what Norman Rush with a grin calls "immaterialism." Just as Ray emerges from a captivity narrative like Don DeLillo's "Mao II" or Richard Powers's "Plowing the Dark," he suddenly finds himself in another literature altogether, among submachine guns and Molotov cocktails, in a garden of fire in a dead man's boots, with his brother's manuscript strapped to his chest like a suicide bomb. After which, as if in a novel by Dostoyevsky or Robert Stone, he will be resurrected in a cave of snakes in the Bushman desert, and ascend a "monadnock" of boulders more bell-shaped than pyramidal, where he will look at the stars and think about Dante in a holy haze of narcotic smoke. 
I am tempted to say that, in this desert, Siddhartha has met Conrad's Kurtz -- except that Madame Bovary is waiting back at the rondavel for both of them. So marriage is a kind of colonialism, and imperialism is a sort of sex crime, and Christianity turns a blind eye in its other cheek. 
"My utopia," we were told in "Mating" by the anthropologist Karen, "is equal love, equal love between people of equal value, although value is an approximation for the word I want. Why is it so difficult?" Ray's redemption will require him to teach in another country. You may want to go back over the novel to read all the paragraphs you skipped on John Milton and "Paradise Lost," not only to try to figure out who's Cromwell in this scheme -- who's the king and who's the regicide? -- but also to think about Africa as a garden, and the tree of knowledge, and principles of disobedience, and whether Jesus Christ was the first hostage.

HEADLINE: Closeout 

BYLINE:  By Mitch Epstein 

 BODY:
Epstein Furniture was started in 1911 in Holyoke, Mass., by my grandfather, Israel Epstein, who bartered furnishings for potatoes and ponies. In 1939, my father, Bill Epstein, inherited an immigrant dynasty. By 1970, Epstein Furniture was the largest furniture-and-appliance store in western New England. My father kept it open six days a week, every week, for 60 years. If a serviceman wasn't available at night, Dad would make house calls, with a sense of responsibility as great as any doctor's, to fix a broken refrigerator or stove.
 Epstein Furniture was always a family business. My brother, Rick, took over much of the store's management in the last decade. My father's sister, Selma, worked there a couple of hours a day for 25 years. An absence of communication among these three partners plagued the store in its last decade, as America's business culture was changing, with chain stores and marketing campaigns overtaking the shops that were hands-on and word of mouth. 
 In 2000, after years of operating in the red and with no choice in sight, Rick turned the store over to a liquidation company, which held an emergency going-out-of-business sale. My father fought hard against this, but it was too late. Too much had been lost. 
Then, oddly, seven months after the store's official closing, business recommenced. My father refilled the emptied main showroom with whatever hadn't sold at the liquidation, along with odds and ends he had saved for decades for a "final tag sale." The store was, for him, a family legend and the symbol of his life's offering to his family and community. He would not let it go easily.
In the midst of my father's troubles, I went to Holyoke to help, but there was little I could do. I became mesmerized, though, by the drama unfolding, and I was moved to make a piece of work -- part still photography, part video -- to better understand his life. As a young man, I tried to create a life for myself that was altogether different from my father's. Now, years later, documenting the final days of my father's business was a way, even if I didn't know it at the time, to overcome my alienation from my father.
How did Bill Epstein, former Chamber of Commerce Businessman of the Year in 1974, end up in this predicament? 
My father and his generation of men were and still are driven to fulfill an American dream that had its apogee in the 50's: Work hard, do well. When and how did that equation fail -- for him and for a whole country of American dreamers?

Dialogue Overheard at the Liquidation Sale

Husband (after purchasing mattress): A cocktail and two ends?
Saleswoman: $365.
Husband: It's $365? I've just given you $800. I used to work for Simmons; I know how much you paid for the mattress. You made a good profit on that mattress . . . that I know.
Saleswoman (smiles): Let's see what we're talking. What did you say?
Husband: I offered you $250.
Saleswoman: Tell you what, I don't think we're anything near there, but I'll find out.
Wife: Then if we paid $800 for the mattress. . . .
Saleswoman: Yeah, but it's going to be the best investment you've ever made. If you value your sleep -
Husband: I don't sleep.
Wife (laughs): He always sleeps on the sofa.
Saleswoman: Why?
Husband: Well, it's a little place in Southeast Asia.
Saleswoman: Oh, yeah, it took a toll on you. You've never been the same.
Husband: Something like that.
Saleswoman: Something like that.
Husband: I'm on 100 percent disability.
Saleswoman (to wife): Are you from Vietnam?
Wife: No, I'm from China.
Husband: I went to China to pick her up.
Saleswoman: And did he do a good job?
Wife: So far, so good.
Husband: Believe it or not, as time goes on -- it scares me -- it's getting better.

Conversations With My Father
Many factors, according to my father, led to the store's undoing: the new mall on the city's outskirts that, as he put it, "sucked the blood out of downtown"; the ruthless methods of contemporary business; the vagaries of an economy he believed would always carry him aloft, but which marginalized him. "I can't complain about history," he said. "My complaint is of today's business and the way business is done. In my mind, it is too competitive a world." Another time, he admitted what he hadn't been able to all along. "It was a mistake not having accepted that a change was coming about and this was the time to get out," he said. "I didn't make it clear to myself. I should have been more aware of it. It is too late to call the moves over again."
