SECTION: Section 6; Column 1; Magazine Desk; Pg. 83

LENGTH: 3056 words

HEADLINE: The Toxic Pharmacist 

BYLINE:  By Robert Draper; Robert Draper is a writer at large for GQ magazine.

 BODY:
He worked in an obscure little room, 9 feet by 9 feet. For several hours a day, he sat in his white lab coat before a white table in the center of the room, mixing powders and creams in a sterile compartment beneath a ventilator hood. The labor, though humdrum, required great dexterity and care: smoothing gritty chemicals into paste, drawing precise dosages of toxins into saline solutions and, in the end, creating medications from scratch. For nostalgia-prone types in the pharmacy profession, drug compounding was something of a lost art, conjuring up images of cloaked and bearded apothecaries hunched over foaming test tubes. Such romantic notions held no sway over Robert Courtney. He was, at the bottom of his soul, a man of commerce. 
 His customers at Research Medical Tower Pharmacy in Kansas City, Mo., had no inkling of this. After Courtney would emerge from the sterile compounding room with their medications in hand, he greeted them with an Old World civility that complemented his fastidious haircut and the crisply professional dress beneath his lab coat. "What a gentleman," Delia Chelston exclaimed to her husband after the pharmacist offered her a seat while he filled her prescription. Through her oncologist, Chelston also received from Courtney's pharmacy the chemotherapy medication known as Taxol, which she was taking to battle ovarian cancer. By early 2001, it dawned on her that she had been experiencing none of the drug's crippling side effects. After considering the spectrum of possibilities, Chelston did as most cancer patients would. She took the Taxol's seeming benignness as an encouraging sign that she was defeating the odds. 
 Another of Courtney's customers, Mary Ann Rhoads, sadly notified her longtime pharmacist one day that her new insurance company required that she obtain her interferon from another outlet. It surprised Rhoads when Courtney followed her out to her car, tapped on her window and said quietly: "I think I can help you. Bring your insurance cards and come inside." He then refilled her prescription as always and continued to do so thereafter. "I considered it a favor," she recalls. 
And so on a summer day in 2001, when Rhoads discovered that the syringes of medication she had just purchased from Research Medical Tower Pharmacy were barely half full, it did not occur to her to suspect the accommodating Courtney of anything other than human error. After Rhoads returned the syringes to Courtney, he reacted with surprise. Then he disappeared into the obscure little room. He emerged, in time, with freshly filled syringes.
Touching her arm, the pharmacist assured her, "We'll take care of you."
Today, Courtney is a ward of the Federal Bureau of Prisons. For perhaps the next 30 years, he will inhabit a prison cell more or less the size of the room where he committed his crimes. That he has earned his confinement no one, not even Courtney himself, denies -- not after he confessed last year to diluting the medications of thousands of individuals during a nine-year spree of avarice. Mary Ann Rhoads was among the 10 grim-faced cancer patients or surviving loved ones who gave statements during Courtney's sentencing Dec. 5. Since the pharmacist's crime was a novel abomination -- apparently no one had ever sought to dilute chemotherapy medications for profit -- the hearing was charged with anguish and vendetta to a degree seldom seen except at war-crimes trials.
When it was Courtney's turn to speak, he said in a tiny voice, "It's very traumatic listening to these people." Still, in an attempt to explain his actions, he could manage only a stammering, "I don't know why I did this." Then Robert Courtney was led away, a pallid, elfin figure in chains, consigned to freakdom in the annals of pharmacology.
He fit no one's profile of malevolence. Born an itinerant preacher's son in Hays, Kan., in 1952, the source and shape of Robert Ray Courtney's middle American yearnings crawled under the radar of his peer group and teachers alike. They did not appear to blossom until 1986, when the druggist one day asked his boss of 11 years if the latter would be willing to sell his pharmacy in the Research Medical Tower in Kansas City. By the time he acquired a second pharmacy in Merriam, Kan., Robert Courtney was nearing 40 and affecting the vanilla swagger of a suburban Turk. He drove a Mercedes and owned a mammoth house in the exclusive Tremont Manor enclave, situated in the northern reaches of Kansas City. In 1990, Courtney divorced the mother of his two daughters and retained custody of the children. As part of the divorce agreement, Courtney paid her a lump sum of $196,000.
He promptly began wooing an attractive woman he had known since childhood, when his father was a minister in Scott City, Kan., and hers preached to a congregation 50 miles away. She was now living in Detroit, and when she came to visit him, Courtney had charms to dangle. He proffered the keys to his ex-wife's Jaguar. He showered her young son with gifts. He took her out in a horse-drawn carriage. Two months into their courtship, the pharmacist presented her with a four-carat diamond ring. She agreed to a wedding on Valentine's Day 1991. But just after Christmas, Courtney talked her into an elopement. 
Almost instantly, Courtney's second wife (who agreed to be interviewed with the stipulation that she not be named) came to regret her decision. The pharmacist, who always wore dress slacks and striped button-downs even during hours of repose, forbade her to wear casual attire around the house. "He wanted my hair, my clothes, my nails to be perfect," she recalls, "like a doll on a shelf." She wore a size 3 dress; Courtney -- who in the wake of his divorce had shed a great deal of weight -- exhorted her not to gain a pound. At one point, when she had nothing he deemed appropriate to wear to an upscale church event, Courtney handed her $600 and instructed her to buy a new dress. He also told her to dispense with her Pontiac Fiero and buy a new car. He stated, "As long as you're married to me, you'll drive a BMW."
Courtney dispatched his bride to pick out a new house. But her choices, she says, were never sufficiently grand. The pharmacist threw money around in the presence of his church friends. Yet he could also be fiercely parsimonious. He complained that his parents were squeezing him for money, though the new wife could see no evidence that this was so. Just a day or two into their marriage, Courtney informed her that she would have to find a job in Kansas City. He told her that she needed to think of ways they could save money. Courtney came up with one of his own: when the two dined at restaurants, he asked his wife not to order her own dish, but rather to eat off of his plate. 
His moods careered from ebullience to aloofness. She began to be frightened by him. When they disagreed about something, Courtney's face would harden "into that crazed look like he wanted to murder me." He yelled at one of his daughters in public and slapped her at home. The new wife had seen enough and left him after four or five days. Robert Courtney annulled the marriage a few months later. 
Unchastened, Courtney two years later married a third, and much younger, wife, the former Laura Braugh. In 1994, the Courtneys added twins to their brood. Later, Courtney drew up plans for yet another residence, in excess of 5,000 square feet, to be built either elsewhere in Tremont Manor or in the equally coveted Riss Lake subdivision. The house, which never came to fruition, was designed to be child friendly, with the breakfast room and a breezeway angled to permit monitoring of the children at play in the backyard. Courtney was emphatic on these matters. But the architect could not help noticing that the husband did all the talking, while Laura Courtney, the stay-at-home mom, "seemed to be mostly an observer."
Though Courtney's dedication to his family as well as his church may well have been sincere, the economic expression of his attachments is impossible to ignore. He maintained extensive control over the household's financial affairs: Laura had signed a prenuptial agreement, and two of his daughters as well as his father were on his payroll. At Northland Cathedral, Courtney's fine tenor earned him a spot as soloist in the church choir. But it was his money that earned him particular distinction. As far back as 1990, his second ex-wife recalls him "bragging about his donations all the time." In 1999, Courtney pledged $1 million to the church's building fund, to be paid over a three-year period. (The church has announced that it will give the $600,000 thus far received to Courtney's victims.) "He was obviously a person to be respected -- he seemed to command that," says one of his former fellow church members, who also remembers Courtney as "a different sort of fellow, kind of withdrawn. Even in church groups, when something pretty hilarious would be going on, I don't recall us sharing any belly laughs."
To his church friends, Courtney was not an easy read. But pressures were apparently building, some of his own design. After both of them remarried, the pharmacist called his second former wife in the mid-90's. "He sounded stressed," she says. A large family, a plush house and cars, frequent skiing trips to Colorado and massive church donations required the kind of salary few if any licensed pharmacists would ever earn. By his own confession to law-enforcement authorities, Robert Courtney's quest for ill-gotten gains began about the time he divorced his first wife in 1990 and paid her the $196,000. Around then, he began to buy prescription medications from a retired pharmaceutical rep through the so-called gray market -- legitimate drugs acquired outside the supply chain. For the next decade, Courtney purchased these items in cash at an under-the-table discount, marked them up and sold them. It amounted to a nice profit center -- and, perhaps, a criminal point of departure.
"The path to hell leads one step at a time," says Mike Ketchmark, the brash but persistent attorney who successfully litigated a $2.2 billion civil judgment against Courtney. "I think he started from the gray market and realized you could make a whole bunch of money. Then he'd get orders in from people who were on their deathbed, and he'd slice a little bit. Then he realizes he can just continue to cut it, and no one's going to notice. It's a felony once you engage in the gray market; you're then breaking down the barrier of a person's inhibition. You don't go from being John-Boy to Charles Manson overnight."
Two months before his arrest in August 2001, the pharmacist who in 1990 listed his gross income as $48,000 had amassed $18.7 million in total assets. During approximately the same time frame, Robert Courtney would, by law enforcement estimates, dilute 98,000 prescriptions for 4,200 patients.
The sheer voraciousness of his dilutions suggests the compulsion of a pathological shoplifter. At times, Courtney diluted conservatively; at others, he reduced medications to trace amounts, seemingly taunting their recipients: Feel anything now? Though Courtney's highest profits came from diluting expensive chemotherapy medication -- a plaintiff's lawyer says he pocketed as much as $50,000 in the treatments of a single cancer patient -- Courtney adulterated a total of 72 different drugs, including fertility drugs, antibiotics, drugs to prevent nausea and others to improve blood clotting. "Basically," says Judy Lewis, the F.B.I. agent in charge of the Courtney investigation, "if you could mix it or inject it, he diluted it." In addition to shorting prescriptions and buying meds from illegal sources, the pharmacist chiseled whenever an opportunity arose. To one oncologist in the Research Medical Tower where he worked, Courtney dispensed generic drugs while charging them for the more expensive brand-name versions. When customers could not make their $5 or $10 copayments, the kindly pharmacist would let them slide, in exchange for taking back the supposed equivalent portion of their medications to be resold later.
"He was sloppy," says Todd Graves, the United States Attorney who oversaw Courtney's prosecution. But the imperfect criminal had seized upon a perfect crime. As a pharmacist, Courtney knew the vagaries of modern medicine. Studies indicate that up to 50 percent of patients feel they are getting better when treated with placebos. At the same time, one study shows that fewer than 1 in 5 pancreatic cancer victims remain alive a year after treatment with Gemzar chemotherapy. If Robert Courtney's indistinct moral code required a rationale for his criminal behavior, he most likely took comfort in what amounted to his defense in the civil proceedings against him -- namely, that regardless of his dilutions, his customers were destined to die anyway. That a patient's precise response to a particular dosage of chemotherapy remains difficult to discern was glumly acknowledged by Dr. Verda Hunter, the oncologist who first detected Courtney's scheme. Hunter testified in a deposition that even as Courtney was skimping on her patients' medication, "I did not have a time where I felt response rates or range of side effects were unexpected or different."
Courtney understood the peculiar vulnerabilities of his victims and of the professional world he occupied. For all his nefarious extracurriculars, he never strayed far from the drug industry's self-described "closed supply chain," overseen by the Food and Drug Administration, which refers to itself as a regulatory "gold standard." Still, drug company officials themselves estimate that 10 percent of the pharmaceuticals traveling through the closed supply chain are counterfeit. Meanwhile, the industry's pre-eminent sales research organization, IMS Health, concedes that its data capture only "roughly 70 percent of all prescriptions dispensed in the U.S." With so many drugs unaccounted for or fraudulently introduced, Courtney could rest assured that it would be nearly impossible to track his dilutions. 
Still, his connivings were destined to invite scrutiny. Ever secretive, Courtney had long made it his policy to fend off inquiries from pharmaceutical reps in the Kansas City region about how much of which drugs he was selling. The reps, who depended upon such information to claim their commissions, widely considered him a jerk. Darryl Ashley, a sales representative for Eli Lilly, especially loathed Courtney, going back to 1989, when the latter reneged on a sales contract. In 1998, it came to Ashley's attention that Courtney was selling more of Lilly's Gemzar chemotherapy medication to the doctors in the Research Medical Tower than he was buying from Ashley. Ashley figured that Courtney might be getting the drugs outside of regular channels. When an investigation failed to reveal another supplier, Ashley and his superiors let the matter slide. Then in the spring of 2001, Ashley casually mentioned the matter to a nurse who worked for Hunter, whose office was in the Research Medical Tower and who had been buying chemotherapy meds from Courtney's pharmacy since 1999. 
Alarmed by the discrepancy, Hunter decided to have one of the pharmacist's prescriptions for Taxol tested. When the results revealed that the drug was diluted, the doctor became, in her words, "physically sick." And yet even when F.B.I. and F.D.A. agents reviewed the evidence supplied by Hunter on July 27, 2001, the implications seemed inconceivable. Recalls Judy Lewis of the F.B.I., "I think everybody who sat around that table that day had the same feeling, which was: 'There's got to be another explanation. I don't care how it looks. No one could do this."'
The agents persuaded Hunter to take part in a sting operation. Though she had quit using Courtney after the Taxol lab test came back -- prompting the pharmacist to offer a discount -- Hunter now ordered six more prescriptions from Research Medical Tower Pharmacy. On Aug. 7, the F.D.A. provided the test results; each had been diluted to between 17 and 39 percent of the required dosage. That same day, Hunter ordered two more prescriptions of Gemzar and one of Taxol. The results came back from the lab on the 8th. The concentration levels had been reduced to 28 percent, 24 percent and virtually zero. On the late afternoon of Aug. 13, 2001, federal law-enforcement agents swarmed the pharmacy.
Robert Courtney eyed the search warrant with dispassion. Two agents suggested that he follow them outside. The three of them sat in a government vehicle and talked about the three IV bags that Hunter had ordered on the 7th. Yes, the pharmacist acknowledged, he had most likely mixed them himself. Could he explain why their dosages had been so drastically diluted? 
Courtney calmly replied: "No sir, I can't. I don't understand it."
What is even harder to understand is why a man worth nearly $20 million would continue to steal from cancer patients as if his own life depended on it. For his customers like Delia Chelston and Mary Ann Rhoads -- both of whom remain in remission today -- chemotherapy represented a last hope. Robert Courtney, a virtual stranger -- worse still, the friendly neighborhood druggist, a devout Christian and family man of sturdy Midwestern stock -- had snatched that hope away. "I felt violated," Rhoads said during Courtney's sentencing.
If those words fell hard on Courtney, the depths of his remorse can only be deduced by what he is now denied. Incarcerated, he fastidiously writes prayer cards in his prison cell as he once diluted medications in his compounding room. Though church members have visited him in prison and he remains married to Laura, the pharmacist who once demonstrated his commitment to faith and family in monetary terms cannot express his devotion in even the most rudimentary of ways.
Shortly into his imprisonment, the federal inmate petitioned for temporary release to attend the wedding of his daughter Valerie in Tiffany Springs, Mo. Courtney expressed his desire to be able to give his daughter away to her new husband "in the traditional way."
The judge, Robert E. Larsen, denied the motion, noting dryly, "Defendant would be unable to give his daughter away at her wedding while dressed in a prison jumpsuit and wearing leg chains and handcuffs."

HEADLINE: MUSIC: THE PHILHARMONIC TRANSFER; 
Unless Avery Fisher Hall Can Program Its Way Out

BYLINE:  By JOHN ROCKWELL 

 BODY:
LET us assume that the merger between the New York Philharmonic and Carnegie Hall, announced last week, comes to pass. There will be some hurt feelings and some prickly contractual negotiations. But the way everyone is talking, it's a done deal.
 The clear winner is the orchestra. Some of us prefer the drier, clearer acoustics of the orchestra's current home, Avery Fisher Hall, at least for some music. But Carnegie sounds better for most big-orchestra showpieces, and it has a prestige that Fisher has never been able to match. The Carnegie move helps solve the problem of where the orchestra will go during Fisher's reconstruction, a two-year interregnum. It does not solve the longstanding conundrum of what the Philharmonic should do with itself in the summer. But the issue here is the main season, and when the move is completed in 2006, the Philharmonic should be sitting pretty. 
 To my taste, Carnegie Hall will not be sitting so pretty. And as one who once worked for Lincoln Center, as director of the Lincoln Center Festival, I suspect that Lincoln Center is not in as dire straits as some seem to think.
Carnegie owes much of its prestige to the parade of great visiting orchestras that have made music on its stage. When the Vienna Philharmonic, the Berlin Philharmonic, the Boston Symphony, the Philadelphia Orchestra, the Chicago Symphony, the Cleveland Orchestra and many more want to play New York, they want to play at Carnegie. It's been a decades-long festival of excellence: sometimes safe and predictable excellence, and sometimes not as excellent as hype made us hope, but excellence nonetheless. Now that festival is coming to a close.
Avery Fisher Hall been constrained by the Philharmonic's laying legitimate claim to many of its available dates, and most of the prime ones. And in recent decades, the Philharmonic has not been a vividly exciting center of New York's orchestral life. Pierre Boulez was perceived as cold and distant, Zubin Mehta as flashy and uninterested, and Kurt Masur (whom I admired) as sober and stolid. Lorin Maazel is seen as flashy and willful.
All of that could change. The move to Carnegie will probably coincide, more or less, with Mr. Maazel's departure and the advent of a younger, more creatively exciting music director. Maybe even an icon like Arturo Toscanini (who arrived as one) or Leonard Bernstein (who became one), though icons are in short supply these days. It's hard to generate excitement week in and week out, no matter who the music director is. And a lack of excitement can't be compensated for by the added security of an enhanced endowment and new subscription audiences for Carnegie. Although the initial programming announced for the new Zankel Hall is lively, the spark may well dim in the main auditorium.
At Lincoln Center, meanwhile, the immediate impression might be that the rats are scurrying down the hawser, fleeing a sinking ship. The New York City Opera is making noises about abandoning the center for a Ground Zero cultural center not yet designed, let alone built. The Philharmonic is on its way out. Who's next? What is to become of the grand late-50's and early-60's dream of a cultural center that would bring everyone together, a dream that spawned imitators all over the world?
NOT much bad, say I, and maybe something good. The urban-renewal aspect of the Lincoln Center project has long been fulfilled. The remaining constituents -- the Metropolitan Opera, the New York City Ballet, Jazz at Lincoln Center, the Juilliard School, the Lincoln Center Theater, the Film Society of Lincoln Center, the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, the School of American Ballet, the Library of the Performing Arts and Lincoln Center Incorporated, which is both landlord and producing arm -- are not likely to go anywhere soon.
Not, at least, in terms of their membership in the center and the devotion of the bulk of their activities to it. Jazz at Lincoln Center has already moved down to Columbus Circle while retaining its ties to the center. The Lincoln Center Theater and even Great Performers and the Lincoln Center Festival, both productions of Lincoln Center Incorporated, routinely perform off campus.
Even if the constituents squabble among themselves and with the central administration, and even if, deep down, some of them wonder whether having joined the center years ago was such a swell idea, they are pretty much locked in. They are bound by investments in their buildings, a lack of viable alternatives and sheer inertia. In other words, Lincoln Center is not about to disintegrate.
But what about Avery Fisher Hall? The Philharmonic's departure frees up Lincoln Center's planners to reshape the hall for more flexible uses and hence more interesting programming. Of course, unless the center can still somehow get the Philharmonic to pay for part of the redesign, it will be hard to afford. But the economy must eventually turn around. Mustn't it?
As for programming, given a hall applauded by all, with acoustics that allow both musicians and audiences to hear music in a satisfying way, the prospects look bright. Jane S. Moss, the center's vice president for programming, must be licking her chops. For years she has had to squeeze her orchestral offerings in around the Philharmonic's schedule. She has still managed coups, like the London Symphony's Berlioz concerts this season. But the opportunities for coups will now increase exponentially.
They could include other ensembles, extant or newly formed, taking up residence in Fisher Hall. Most likely, they will mean guest appearances more and more imaginatively programmed. Perhaps, even, many of the prestige orchestras that have graced Carnegie will choose to move to Fisher, or be forced to do so by a lack of dates in the Philharmonic's new home. If the revamped Fisher Hall further differentiates itself from Carnegie by slimming down from 2,800 seats to, say, 2,200, it may be more suitable for chamber music and early music than Fisher is now or Carnegie will continue to be.
Not all will be smooth sailing. Standard-issue orchestra concerts -- those without a blue-chip ensemble, box-office stars or extraordinary programming -- have been a hard sell of late in both Fisher and Carnegie. But here is an opportunity for programmatic innovation, and Ms. Moss and her Lincoln Center colleagues have proved themselves good at that. I look forward to the forthcoming upheavals in our musical life with keen anticipation.
Especially if Lincoln Center has the good sense to install a pipe organ in Fisher Hall.

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER; 
The Benefits Of Air Alliances

BYLINE:  By SUSAN STELLIN; SUSAN STELLIN contributes regularly to the Travel section.

 BODY:
FOLLOWING the shifting partnerships among airlines may seem a bit like keeping up with alliances on reality TV shows like "Survivor": of interest to some, but for most people, probably not a worthwhile investment of time.
 However, as the airlines increasingly rely on partnerships to survive an industrywide financial crisis, there are a few things travelers should know about what these agreements mean for consumers, particularly frequent fliers. While the growing number of airline alliances may not bring leisure travelers all the benefits the carriers promise, they do open up opportunities to earn and redeem frequent flier miles. 
 For starters, it's helpful to know which carriers are currently aligned. As on reality shows, these alliances change from time to time. 
 Among the domestic carriers, probably the best-known alliance is between Continental and Northwest, which have been partners since 1998. Tim Cassady, managing director of alliance development for Continental, calls Northwest a "strategic partner," describing this as a deeper level of commitment than Continental has with some of its other partners like Qantas, Hawaiian Airlines and Alaska Airlines.

One Flight, Two Airlines
 Continental and Northwest "code share" on almost all their domestic and international flights, meaning that Continental sells a flight with a "CO" number while Northwest sells that same flight under an "NW" number. Whichever sells the ticket keeps the revenue, but it is the same plane, operated by one of the two carriers. From the airlines' perspective, such relationships enable them to expand their networks without incurring the costs of flying to new destinations themselves.
 A big benefit of the Northwest-Continental alliance -- and typical of other airline partnerships -- is that members of either airline's frequent flier program can choose to earn Continental OnePass miles or Northwest WorldPerks miles on a particular flight. A passenger who buys a ticket from Northwest can give the agent a Continental frequent flier number and earn OnePass miles for the trip. 
 "You don't need to be loyal anymore," said Randy Petersen, editor of Inside Flyer magazine, which tracks frequent flier and other travel loyalty programs. "You can search for the best fare and end up with the miles of your choice, and that's pretty nice." (Partner airlines may have different fares for the same flight.) 
 Most airlines include such mileage arrangements in their partnership agreements, and the options are proliferating. Last summer, Continental and Northwest announced their intention to add Delta Air Lines to their alliance, raising concerns among government regulators that this could stifle competition.
 After some back and forth with the Department of Transportation and the Department of Justice, which must approve such agreements, the Delta addition got the green light. However, Continental and Northwest agreed to limit the number of routes each would code-share with Delta, at least initially, as well as to abide by some other restrictions intended to prevent the carriers from gaining an unfair advantage over smaller competitors. Mr. Cassady, the Continental executive, said that "sometime this summer" the airlines would begin putting various aspects of the alliance, including reciprocal frequent flier benefits, into effect. 
 US Airways and United announced their own alliance last July, which has also received government approval. In October, the two gave members of their airport clubs reciprocal privileges, another benefit typical of alliances. Since last November, members of both airlines' frequent flier programs have been able to earn either US Airways or United frequent flier miles on each carrier's flights and have been able to redeem miles for a free ticket on either airline since April.
 I flew from New York to Pittsburgh on US Airways in January, but chose to earn United MileagePlus miles for the trip. However, when I decide to cash in those United miles for a free ticket, I can do so on either United or US Airways -- or for that matter, a number of other carriers that also have partnerships with United, like Lufthansa, Air Canada or Varig. All three, plus several others, are members of the Star Alliance, www.staralliance.com, an international alliance of airlines that enables each member's frequent fliers to earn and redeem miles on the others' flights.
 American Airlines, in turn, is a member of the oneworld alliance, www.oneworld.com, which also includes British Airways, Cathay Pacific, Iberia and Qantas, among others. Domestically, American also has a partnership with Alaska Airlines.
 Despite -- or maybe because of -- all these overlapping partnerships, many travelers "don't really knowwhat they mean, and more importantly, they don't know how to take advantage of them," Mr. Petersen said.
 "Alliances are probably one of the most valuable assets of a frequent flier membership, both for earning miles and burning miles," he said, adding that travelers who cannot redeem miles for the route or dates they want on one airline can often find seats available on a partner.

Finding a Line's Partners
 But that does not mean you can take 10,000 miles from, say, your United Mileage Plus account and combine them with 15,000 US Airways Dividend Miles for a free domestic ticket. All the miles for an award have to come from one account, and the programs themselves remain separate, with their own award levels and rules. The best way to find out which airlines a carrier is partnered with is to check its Web site; most list their airline partners in the section describing their frequent flier program.
 Terry Trippler, who follows air fares for CheapSeats.com, advises travelers considering a flight that is a code share to check the fares with both airlines. "It's the same airplane, but the fare could be different on both airlines," he said. Also, one partner may be sold out and the other has seats available, he said. 
 Although airlines are required to tell customers a flight is a code share, Mr. Trippler said, they cannot say what price the partner has available for that same flight; travelers have to find out on their own. Also, domestic airlines are prohibited from discussing fares with domestic competitors, alliance or not.
 For their part, the airlines mainly benefit from these alliances by being able to sell tickets to customers headed to places they do not fly. "Every airline in the world, big or small, serves some markets very well, serves other markets in a mediocre way and some markets not at all," said Ben Baldanza, senior vice president of marketing and planning for US Airways. "When you put two networks together, we both become stronger."
 At a time when many carriers have either declared or face bankruptcy, these alliances do have some "Survivor" parallels.
